name: 10th Royal Hussars Memorial
description:
10th Royal Hussars Memorial
The Regiment was raised as Humphrey Gore’s Regiment of Dragoons at Hertford in 1715 as part of the response to the Jacobite rising. 
In 1784, His Majesty King George III appointed his son, then Prince of Wales, as Colonel of the Regiment which has since borne the title of ‘Prince of Wales’s Own’ with the coronet and feathers, together with the Rising Sun and Red Dragon (an ancient badge of Wales) and the motto “Ich Dien” (“I serve”). 
The Regiment campaigned in the Peninsula War and fought at Waterloo. The 10th were in the Crimea and were awarded two VCs in the South African War. 
In 1806, the Prince of Wales obtained permission to clothe and equip the regiment as Hussars and it thus became the First Hussar Regiment in the British Army. The 10th Royal Hussars has taken part in most British Army campaigns around the world. On 25 October 1969, the 10th Royal Hussars amalgamated with the 11th Hussars to form the Royal Hussars. 
One nickname is ‘The shiny 10th’, possibly a derivation from the earlier ‘Chainy 10th’ which came from various ‘chain mail’ type uniform insignia and decoration which needed to be kept highly polished.

name: 11th (Prince Albert's Own) Hussars (The Cherry Pickers) Memorial
description:
The 11th Hussars (Prince Albert’s Own) 
The 11th Hussars (Prince Albert’s Own) was established in 1715 as a cavalry regiment of the British Army. 
Conflicts and battles in which the Regiment has taken part are listed on the plinth, including the Battle of Waterloo and Charge of the Light Brigade. The Regiment is associated with notable personalities including Prince Albert (husband of Queen Victoria) from whom the Regiment got its famous cherry coloured trousers. The nickname Cherry Pickers came after an incident in a cherry orchard during the Peninsular War. 
During the Second World War, the Regiment led the Desert Rats, the 7th Armoured Division, and were the first British troops into Berlin. The 77 battle honours shown on the memorial tell the full story. The Regiment was amalgamated with the 10th Royal Hussars in 1969.

name: 17th Dogra Regiment Memorial
description:
17th DOGRA REGIMENT MEMORIAL
The Dogra Regiment was raised in 1887 from the foothills of the Himalayas and earned laurels for valour in both World Wars, including Nunshigam, Imphal and Kota Bharu in the Second World War Burma campaign.

name: 1940 Dunkirk Veterans' Association Memorial
description:
DUNKIRK MEMORIAL 
▪ The Dunkirk evacuation code name Operation Dynamo (also known as the Miracle of Dunkirk), was the evacuation of Allied soldiers during WW2 from the beaches and harbour of Dunkirk in northern France, between 26 May and 4 June 1940. 
▪ The operation started after a large number of British, Belgium and French troops were cut off and surrounded by German troops during the six-week battle of France. 
▪ Royal Navy ships were involved, and hundreds of small vessels went out to help in the evacuation including merchant ships, fishing boats, pleasure craft and yachts. 
▪ On the first day of the evacuation over 7,600 were evacuated and by the last day of the operation around 338,000 had been rescued.

name: 1st Airborne Reconnaissance Squadron Memorial ; Freddie Gough Squadron
description:
1st Airborne Reconnaissance Squadron - The Freddie Gough Squadron. 
This black Scottish granite memorial is dedicated to the men of the 1st Airborne Reconnaissance Squadron, known as the Freddie Gough Squadron. The 1st Airborne Reconnaissance Squadron was a Reconnaissance Corps unit which formed part of the 1st Airborne Division and was sent to North Africa, seeing service in Italy, Arnhem and finally in Norway. It had various names before the authorities settled on the name by which it was finally known.  The first commanding officer was Major Freddie Gough and it quickly became known as the Freddie Gough Squadron. It should be noted that Major Gough came from a distinguished military family (see below). Charles Frederick Howard “Freddie” Gough was born in India in September 1901. He was awarded the MC for his actions with the Squadron during the Italian Campaign. The Squadron took part in the Battle of Arnhem; hence the location of this memorial. Freddie Gough was taken prisoner at the Bridge at Arnhem and remained a POW until he escaped in April 1945. 75 men from the Squadron escaped from the Arnhem Battle and at the end of the war were sent to Norway to help disarm the German occupying forces. During the autumn of 1945 the Squadron was demobilised. After the war Freddie Gough was Member of Parliament for Horsham and died at the age of 76 while on holiday on Italy in 1977. 
The Gough VCs 
Three members of the Gough family were awarded the Victoria Cross. 
General Charles John Stanley Gough VC, GCB 
General Hugh Henry Stanley Gough VC, GCB (brother of Charles & grandfather of Freddie) 
Brigadier General John Edmund Gough VC, KCB, CMG (son of Charles)

name: 1st Army Memorial
description:
1ST ARMY
▪ 1st Army was first formed in WW1 1914-1918, then disbanded only to be reformed in WW2 1942-1943. They were reformed to fight in Operation Torch the allied invasion of North Africa. After the allied victorythe 1st Army was disbanded.

name: 1st Queens Dragoon Guards Memorial
description:
QUEEN’S DRAGOON GUARDS Map
The memorial features a stone monolith, remembering those who served in:
 1st Queen’s Dragoon Guards
 1st King’s Dragoon Guards
 The Queen’s Bays (2nd Dragoon Guards)
Cavalry regiments converted to armoured cars and tanks in the 1930s.

name: 216 Squadron RAF
description:
216 SQUADRON ROYAL AIR FORCE
In 1918 ‘A’ Squadron, Royal Naval Air Service was renumbered as No 216 (two-sixteen) Squadron Royal Air Force. It was designated a bomber-transport squadron for strategic bombing during the latter stages of WW1 and during the inter war years in the Middle East. On the outbreak of war with Italy in June 1940 the units’ aircraft undertook bombing sorties, then concentrated on transport flying, moving squadrons around the Middle East and Greece and keeping open the supply and reinforcement routes. In 1941 the Squadron agreed to provide a Bristol Bombay aircraft for the newly formed SAS for its first real parachute jump into the North African Desert. . 1955, the Squadron returned to the United Kingdom and received the Comet 2 aircraft and continued to operate these aircraft in the transport role, particularly for Royal and VIP flights. During the Falklands War the Squadron assumed the task off a refuelling Unit including the twice weekly schedule to the Falklands Islands At the end of July 1990, Iraq invaded Kuwait. No 216 Squadron with eight Tri star aircraft made a significant contribution including air-to-air refuelling and troop-carrying in support of both the RAF and US Navy, as it did later in Iraq and Afghanistan In 2020 No. 216 Squadron reformed to become an experimental unit that will test future drone swarm technology. Based at RAF Waddington. The memorial was dedicated in April 2022.

name: 3 (F) Squadron Association
description:
3 (Fighter) Squadron RAF; 3 Squadron RAF 
The No. 3 Fighter Squadron Memorial honours the courage and sacrifice of those who have given their lives to the defence of the UK through two World Wars, subsequent world conflicts, the ‘Cold War’ and general air operations. 
Squadron History 
In the Beginning 
Following the issue of a Special Army Order, dated 28th February 1911, the Air Battalion of the Royal Engineers was formed on 1st April 1911, comprising No.1 (Airship) Company and No.2 (Aeroplane) Company. The creation of No.2 Company, stationed at Larkhill, marked the first formation of a British military unit composed of heavier-than-air flying machines. No.2 Company continued flying training including participation in the Army’s Autumn (1911) manoeuvres. 
The Royal Flying Corps The Royal Flying Corps (RFC) was formed on 13 May 1912 by absorbing the Air Battalion’s No.1 and No.2 Companies, with No.2 Company being renamed No.3 Squadron (Military Wing) RFC. On the outbreak of World War 1 the Squadron deployed to France as part of the British Expeditionary Force (BEF) in August 1914 on reconnaissance, photography and artillery spotting duties. In October 1917 Sopwith Camels were received, and the Squadron became a fighter / scout unit. After the Armistice, the Squadron was reduced to cadre strength until re-established at Ambala (India) from January 1920 to September 1921. 
The Biplane Era 
After returning to UK the Squadron spent the 1920s on many short periods at various locations before arriving at Upavon in 1924 with Sopwith Snipes. During their ten-year stay, the Squadron flew Woodcocks, Gamecocks and Bulldogs. The Bulldog was deployed to Sudan during the Abyssinian crisis in 1935. Upon its return from Sudan, No. 3 Squadron introduced the Gladiator into the RAF which became the last biplane operated by the Squadron and as the Second World War started converted to the Hurricane at Biggin Hill. 
World War 2 
A brief period with the BEF in France was followed by relocation to Scotland on night-patrol duties. During 1943, the Squadron replaced the Hurricanes with Typhoons and switched to the anti-shipping and intruder roles. After re-equipping with Tempests in 1944, the Squadron destroyed 288 V1 flying bombs, and following D-Day in 1944 moved on to the Continent as part of the advance towards Germany. 
The Jet Era 
The Squadron remained in Germany, converting successively to the Vampire in 1948, the Sabre in 1953 and the Hunter in 1956. After disbanding (1957 –1959) a brief time with Javelin fighters was followed by an extended period of Canberra B(I)8 operations, before the Squadron converted to the Harrier early in 1972 at Wildenrath. In 1977 the unit moved to Gutersloh near the old East German border, before relocating to Laarbruch with the Harrier GR7. 
Following the closure of RAF Laarbruch, the Squadron returned to the UK in 1999, to RAF Cottesmore. Subsequently, No. 3 Squadron, along with its sister RAF Harrier and Royal Navy Sea Harrier units, combined to form Joint Force Harrier and undertook several deployments including on-board HMS Illustrious during operations in Sierra Leone. The Harrier aircraft of No 3 Squadron also saw action in Kosovo, Bosnia-Herzegovina and both of the Iraq conflicts. 
Farewell to the Harrier 
On the 31 March 2006, the Squadron relinquished its Harrier role and moved to RAF Coningsby becoming the third RAF, and first front-line Squadron to be equipped with the Eurofighter Typhoon. The Squadron’s Typhoons continue to contribute to the RAF’s on-going commitments in Iraq & Syria plus participating in the Falkland Islands detachments and QRA (Quick Reaction Alert) to the present day. 
The date of dedication is May 12th 2023, a date which closely commemorates the 111th Anniversary of the Squadron’s inclusion in the Royal Flying Corps in 1912. 
Symbolism 
There are two faces to the memorial, the aspect facing the Armed Forces Memorial carries the Squadron’s battle honours, while the other side records the time line of its origin in 1911 and its status as recorded in official Air Ministry records. Both aspects carry the Squadron badge with the inscription ‘Tertius Primus Erit’ – The Third Will Be First. The central image is of a cockatrice mounted on a monolith, said to represent a fallen stone from Stonehenge. A cockatrice is a mythical beast that is hatched by a serpent from an egg laid by a rooster, and reputedly able to kill at a glance. The frontal aspect carries two smaller badges, one representing the first location of Larkhill on Salisbury Palin in 1912. Again, the stones symbolise the Squadron’s location of nearby Stonehenge. The second badge is carried on the Typhoon FGR4, which commenced operations in 2006.

name: 36th Ulster Division
description:
36th Ulster Division. The memorial commemorates the actions of the 36th (Ulster) Division during the First World War. The 36th (Ulster) Division, formed in September 1914 under Kitchener’s ‘New Army’ recruitment initiative, played a vital role in the Great War. Commanded initially by Major General C H Powell C.B., the Division was made up from units of the Ulster Volunteer Force, which had been formed in 1913 to fight against Home Rule in Ireland. After initial training in Ireland, Seaford and Aldershot, the Division was deployed to France in September 1915 under the command of Major General Oliver Nugent C.B. D.S.O. The 36th (Ulster) Division took part in the long awaited ‘Big Push’– the Battle of the Somme - commencing on 1 July 1916. Remarkably, progressing as far as the German Third Line, they were the farthest advances made on the day. However, the Division subsequently got caught in German enfilade (flanking) fire from the side and from behind and with the possibility of being cut off with limited supplies they withdrew and were relieved the following day having suffered heavy causalities. The bravery and exploits of the Division are legendary - seeing action in many of the subsequent campaigns of the Western Front until the Armistice in November 1918. The Division ceased all military action at the end of June 1919 when the last soldiers were de-mobbed. It is estimated that The Great War cost 36th (Ulster) Division 32,186 men killed, wounded or missing. The memorial comprises a large, rustic, black granite stone on a base plinth with a black polished façade inscribed with gold lettering. The stone’s rugged profile, suggesting the toughness of the men who fought in the 36th (Ulster) Division, is emphasised by the lines of the polished face. The heraldic Red Hand of Ulster (depicted: sinister / left), which is the insignia badge of the 36th Division, is featured at the top of the memorial above the following inscription: This memorial is dedicated to the Officers and Men of the 36th (Ulster) Division who fought in the 1st World War and the Nursing and Medical corps who served beside them. At the centre of the memorial is a reproduction of the famous James Prinsep Beadle painting ‘The Attack of the Ulster Division’ depicting a scene on the fist day of the Battle of the Somme (1 July 1916), the original of which hangs in the City Hall, Belfast. The Division’s Western Front campaigns are listed either side of this.
Interestingly, soil from each of Ulster’s nine Counties has been placed within the memorial along with soil from the following battlefield sites: Somme, Messines, Passchendaele, Wytchaete and Polcapelle. In total, nine members of the 36th (Ulster) Division were awarded the Victoria Cross, four of which were awarded for actions during the Battle of the Somme.
Below the central painting is a verse from the poem Remember Them by D. Ross Campbell:
They heard the call, they answered yes,
They proudly wore the battle dress,
For us who live they gave their all
That our great flag would never fall.
The base of the memorial displays the inscription: At the going down of the sun and in the morning we will remember them, whilst the reverse notes the memorial was funded by the 36th (Ulster) Division Memorial Association.
Footnote:
The famous Ulster Tower memorial (based on Helen's Tower in Clandboye near Belfast), which dominates the skyline around the village of Thiepval in Northern France, occupies the site of what was the German Front Line and is opposite Thiepval Wood where the 36th (Ulster) Division made its historic charge on the first day of the Battle of the Somme.

name: 41 Club Memorial
description: 41 Club Memorial. Celebrates the community service achievements by former Round Table members (young men aged between 18 and 45) since the association was founded. 41 trees, surround a central obelisk.

name: 45 Commando, 'Baker' Troop
description:
Baker Troop – 45 Commando
This memorial honours all Royal Marines who were members of the ‘Baker’ Troop – 45 Commando – (1955 - 1957) serving with distinction in the Cyprus EOKA Emergency and the Invasion of Suez. The memorial was presented with the aid of a legacy from Captain F Collingwood BEM RM.

name: 4th Royal Tank Regiment 1916 - 1993 Memorial Altar
description:
4th Royal Tank regiment 1916-1993
This stone Alter was originally presented to the Church Centre, York Barracks, Munster in Germany.
It was later rescued and re-erected at the Arboretum by the 4th Royal Tank Regiment of Scotland.
Dedicated on 5 May 2016, the memorial commemorates all those who served in “D” Company Heavy Section Machine Gun Corps, “D” Company Tank Corps, 4th Battalion Royal Tank Corps, and the 4th Royal Tank Regiment 1916-1993.
The badge of the 4th Royal Tank Regiment is inscribed on the upright face of the memorial together with the Regiment motto: “Fear Naught”.

name: 624 (Special Duties) Squadron RAF Memorial
description:
M-286 624 (Special Duties) Squadron RAF
This squadron was formed in September 1943 and carried out Special Duties Operations into Greece, 
Romania, Albania, Italy, Corsica, Sardinia, Southern France, Yugoslavia and Czechoslovakia. They 
dropped agents and supplies to partisans and resistance forces and operated from Algeria, Tunisia, 
Libya and Italy. 
The squadron was disbanded in September 1944. 
The memorial, Established in 2012, was instigated by Ron McKeon who has a plaque in the Sun 
Room and is supported by members of the 4624 Royal Auxiliary Air Force and 624 Veterans. The 
memorial is located in the Special Operations Garden opposite the 299 Squadron Stone and close to 
the Vera Atkins memorial seat.

name: 8th Army Memorial
description:
DESERT RATS
• Located by Lions Shelter and Gulf War Memorial
• The 7th Armoured Division was a division of the British Army that saw distinguished service during World War II, where its exploits in the Western Desert Campaign gained it the ‘Desert Rats’ nickname. Since then, the desert rats insignia has been worn by generations of military units, celebrating the kinship and tenacity of those men and women fighting in the desert.
• The stylised sculpture, whilst representing the Desert Rats insignia, also symbolises armour, both light and heavy.
• The sculpture sits on a stone plinth, with sloping sides to represent the angles used on some armour and tanks. The sides of the plinth are carved with a sand motif with the words “Desert Rats” engraved and fading in and out of the pattern to suggest movement through time and sand.

name: 90 Signals Unit RAF TCW Memorial
description:
90 Signals Unit TCU
90 Signals Unit (90SU) provides a vital role in ensuring the RAF achieves operational success and exists to provide Expeditionary Information Services, whenever they are required. 
Comprising two Wings, Force Generation Wing (FGW) and Tactical Communications Wing (TCW), the Unit’s history can be traced back to the mid1950s, although TCW did not become an autonomous signals unit until later (1973). 
Since this time, 90SU have been involved in every major conflict and support operation that has taken place worldwide.

name: 9th/12th Royal Lancers Memorial
description:
9th/12th Royal Lancers
The 9th/12th Royal Lancers can date its ancestry back to 1715 with the formation of Wynn's Dragoon and Bowles Dragoons. The antecedent regiments served in many campaigns including the Peninsular War, Waterloo, Crimean War, Indian Mutiny, Boer War, WW1 and WW2. In May 2015 it was amalgamated with the Queen's Royal Lancers (see Memorial M-287) to form the Royal Lancers.
The amalgamation history is shown in the table below.
9th/12th Royal Lancers (Prince of Wales’s) September 1960
o 9th (Queens Royal) Lancers 1830 from 9th Regiment of (Light) Dragoons ) Lancers) 1816 from • 9th Regiment of (Light) Dragoons 1783 from 9th Regiment of Dragoons 1751 from Wynn’s Dragoons 1715
o 12th (Prince of Wales’s) Royal Lancers 1817 from 12th (Prince of Wales’s) Lancers 1816 from • (Prince of Wales’s) Light Dragoons 1768 from 12th Regiment of Dragoons 1751 from Bowles’s Dragoon’s 1715

name: Adjutant General's Corps Commemorative Garden
description:
ADJUTANT GENERAL’S CORPS
(In front of the Staffords) They have responsibility for administration, pay, education, legal and policing matters relating to Army personnel.
It doesn’t sound exciting, but they are often required to fight alongside frontline troops, and of course the British Army would quickly grind to a halt without them.
 (In front of the Staffords) They have responsibility for administration, pay, education, legal and policing matters relating to Army personnel.
It doesn’t sound exciting, but they are often required to fight alongside frontline troops, and of course the British Army would quickly grind to a halt without them.

name: Aguila Memorial (WRNS) (Wrens)
description: Aguila Memorial (WRNS) (Wrens). Located in the garden The Women’s Royal Naval Service (WRNS) Garden, is the Aguila Memorial, a beautifully carved wren which commemorates the 21 WRNS and one Naval Nursing Sister who were lost when SS Aguila was torpedoed in 1941

name: Air Formation and Air Support Signals Memorial
description:
Air Formation and Support Signals
The Air Formation and Air Support Signals Memorial is in the RAF Wing.

name: Aircrew Association Memorial
description:
The Aircrew association
memorial is in memory of the Air Crews of WW2. The 3-armed bushes represent the propeller blades of a Spitfire, with a walnut tree nearby as the centre boss and blades of an early Spitfire propeller was made of walnut wood.

name: Allied Special Forces Association Grove
description:
Allied Special Forces Association Grove 
The Allied Special Forces Association Grove is a living memorial, laid out in the form of an ‘Open Air Book’, where you can read about individuals and military units who have served with the Allied Special Forces up to the present day. The Grove has an oak sun room at its heart, and includes memorials to historical moments such as; the Dieppe Raid, Cockleshell Heroes, the Battle of Mirbat, the Falklands Conflict and many others.

name: Allied Special Forces Association Sun Room
description: Allied Special Forces Association Sun Room. The Allied Special Forces Association Grove is a living memorial, laid out in the form of an ‘Open Air Book’, where you can read about individuals and military units who have served with the Allied Special Forces up to the present day. The Grove has an oak sun room at its heart, and includes memorials to historical moments such as; the Dieppe Raid, Cockleshell Heroes, the Battle of Mirbat, the Falklands Conflict and many others.

name: Amalanchier Walk
description: Amalanchier Walk

name: Ambulance Services
description:
AMBULANCE SERVICE 
The green granite memorial reflecting the medical green of the Ambulance Services was dedicated in 2004. 
It is a lasting tribute to those ambulance staff who lost their lives whilst serving in the ambulance services of England, Scotland, Wales, Northern Ireland, Republic of Ireland, Guernsey and Jersey. 
The garden is in the shape of a large letter ‘A’ – being both the initial letter of the service and to stand for ‘Asclepius’, the Greek God of healing and medicine. 
On the memorial stone itself is the blue 6-pointed ‘Star of Life’ with the ‘Rod of Asclepius’ at its centre. This is now the internationally recognised symbol for emergency medical service units and personnel.

name: Ancient Burial Mound
description:
Ancient Burial Ground 
At the heart of the Arboretum is a Bronze Age burial mound that is between 3500 and 4500 years old. 
The Bronze Age is the name given to the period of time between the Stone Age and the Iron Age. Bronze is a metal alloy, or mixture of tin and copper, and was used extensively to make a wide range of tools and weapons. 
The monument was first identified from an aerial photograph taken in 1965, which revealed the visible cropmarks of a prehistoric multiple ring ditch. It was later Scheduled as a site of historic significance in 1969. Although there is little in the way of discernible remains above ground the site is now a set-aside wildflower meadow which attracts much important wildlife. 
During excavations in 1996, a prehistoric pottery vessel thought to be a late example of Beaker Ware, was discovered by archaeologists about 0.5m below the surface. Very few examples have been found in the Trent Valley and so this is an important find. The vessel is currently on display in the Landscapes of Life exhibition in the Remembrance Centre. 
In the Bronze Age, many important people were buried under mounds like this one. Excavations show that it was probably part of a much bigger commemorative landscape that included other burial monuments. Between 1500 and 500 BC, this prehistoric landscape seems to have changed. No new monuments were built, and the meaning of the old ones probably faded as farming and flooding eroded their remains. Thousands of years later, archaeologists working during quarrying are revealing their stories. 
Bronze Age burial mounds marked territory and reflected status. Their size and positioning in the landscape sent out a message. This mound is set above where the River Tame meets the Trent.

name: Anglo-Japanese Peace Garden
description:
ANGLO-JAPANESE GROVE OF RECONCILIATION 
The circular grove of European and Japanese maple trees is the ANGLOJAPANESE GROVE OF RECONCILIATION, presented by Japanese business people. The intermingling of their leaves symbolizes the strengthening friendship between the two nations, as does the pink granite STONE OF RECONCILIATION itself, which was presented to us by the Japanese Government. 
Adjacent to it is the HIROSHIMA CAIRN. The top-most stone was donated by the people of HIROSHIMA, the Japanese city destroyed by a bomb (named Little Boy) in August 1945 and is dedicated to the millions of people who died and suffered in the Second World War.

name: Arctic Convoys Memorial;Russian Convoys
description:
ARCTIC CONVOYS
Arctic Convoys - Russian Convoys 
This memorial of black Aberdeen granite was dedicated on 14 August 2012 in honour of all who sailed on the Arctic Convoys during the Second World War. 
The memorial’s inscription is engraved in both English and Russian. Between June 1941 and May 1945, the United Kingdom supplied Russia with millions of tons of war-related goods. These convoys were protected by Royal Navy ships of many types, with only 22 losses. Men serving on these ships undertook this most hazardous journey through seas littered with floes and bergs with force nine and 11 winds whipping the seas into mountainous waves. It was always cold, both inside and out, with the permanent duty of ice breaking from the superstructure to prevent them from capsizing and sinking. The convoys suffered constant attack from the German Navy and Air Force from their safe ports in Norway. Winston Churchill called it “The worst journey in the world”. This is the only major memorial at the Arboretum paid for by one family: the Coyle Family. The adjacent tree is dedicated to Michael Joseph Coyle who served on Royal Navy ships escorting the merchant vessels to Russian ports. Millions of tons of war-related goods were supplied to Russia to help in their conflict against Germany. These supplies had to be carried by sea to Archangel or Murmansk. The convoys of merchant ships had to be guarded by the Royal Navy from attack by German naval and air forces. Weather conditions were usually very poor with frequent heavy seas and sub-zero temperatures. Winston Churchill called it ‘The worst journey in the world.’ The laser-engraved main image shows a British warship navigating in a stormy sea. Also shown are badges of the Arctic Convoy Club and the Russian Convoy Club. Script on the memorial is engraved in both English and Russian. The terms Russian Convoys or Murmansk Convoys could also be used for search purposes. 
The Arctic convoys of WW2 sailed from the United Kingdom, Iceland, and North America to northern ports in the Soviet Union – primarily Arkhangelsk (Archangel) and Murmansk. 
There were 78 convoys between August 1941 and May 1945 
About 1,400 merchant ships delivered essential supplies to the Soviet Union under the Anglo-Soviet agreement and US Lend-Lease program, escorted by ships of the Royal Navy, Royal Canadian Navy and U.S. Navy 
85 merchant vessels and 16 Royal Navy warships (two cruisers, six destroyers, eight other escort ships) were lost. 
In some books the Arctic Convoys are referred to as the Russian Arctic Convoys or the Murmansk Run

name: Arethusa Old Boys Association
description: Arethusa Old Boys Association

name: Argyll and Sutherland Highlanders Memorial ; Royal Scottish Regiment
description:
Princess Louise’s Argyll and Sutherland Highlanders 
Princess Louise’s Argyll and Sutherland Highlanders were formed in 1881 from the amalgamation of the 91st Regiment of Foot (Argyll Highlanders) and the 93rd Regiment of Foot (Sutherland Highlanders). In 2006, they were absorbed into the Royal Regiment of Scotland. 
During the First World War 27 Battalions were raised. Nine thousand Argyll and Sutherland Highlanders gave their lives in the First and Second World Wars. 
Sixteen members of the Regiment, including seven in the Sutherland Highlanders, were awarded the Victoria Cross.

name: Armed Forces Memorial
description:
Armed Forces Memorial 
The Armed Forces Memorial, dedicated in the presence of Her Late Majesty Queen Elizabeth II on 12 October 2007, is a nationally significant focus for Remembrance, providing recognition and thanks for those from our Armed Forces who have given their lives in the service of the country since the end of the Second World War. The Memorial is a stunning piece of architecture designed by Liam O’Connor, which draws its inspiration from the ancient landscapes of prehistoric Britain and the classical forms of ancient Rome. It consists of a six-metre-high earth mound, 100 metres wide at the base reducing to 50 metres wide at the top, which is based on early British barrows or tumuli. The spiral walkway that navigates the grassy slopes, planted with clipped holm oaks 'Quercus ilex', provides accessibility to people of all ages and levels of mobility. At the top of the mound stands a 43 metre diameter stone structure, comprising two curved walls and two straight walls which are constructed of 200,000 bricks faced with over 1,000 tonnes of Portland stone panels. In recognition of the importance of Armistice Day, a gap has been left in the two southern walls, which allows a shaft of sunlight to penetrate to the heart of the Memorial, onto the central bronze wreath. 
The Memorial is particularly important for the many families and friends who have no grave to visit, or who remember those in graves in far-off places. The Memorial plays a valuable role in helping all who grieve for an Armed Forces service person to come to terms with their loss, by providing a focus for their grief as they pass through different stages of their lives. The names are arranged firstly by year and then in service order: Royal Navy, Army and then the Royal Air Force. Within service order the names are arranged chronologically, in the order of the event which caused the death. This ensures that those who died together are recorded and remembered together. The name and initials are shown without ranks but, where appropriate, honours are also included. In the summer of each year the names of those who have died in the previous year will be carved and their names dedicated at a special service. At the centre of the Memorial are two bronze sculptures, the embodiment of loss and sacrifice. Created by Ian Rank-Broadley, best known for his image of Her Late Majesty Queen Elizabeth II which appeared on all UK and Commonwealth coinage produced between 1998 - 2015, the sculptures bear silent witness to the cost of armed conflict. This significant work is becoming an icon identifiable to all and especially to those who live with the consequences of the Nation’s call to duty.

name: Armed Services Wood
description:
Armed Services Wood 
The Armed Services Wood is a woodland of mixed trees individually sponsored as living tributes to those who served in the British Army, the Royal Navy and the Royal Air Force.

name: Army Air Corps Memorial
description:
ARMY AIR CORPS
▪ On our left we have a striking brass eagle memorial for the Army Air Corps. The plinth is made of Portland stone and the darker stone in the circular base represents helicopter rotor blades. The Corps supplies air support to the Army in the form of an attack helicopter, the Apache, or reconnaissance & transportation of troops or supplies, in the form of the Wildcat helicopter. 
▪ They also use the Gazelle for observation and reconnaissance, and the Bell 212 which is used predominantly in jungle areas.

name: Army Apprentice National Memorial
description:
ARMY APPRENTICE NATIONAL MEMORIAL
This memorial is dedicated to all the young soldiers who undertook technical apprenticeship training, usually lasting 3 years, at one of the four main schools named (Chepstow, Arborfield, Harrogate and Carlisle), and in memory of those who gave their lives for it. 
More than 70,000 apprentices (aged 14-17) were trained between 1923 and 2004, before passing out to serve in the Regular Army as soldier/tradesmen. 
The memorial consists of an engraved and polished granite monolith, carrying the Army Apprentices School badge, set on a circular granite base. The granite paviours were sponsored by former apprentices and/or their families and give the dates of their apprenticeships.

name: Army Benevolent Fund - The Soldiers' Charity ; ABF
description: No information available

name: Army Commandos Memorial
description:
Army Commandos Map Index
The British Commandos were first formed by the Army in June 1940, during the Second World War, as a well-armed but non-regimental raider force, employing unconventional and irregular tactics to assault, disrupt and reconnoitre the enemy in mainland Europe, Scandinavia, North Africa, The Levant (Eastern Mediterranean) and the Far East.Initially raids were made by comparatively small numbers, were of short duration and at night but later growing in complexity and size. The Commandos were formed and operated in secrecy and produced a demoralising effect on German coastal forces while achieving celebrity status among the British public, comparable with that attached to fighter pilots, and shrouded in myth. This memorial consists of a reproduction of part of the Association badge – the wreath in copper and the Fairbairn-Sykes fighting knife in stainless steel. The impressive piece was created at Anwick Forge in Lincolnshire and dedicated in the presence of HRH Prince Philip, The Duke of Edinburgh, in July 2007. At the centre of the memorial is a stone with the names of eight commandos awarded the Victoria Cross. Behind the memorial is a roll of honour listing all 1,205 commandos who died in training or on operations during the Second World War. On examination of the Roll of Honour you will note that many were executed: this is because on capture they were executed under the terms of the infamous Hitler “Kommandobefehl” Commando Order.

name: Army Dog Unit (Northern Ireland) Association Red Paw Memorial
description:
Army Dog Unit (Northern Ireland) Association Red Paw Memorial 
This memorial was dedicated on 1 August 2009 to the memory of those, both humans and animals, who lost their lives whilst serving in the Army Dog Unit, Northern Ireland.
The memorial comprises a natural boulder with an inscribed polished, black granite plaque displaying the Association’s red dog paw badge and motto “Search and Secure”.

name: Army Parade
description: no information available

name: Army Wood
description:
Army Wood 
This wood is divided into Army Wood -Central, Army Wood -East and Army Wood – West 
The Army Wood comprises mixed native trees individually sponsored and dedicated to those who have served in the British Armed Forces. Within the wood are the Irish, Tank, Logistics, Army Air Corps and Fusilier memorials.

name: Association of Jewish Ex-Servicemen and Women (AJEX) Memorial
description:
ASSOCIATION OF JEWISH EX-SERVICEMEN (AJEX) 
Made from Chinese granite, The Star of David is designed to give you a different perspective when viewed from different angles. 
The small stones on the memorial are there as it is traditional for a Jewish person who visits any memorial to place a stone onto it to mark their visit. 
The Hebrew characters at the top right say ‘Remember’. 
The bench in the left corner has been dedicated by family members to a Polish couple who were killed in the Warsaw uprising against German occupation towards the end of World War 2.

name: Association of WRENS Centenary Stone
description:
Association of WRENS Centenary Stone. The installation of the AOW Centenary Stone took place on Wednesday 23rd September 2020 in the WRNS Garden.The memorial represents one hundred years since the Association was formed and it is very fitting that installation was able to go ahead in what should have been a year of celebration when so many planned events had to be cancelled.
The stone was constructed by Robyn Golden-Hann. It represents not only former wrens but also the Women of the Royal Naval Services as they are today. The WRNS were founded in l9l7 to support the men of the Royal Navy, but were disbanded in 1919. In 1939, at the outbreak of WW2, they were re-established and remained in service until 1993 when they were fully integrated into the Royal Navy. Women now carry out exactly the same duties as their male counterparts, both at sea and ashore. The garden is dedicated to all who served in the service and is designed to encourage birds, insects and butterflies. The pathways form the shape of an anchor. The wren, which was carved by the Essex Woodcarvers, forms part of a memorial for the 21 WRNS and a Naval Nursing Sister who lost their lives when their ship, SS Aguila, was torpedoed inl94l. One of the first WRNS to see active service was Wendy Clayin, who in 1990, served on board HMS Brilliant. The Women’s Royal Naval Service (WRNS), known as the Wrens, was formed in 1917 to release Royal Navy men for sea service during the First World War. It was disbanded after the war. On 11th April 1939 Vera Laughton Matthews was appointed Director of the newly reformed Women’s Royal Naval Service WRNS: she had previously been a member during World War 1. It was originally envisaged that there would be about 3000 women in the WRNS, however at its peak the number was more than 65,000. Around 75,000 Wrens carried out highly confidential and responsible roles in Britain and overseas. The WRNS was fully integrated into the Royal Navy in 1993.
This charming garden at the far end of the Royal Naval Review is dedicated to the WRNS and has been designed to encourage birds, insects and butterflies. The paths are in the shape of an anchor. Buddleia shrubs provide a haven for butterflies in summer. The two rose beds are planted with “Wren” roses to celebrate the 90th anniversary of the Association of Wrens 1917 – 2007. Notcutts Nurseries developed this rose for the 2007 Chelsea Flower Show and donated plants to the Wrens Garden at the NMA. In the rose beds and against the trees may be found dedications to individual Wrens. Located in the garden is the Aguila Memorial, a beautifully carved wren which commemorates the 21 WRNS and one Naval Nursing Sister who were lost when SS Aguila was torpedoed in 1941 (see M-152 Aguilla Memorial).

name: Athel Shipping Line Memorial
description:
Athel Shipping Line Memorial 
The memorial to the Athel Line – The United Molasses Company is placed in the Athel Line Grove of six English Oaks dedicated in gratitude to those who served in the Athel Line of Liverpool at Home and Overseas, Ashore and Afloat. Of the 32 ships owned by Athel Line Ltd and Tankers Ltd, 22 ships were lost. 
This memorial honours the 205 souls who perished as a result of enemy action.

name: Auxiliary Territorial Service / Ack Ack Memorial
description:
Auxiliary Territorial Service / ACK ACK (ATS / ACK ACK) 
A memorial rock remembering the women who staffed the anti-aircraft guns in the Second World War, the Auxiliary Territorial Service / ACK ACK (ATS / ACK ACK), who were attached to the Royal Artillery.

name: Auxiliary Territorial Service Statue
description: No information available

name: Baluch Regiment Memorial
description: Baluch Regiment Memorial. Raised in 1820 as a Regiment of Indian Native Infantry, they served in both the First and Second World Wars. Planted in 2002, the grove commemorates all those who served the Crown with the Baluch Regiment.

name: Basra Memorial Wall
description:
Basra Memorial Wall
The Basra Memorial Wall is a truly poignant monument to the 178 United Kingdom Armed Forces Service personnel and one Ministry of Defence (MOD) civilian who lost their lives on combat operations in Iraq. It also lists members of Coalition Forces who were killed whilst under United Kingdom command during the six years of conflict. The original memorial was built in Basra in 2006 and stood outside the front of the Headquarters of the Multi-National Division (South East). It was originally built by members of the Royal Engineers on their own initiative and in their own time, often in darkness and after a hard day’s work. The Wall was dismantled, and reconstructed at the Arboretum by British soldiers from 37th Armoured Engineer Squadron in a personal gesture to commemorate their fallen comrades. The original bricks would not have survived our climate, so have been incorporated into the foundations and replaced by red granite. The brass plaques on this memorial are the originals placed on the wall when it was in situ in Basra, Iraq. The plaques are cleaned twice a year; before the anniversary of the end of combat operations in Iraq and before Armistice, but in between they are allowed to weather naturally. This will allow the detail on these original plaques to last for as long as possible for the benefit of future generations. 
On the back of the memorial is a representation of the Iraq Medal; the campaign medal issued to O›cers and Other Ranks of the British Armed Forces as well as others, who served on, or in support of, Operation TELIC. It depicts an Assyrian protective deity, known as a Lamassu and often shown with a bull or lion’s body, eagle’s wings, and human head. The bull demonstrates strength. The eagle, being the most powerful bird in the sky, symbolises the king’s power as he looks over those he rules. The crowned human head represents intelligence. On top of the head is a crown, which features horns as a sign of divinity. It is symbolic of the region in which British service personnel fought.

name: Bastion Memorial
description:
CAMP BASTION MEMORIAL Map
• We start at the Camp Bastion Memorial, in remembrance of the 456 service men and women who lost their lives in Afghanistan. It is based on the same design as the former Camp Bastion Memorial Wall in Helmand Province, Afghanistan, which was dismantled in late 2014 following the end of combat operations
• It contains elements of the original wall, such as the cross made of shell cases placed on top of the cairn, material from the original wall in the foundations and the original memorial plaques engraved with names of the fallen, which have been placed inside the structure to preserve them for all time.
• On the reverse side is an engraved map of Afghanistan marking the locations where UK forces served during the 13-year campaign (with a stone from each actual location).
• The rededication service in June 2015 was attended by Prince Harry and the then Prime Minister, David Cameron.

name: Battle of Mirbat Memorial
description:
M-214 The Battle of Mirbat Memorial 
The Battle of Mirbat memorial commemorates a conflict, codenamed 'Operation STORM', which 
took place between 1970-1975 in the Dhofar Province of Southern Oman. 
Soldiers from 22 Special Air Service (SAS) Regiment were deployed under the guise of a British Army 
Training Team (commonly known as BATT Men). The SAS objective was to help the armed forces of 
Oman win the battle on the Jebel of Dhofar and so deliver the Province from armed communists 
working from bases in South Yemen. 
At dawn on the 19th July 1972 a nine man BATT team under the command of Mike Kealy were 
"stood to" in their gun positions at the ancient capital port of Dhofar called Mirbat. 
They came under attack by over 250 communist fighters. As the battle intensified Talaiasi Lablaba, a 
Fijian was firing the 25-pounder field gun directly at the enemy forces who were only yards away 
from the gun pit. Walid Khamis of the Omani gun team and Sekonaia Takevesi another Fijian had 
been seriously wounded. 
Tommy Tobin the medic was tending to them when he was shot in the jaw, a wound that was to 
later to prove fatal. Labalaba was shot in the neck whilst trying to retrieve a mortar nearby.

name: Battle of the River Plate Memorial
description:
BATTLE OF THE RIVER PLATE (The first sea battle of WW2)
The Battle of the River Plate, which took place on the 13 December 1939, was the first major naval battle of the Second World War and the only episode of the War to take place in South America. The German pocket battleship Admiral Graf Spee, commanded by Kapitän sur See Hans Langsdorff, had been terrorising Allied shipping in the South Atlantic. It was eventually tracked down and engaged by three ships from the Royal Navy’s South American division (the cruisers HMS Ajax, HMS Exeter, and HMS Achilles) commanded by Commodore Henry Harwood Harwood. All four ships sustained considerable damage and Graf Spee limped into an estuary in neutral Uruguay to undertake necessary repairs. Given just 72 hours to repair, the Germans knew escape was impossible and scuttled (sank) the ship in the River Plate. Two days later, in Buenos Aires where the crew were taken, Kapitän Langsdorff committed suicide. He was buried there with full military honours and the service was attended by British officers who were present in the city. This impressive black granite memorial was unveiled in the presence of the few remaining River Plate veterans on 12 April 2014 to mark the 75th anniversary of the Battle of the River Plate. Significantly, it was the 300th memorial to be dedicated at the Arboretum. 
The Graf Spee was a German battleship; her mission, to destroy allied merchant ships in the Atlantic. 
In December 1940 she was engaged by HM Ships Exeter, Ajax and Achilles 
Exeter was badly damaged and withdrew; the other two ships, although damaged, remained on station. 
The Graf Spee put into Montevideo, Uruguay, which was a neutral country, so she could only stay for 24 hours for humanitarian reasons; however, she managed to stay for 72 hours. 
The Admiralty sent a signal to Ajax and Achilles informing them that a carrier and a battlecruiser were on their way as support; this was in fact one of the greatest deceptions of the war, they were not. 
Graf Spee's captain, convinced that stronger forces were waiting, left the majority of his crew behind and sailed out of the port where he scuttled his ship; he committed suicide two days later. 
Most of his crew stayed in Montevideo, others went to Buenos Aires, many of them married and raised families; the last surviving crew member, died in Buenos Aires June 2007 aged 89. 
The apron approaching the memorial shows the exact size of the shells that were exchanged. 
The front of the memorial shows the crests and silhouettes of the 3 RN ships, the reverse side is the ship's crest and silhouette of the Graf Spee. 
There are two quotes from Winston Churchill; "This brilliant sea fight takes its place in our naval annals and in long cold dark winter it warms the cockles of the British hearts"; and other one says, "This great battle will long be told in song and story" 
Behind the memorial is a small pavier with the inscription, "sealed herein are the names of those who served on HMS Ajax, HMS Achilles, HMS Exeter and Admiral Graf Spee who gave their lives whilst serving their country. Also, those who 75 years later supported the commissioning and dedication of this memorial on 12 April 2014.

name: Bevin Boys Memorial
description:
Bevin Boys
Nearly 48,000 young men, all of them conscripts, joined regular miners in their work from 1943 - 1948. They were pressed into action because many miners had gone to war and at one stage coal reserves fell to less than three weeks' supply.  Ernest Bevin was the Minister of Labour at that time and decreed that every 10th man called up for war service would instead be sent down the coal mines.  The Bevin Boys were chosen out of a hat. Every month, for 20 months, Bevin's secretary drew numbers from his distinctive Homburg hat. If the number drawn matched the last digit of a man's National Service number, he was sent to the mines 
Comedian Eric Morecambe was a Bevin Boy (as was Brian Rix and Nat Lofthouse). 
The work was unfamiliar and dangerous; resulting in many injuries and lives lost. They were also often unfairly accused of being ‘Conscientious Objectors’, which they most certainly were not, although some Conscientious Objectors HAD been sent to work in the mines as an alternative to imprisonment. 
The plinths are made of Kilkenny limestone which will eventually turn black, like coal. 
During the Second World War 48,000 men were conscripted, via a lottery, to work in coal mines 
They were called “Bevin Boys” after Ernest Bevin, the Minister of Labour and National Service in the wartime coalition government 
The Bevin Boys joined regular miners in their dirty, dangerous but essential work to keep the coal supplies of Britain flowing 
The badge awarded to Bevin Boys can be seen on the face of the main memorial 
The smaller of the two blocks is carved with the tools and equipment used by the Bevin Boys 
There are also two mice carved on the memorial as Bevin Boys said that there were always mice in the mines. Can you spot them?

name: Bidadari Cemetery Memorial
description:
Bidadari Cemetery 
The four cherry trees commemorate the Bidadari Christian Cemetery, which contains the graves of people who died in Singapore from 1908 to 1972. Today, Bidadari Cemetery is no longer in use, and most of the graves have been exhumed to allow land redevelopment.

name: Birmingham Children's Hospital
description:
Birmingham Children’s Hospital Memorial 
There are five sculptures along this Riverside Walk, as well as further pieces within Birmingham Children’s Hospital. The organic or ‘seed-like’ sculptures represent the key sentiments of love, loss, endings and new beginnings. There is a bench at the beginning of the walk.

name: BLESMA -  The Limbless Veteran's Orchard.
description:
British Limbless Ex-Service Men’s Association (BLESMA)
BLESMA - The Limbless Veteran’s Orchard. The 70 fruit trees here, including varieties of bramley seedling ‘Malus domestica’, Fiesta, James Grieve, Golden Delicious, Cox’s Orange Pippin, Katie and Egremont Russet, are dedicated to those serving and ex-service personnel who are assisted by Blesma, The Limbless Veteran’s charity.

name: Blind Veterans UK (St Dunstan's) Pathway
description:
Blind Veterans UK (St Dunstan's) Pathway Map
Blind Veterans UK supports anyone who has served in the Armed Forces, or who has done National Service, and who is now living with significant sight loss. The scented pathway is lined with all-year round fragrant shrubs.

name: Blown Away
description:
Blown Away
This sculpture which is on permanent loan to the Arboretum from Peter and Carole Wilcock. ‘A study of a moment in time. The young man, his life fleeting as a gust, sees the whole world in a glance.’ The artist’s inspiration for the piece was the Four Quartets, a work by the writer and poet T.S.Eliot: “Time present and time past Are both perhaps present in time future” The sculpture is made from bronze laurel leaves and sits on a plinth fabricated in mild steel. The plinth’s shape suggests hastily despatched munitions or a ship’s funnel. It has intentionally been left to rust, with stripes of bronze reflecting its adopted strength.

name: Blues and Royals
description:
Life Guards Memorial 
The Life Guards the memorial, together with the Blues and Royals Memorial, is part of the memorial to the Household Cavalry Regiments. It was placed on site in 2016 and is dedicated to The Life Guards Regiment which was founded in 1660. 
The memorial was officially dedicated on 28 September 2017 by Field Marshal The Lord Guthrie of Craigiebank GCB LVO OBE DL Colonel of the Life Guards. 
Two black polished granite stones slabs, each bearing the badge of The Life Guards and The Blues and Royals respectively mark the entrance to the memorial garden.

name: Bomb Disposal Memorial ; Explosive Ordnance Disposal
description:
BOMB DISPOSAL
▪ One can only describe these people as ‘The bravest of the brave’ for what they do. 
▪ This memorial shows a soldier on what they call ‘The Long Walk’ towards an IED – an improvised explosive device, which he must make safe. 
▪ He is wearing a suit which gives some protection from blast and fragmentation and is carrying what they call a ‘disruptor’. Beside him is a piece of electronic counter measure equipment. 
▪ The cartoon cat on the base relates to ‘Felix’, the unofficial mascot of the British Army counter-terrorism bomb disposal units, probably because cats have always been associated with luck and their ability to land on their feet. 
▪ The Bomb Disposal Charity, which provides assistance to personnel and their families, is also known as ‘The Felix Fund’. 
Lisa Head was was the first female bomb disposal officer to be killed on operations.[2] She died on 19 April 2011 at the age of 29, having sustained serious injuries on active service in Afghanistan,

name: Boyes Garden
description:
Boyes Garden Map 
This attractive garden with its winding path, its arches of Carpinus Betulus and water feature was funded by the G & K Charitable Trust when the new Visitor Centre was built in 2016. Trees, shrubs and plants found in the garden include Betula Utilis ’Jacqmontii’, Amelanchier Lamarckii, Cornus Sanguinea ‘Midwinter Fire’, Echinacea Purpurea ‘Magnus’, Echinops Rito ‘Vetch’s Blue’, Leucanthemum Vulgare ‘Snow Lady’. The path through the garden is the principle route from Heroes Square out on to our site. 
The purpose of the G & K Boyes Trust is to promote, advance and support by way of grants to charities, charitable organisations, charitable purposes and charitable causes with a focus on (but not limited to) education, training, advancement of health or saving lives, arts, culture, heritage, science, environment and conservation.

name: Boys' Brigade
description:
Boys Brigade Map
This garden, a grass rectangle with one corner curved, is bounded by a low hedge of field maple and box.
At the entrance, two pieces of 5,000 year old ‘bog oak’, donated by the Republic of Ireland and the Northern Ireland Districts, depict the twin pillars of Religion and Discipline. A path winds down to a small patio area where visitors can sit on a bench, set on a bed of Portland stone.
A large granite rock from Scotland, to which a real metal anchor is attached and inscribed with the chorus of The Boys’ Brigade Hymn “Will your anchor hold?”, occupies a prominent position, as does a solid slate plinth from Wales in the centre of the patio.
Five Hundred bulbs were planted in 2009 – 125 bulbs each of standard daffodils, pheasant-eye narcissi, Tête-à-tête daffodils and blue grape hyacinths. The bulbs represent the 125 years of existence of The Boys’ Brigade.
Along one side of the Garden are 17 stones, each bearing the name of a Boys Brigade member who has been awarded the Victoria Cross.
A time capsule was buried in the garden containing items from Boys’ Brigade young people in 2009.

name: Brigade of Gurkhas Memorial
description:
Brigade of Gurkhas Memorial. Gurkhas have served the British Crown for over 200 years. It is a rich heritage marked by excellence and sacrifice. The names of over 400 Gurkhas appear on the Armed Forces Memorial. The history of the Brigade from its inception in 1815 during the early wars between the Honourable East India Company and city-state of Gorkha, through the early Afghan wars, the two World Wars, the almost continuous post-war conflicts to modern day Afghanistan, is forged from the deep feeling of mutual respect and admiration developed between the British and their Gurkha adversaries. Following the Nepal Wars, and under the terms of the Sugauli Peace Treaty in 1816, Gurkhas were permitted to volunteer for service in the East India Company’s Army. From these volunteers were formed the first regiments of the Gurkha Brigade,and from this time stems Britain’s friendship with Nepal, a country which has proved a staunch ally ever since and has become our ‘oldest ally’ in Asia. Since 1997, the Brigade of Gurkhas has been operationally and battle proven in Bosnia, Kosovo, East Timor, Sierra Leone, Macedonia and Iraq. With 11 years of continuous Gurkha deployments in Afghanistan, the human cost and sacrifice in Afghanistan has been high. Fifty four officers and soldiers of the Brigade have been wounded in action and 15 have died.
The memorial takes the form of a traditional chautara, a traditional resting place for travellers on hillside trails in Nepal. The plaque incorporates the badges of the units of the Brigade, past and present.

name: British Berlin Airlift Memorial
description:
BERLIN AIRLIFT MEMORIAL 
▪ The Berlin blockade was one of the first major international crises of the Cold War; the Soviet Union blocked access to West Berlin and the Soviets had control of East Berlin. 
▪ The Soviet action was in response to the American and British officials not allowing Russia more say in the economic future of Germany. 
▪ The two million people of West Berlin could not get any food or other essential supplies when the blockade started on 24 June 1948 and it eventually finished on 12 May 1949. 
▪ So on 24 June 1948, Operation Vittles was launched; around 8,000 tons of supplies were airlifted and delivered. Every day for the next 323 days, around 2.3 million tons of cargo were flown in by the American and British and Commonwealth Air Forces, together with allied Air Forces. 
▪ Around 300 aircraft took part in the airlift, around 300,000 flights in all. 
▪ Eventually the Russians conceded the blockade was a failure and withdrew the blockade. 
▪ The theme of the memorial is three air corridors which created what was known as the "Air Bridge". It is symbolised by the three elements standing proud of the main structure, and by the Berlin Airlift motif depicted on the terrace in front of the memorial incorporating Paviours representing the 39 British and Commonwealth who died in air accidents during the operation.

name: British Korean Veterans Association (BKVA)
description:
British Korean Veterans Association (BKVA). There is still great interest in this site as many of those who took part are still alive. The conflict between North and South Korea is of course still ongoing and newsworthy. In 1950, 22 member nations of the United Nations (UN) joined South Korean forces to repel the North Korean and communist Chinese aggression. During the three years of the conflict, some four million people died. Over 100,000 British Service personnel served during the war, of whom over 2,000 were killed or taken prisoner. Among the many decorations awarded were four Victoria Crosses and two George Crosses. In 1952, the Commonwealth units from Australia, Canada, India, New Zealand and South Africa combined to form the 1st Commonwealth Division. The memorial garden, originally laid out and maintained by members of the British Korean Veterans Association (BKVA), is designed to create a living memorial to all British Service Personnel who served and gave their lives. It is an arboretum within an arboretum, planted with more than 100 trees of some 27 different species, mostly of Korean or Asian origin. The bronze plaques on the large boulders give a brief history of the Service Units involved together with the dates and locations of the various battles and actions. An arboretum within an arboretum to form a living memorial to all British servicemen and women who served in the Korean War. It represents the continuing friendship between ourselves and South Korea, but also reminds us that this conflict was
fought under the flag of the United Nations. Originally planted with over 150 trees of 27 different varieties, mostly of Korean or Asian origin. Five boulders of rock in a semi-circle have brass plaques attached giving a time-line of events during this
conflict and the armed forces involved. There are 3. flagpoles, which normally fly the standards of the UK, South Korea

name: British Limbless Ex-Service Men's Association  (BLESMA). The Limbless Veteran's Garden.
description:
BLESMA 
BLESMA stands for British Limbless Ex-Service Men’s Association 
BLESMA was formed in 1932 
BELSMA works to assist those who have lost limbs as a result of service in any branch of Her Majesty's Armed Forces. 
The garden is planted mostly with fruit trees which are kept purposely at a low height to allow easy access for those in wheelchairs both to smell the blossom in spring and harvest the fruit in autumn. 
An apple or pear, of course, does not need to be peeled for eating (requiring two hands) 
The circular benches do not have any arm rests. A service person may have lost their arms.

name: British Nuclear Test Veterans Memorial (BNTV)
description:
British Nuclear Veterans Memorial
The BNTVA Formed in 1983, the British Nuclear Test Veterans Association (BNTVA) is a focus for all those who served at the test sites and combines comradeship with the objective of recognition of the ill effects suffered by some veterans, their families and children born with lung problems. The BNTVA believe that over 22,000 British servicemen from the Army, Royal Air Force, Royal Navy, Merchant Navy, and Royal Fleet Auxiliary participated in the British and American nuclear tests and clean-ups between 1952-1966, along with scientists from the Atomic Weapons Research Establishment and civilians. The BNTVA promote research into the effects of clastogenic radiation on the nuclear community, and educate the general public about the nuclear tests in creative ways.
The BNTVA has about 1,400 members of which one third are widows. Membership is limited to men who served in the nuclear test areas, their widows and their descendants.
The Nuclear Test Program
Between 1952 and 1958 21 atmospheric tests took place at the locations listed on the memorial. The yield from these tests varied between 1 and 150 kilotons.
3rd October 1952: the Hurricane Test at Monte Bello
15th & 23rd October 1953: 2 Totem Tests at Emu Field
16 May & 19th June 1956: 2 Mozaic Tests at Monte Bello
September-October 1956: 4 tests in the Buffalo series at Maralinga
May – June 1957: 3 tests in the Grapple series at Malden Island
September –October 1957: 3 tests in the Antler series at Maralinga.
November 1957 – September 1958: 6 tests in the Grapple Series at Christmas Island.
From the 1960s further tests were undertaken at underground facilities in Nevada in cooperation with the USA.
The Medal for British Nuclear Test Veterans
The BNTVA campaigned for many years for a medal to be awarded to recognise the service and sacrifice of the service personnel who had taken part in the tests.
At a ceremony at the BNTVA Memorial on 21st November 2022 the Prime Minister Rishi Sunak announced that the British Nuclear Veterans would now be entitled to a medal to mark their service and said: “I am incredibly proud that we are able to mark the service and dedication of our nuclear test veterans with this new medal. Their commitment and service has preserved peace for the past 70 years, and it is only right their contribution to our safety, freedom and way of life is appropriately recognised with this honour.
This medal is an enduring symbol of our country’s gratitude to each and every person who played a part in this effort and their loved ones who supported them.”
HM Government website states that:
The Nuclear Test Medal will be a commemorative medal that can be worn by recipients.
The medal also recognises the contribution made by veterans and civilians from across Australia, New Zealand, Fiji and Kiribati. All service personnel and civilians under UK command, including close partners from the Commonwealth and Pacific region, who participated in, or were present at, the British or American nuclear tests at the Montebello Islands, Christmas Island, Malden Island and Maralinga & Emu Field, South Australia between 1952 and 1967 will be eligible for the medal. This also includes scientists and local employees.
It is estimated that around 22,000 veterans will be eligible for the medal.

name: British South Africa Police Memorial
description:
British South Africa Police
This memorial was dedicated on 25 July 2010 and replicates the memorial erected in 1921 in the Morris Depot (the training depot for new recruits) in Salisbury, Rhodesia (now Harare, Zimbabwe).

name: BRIXMIS Memorial
description:
Brixmis Memorial 
BRIXMIS (the British Commanders’- in-Chief Mission to the Soviet Forces in Germany) along with its American and French counterpart military liaison missions, worked throughout the Cold War from 1946-1990 in East Germany. 
As well as keeping open high-level communication channels between the Soviet and British military commands in Germany, these missions evolved into highly professional and successful intelligence gathering units. Their patrolling operations, both on the ground and in the air, were conducted under conditions of strict secrecy. 
The dedication of the BRIXMIS Association Memorial at the Arboretum on 17 September 2016 marked the 70th anniversary of the Anglo-Soviet agreement to set up reciprocal military liaison missions.

name: Brotherhood of Greek Veterans Chapel
description:
Brotherhood of Greek Veterans Chapel 
The Brotherhood exists to ensure that the Greek Campaign of the Second World War and the men who were left behind are not forgotten. 
The impressive Greek stone and marble altar in this outdoor chapel symbolises the strength of this Brotherhood that was established in April 1991 commemorating the 50th Anniversary of the surrender of The Allied Forces at Kalamata, the Peloponnese in Southern Greece. 
Ten thousand men were captured and became Prisoners of War (POWs), enduring massive hardship and terrifying trials until Liberation. The horrors of war and incarceration created a band of spirited and brave young men whose camaraderie and resilience survives even to this day. 
A plaque located beneath the altar states “In memory of all those who took part in the Greek campaigns 1940-1945. They will be remembered”. 
Within the memorial area there is a small memorial to three ships sunk with heavy casualties while evacuating British troops from Greece - SS Slamat, HMS Diamond & HMS Wryneck.

name: Burma Railway Memorial
description: Burma Railway Memorial. This 30-metre stretch of track was bought back from Burma to form the memorial here at the National Memorial Arboretum. Construction started in June 1942 and after 18 months the 415km (257 miles) of railway was finished. The POW’s and Asian labourers, many of whom were Indians who had gone to Burma to work for the British, had to work long hours in extreme conditions and with little food. Over 330,000 men worked on the railway. Around 16,000 POW’s and 100,000 labourers lost their lives. It has been said that one person died for each sleeper that was laid. Burma railway actually took 16 months to build, 2 months faster than engineers estimated. This was because the Japanese pushed the workers to the absolute limit. The railway ran between Bangkok in Thailand to Rangoon in Burma, 600 bridges had to be constructed and bridge number 277 was the infamous bridge over the River Kwai. When this piece of track arrived here one of our Volunteers traced its origins only to find that it was actually manufactured in Middlesbrough! (There are embossed markings on the inside of the left-hand rail, just past the 9th sleeper).

name: Burma Star Memorial
description:
The 15ft tall monolith is a copy of the one that stands at the Commonwealth War Grave Cemetery in Kohima, on the border of India with Burma, which saw some of the fiercest fighting of the Burma campaign, but is where the Japanese advance was finally halted.
It is intended to pay tribute to ALL organisations, armed forces and individuals who hold either the Burma Campaign Star or the Pacific Star with Burma Clasp. On the memorial is the famous Kohima Epitaph that has been used around the world on memorials and at remembrance services:
‘WHEN YOU GO HOME
TELL THEM OF US AND SAY
FOR YOUR TOMORROW
WE GAVE OUR TODAY’
The words are attributed to John Maxwell Edmonds (1875 -1958), an English Classicist, who had put them together among a collection of 12 epitaphs for World War One, in 1916. According to the Burma Star Association the words were used for the Kohima Memorial as a suggestion by Major John Etty-Leal, the GSO II of the 2nd Division, another classical scholar. The verse is thought to have been inspired by the Greek lyric poet Simonides of Ceos (556-468 BC) who wrote after the Battle of Thermopylae in 480 BC:
"Go tell the Spartans, thou that passesth by, That faithful to their precepts here we lie."

name: Cadet Forces' Memorial
description:
Cadet Forces’ Memorial 
The circular seat, sponsored by the Army Cadet Force, a national voluntary youth organisation for young people aged 12–18, honours former members of the Cadet Forces who went on to join the Armed Forces and subsequently lost their lives.

name: Captain Class Frigates Memorial
description:
Captain Class Frigates
The 78 Captain Class Frigates were all built in the USA and supplied to the United Kingdom as part of the lend-lease programme. They were all named after Royal Navy Captains who had served with distinction. 
They served as Convoy escorts and anti-submarine vessels, contributing to the sinking of over 30 U-boats. However 7 were sunk and a further 8 so severely damaged they were considered a constructive total loss. 
At the end of the war they were rapidly returned to the USA in order to avoid further costs. 
They can be divided into two groups: 
Evarts Type – displacement of 1140 long tons, 290 feet long, diesel-electric propulsion and a complement of 156 
Buckley Type– displacement of 1400 long tons, 306 feet long, tubo-electric propulsion and a complement of 156

name: Captain Sir Tom Moore Way
description: Captain Sir Tom Moore Way

name: Cardiac Risk in the Young, Dawn, Dusk
description: Cardiac Risk in the Young, Dawn, Dusk. The owl and cockerel features relate to raising awareness of cardiac risk to young people and the need for families/carers to bear in mind that problems of heart disease are not confined to older people and can occur at any time of day or night.

name: Care of Police Survivors (also known as COPS)
description: No information available

name: Castle Class Corvettes Memorial
description:
CASTLE CLASS CORVETTES
To the left is a plaque to the Flower Class Corvettes (all named after flowers) - they were the predecessor of the Castles 
The ships of this class were named after castles. 
The stones laid across the top are taken from various castles and are placed to resemble the battlements on top of a castle wall.

name: Cavalry Grove (Crescent)
description:
Cavalry Crescent
The Cavalry Grove (Crescent) grove consists of a colourful mix of ornamental trees and memorials dedicated to the Cavalry Regiments of the British Army. These include 9/12 Lancers, The Queen’s Royal Hussars, The Royal Dragoon Guards, The Queen’s Royal Lancers, The King’s Royal Hussars and The Light Dragoons.

name: Celebration of Life Grove (Co-op)
description:
Co-op Celebration of Life Grove 
Supported by the Midlands Co-operative Society, the grove is a large semi-circular planting of mixed spring-flowering blossom trees individually dedicated as a celebration of the life of family members and friends who have passed away.

name: Changi Lych Gate
description:
Changi Lych Gate. This is the original Lych Gate from Changi Jail, Singapore, designed by Captain C.D. Pickersgill and built in 1942 by Royal Engineers from the 18th Division who were prisoners of war. The gate was first erected at the entrance to the camp cemetery to mark the graves of those who had died and to give their funerals some dignity. In 1952, the graves were moved to Kranji War Memorial Cemetery and the Lych Gate to the British Garrison Church, St George’s, in Singapore. When British troops withdrew completely from Singapore in 1971, the Lych Gate was dismantled and brought back to England where it was erected at the Queen’s Division Depot, Bassingbourn Barracks in Royston, Hertfordshire. In 2003, the refurbished Lych Gate was reconstructed at the Arboretum by the 39th Engineering Regiment and the re-dedication took place on 8 February 2004. In the structure of the Lych Gate was carved the national emblems of the British Isles. Inside the eaves, in Gothic lettering, is an inscription:
‘To the Glory of God
And in memory of those
Who laid down their lives
For their King and Country’.
The idea of a Lych Gate, familiar to prisoners from churchyards back in England, gave some feeling of dignity and respect for those who had died in appalling conditions. The Lych Gate is set in an area heavy with symbolism. It is the entrance now to the Far East Prisoners of War Grove. Most of the trees here are dedicated to individual FEPOWs, with some mentioning groups, such as the civilian and military women and children who perished and all the FEPOWs lost at sea while being transported.

name: Changi Prison Map
description: Changi Prison Map

name: Cheltenham College Memorial
description:
CHELTENHAM COLLEGE
▪ The light-coloured pedestal to the left honours former students of Cheltenham College. Some 6,000 former students have served in the armed forces and over 1,500 lost their lives. 
14 Victoria Crosses have been awarded to former students, and it is one of only two non-military schools allowed to parade the Queens Colour, the other school is Eton.

name: Cheshire Regiment Association
description:
THE CHESHIRE REGIMENT EVER GLORIOUS’ Map Index
The Regiment was formed in 1689 by Henry Howard, 7th Duke of Norfolk as the ‘Duke of Norfolk's Regiment of Foot.’
During the intervening 300 years, it spent much time on garrison duty in the Empire (Europe and the Americas).. At Dettingen (1743) it won the distinction of wearing the oak leaf whilst parading for Royalty and also on certain Regimental days. The story is that the 22nd protected the king, who was commanding the field, from being taken prisoner by the French. The king picked a sprig of oak from a nearby tree and presented it to them.
In 1751 the Regimental was renamed, The 22nd Regiment of Foot. In 1782 all British Regiments without Royal titles were assigned a county title in order to aid recruitment, therefore the Regiment became the 22nd (Cheshire) Regiment of Foot and later in 1881 re – titled The Cheshire Regiment
During the course of the First World War, The Regiment was awarded 75 Battle Honours and 2 Victoria Crosses losing 8,413 men.
In WW2 the 1st the Battalion served in North Africa, Malta and North West Europe . The 2nd Battalion was evacuated from Dunkirk before fighting in North Africa, Sicily and Italy. It then landed on D-Day and fought in the North West Europe campaign.
Following WW2 the 1st Battalion has served in numerous operational areas: Malaya, Cyprus, Northern Ireland, Bosnia under the United Nations and Iraq.
In 2007 the Regiment was amalgamated in with the Staffordshire and Worcestershire & Sherwood Regiments to form the Mercian Regiment the 1st Battalion, The Mercian Regiment (Cheshire).
The memorial consists of a 2 foot plinth displaying the 138 battle honours and holds a large stone cut from a Sycamore quarry in Cheshire. The stone is flanked on both sides by steel cut-outs of soldiers representing the Regiments formation in1689 and amalgamation in 2007. It was dedicated in October 2022.

name: Cheshire Regiment Memorial Bench
description:
Cheshire Regiment Memorial Bench 
This polished grey granite bench from the people of Winsford is dedicated to the service men and women of The Cheshire Regiment who gave their lives in conflict. The badges of the Cheshire Regiment, comprising an acorn accompanied by crossed oak leaves, are displayed either side of the inscription.

name: Cheshire Yeomanry
description:
The Cheshire Yeomanry Memorial
'Moving Forward, Looking Back' 
This memorial was commissioned to coincide with the 225th anniversary of the raising of the Cheshire Yeomanry Regiment. With the constant uncertainties of future British Army structures and the unknown future threats of town planning, what better place to secure our memorial, for future generations of Cheshire Yeomen, than at the National Memorial Arboretum. We now have a permanent and fitting place to lay our wreaths and pay our respects to all our comrades. We have a focal point to be able to contemplate those that have gone before us. 
The Cheshire Yeomanry was raised as a light cavalry regiment in 1797 under the threat of a Napoleonic invasion. The regiment has built a proud history during that period. Our role remains today as Light Cavalry and throughout its early history up to and during World War 2 the regiment served with its constant companion, the horse. Since then, we have had another type of companion, who has been our protection, our weapon, our shelter and our means of transport, the mechanised vehicle. Our memorial represents the strength and power of a horse, but at the same time represents through its design, examples of many of those other vehicles. 
Designer and Sculptor - Joanne Risley (Sculptor) 
“I was very honoured to have been chosen to create the memorial sculpture for the Cheshire Yeomanry to celebrate 225 years since its inception. In response to the brief, I have designed a life-sized rearing war horse created using the mechanisms, structure and detail found on the Fox, Ferret and Jackal armoured vehicles. 
Objects of war mix with more familiar domestic objects such as a spade and the beloved ‘BV’ boiling vessel that provides the crew with hot water for tea and cooking. The plinth carries a turret wheel which frames the cast bronze regimental crest. I have tried to encapsulate the strength and dynamism of the animal with the armoured feel of the regiment’s vehicles. 
The arboretum already features a highly naturalistic life-size horse so I wanted to create a unique and modern monument that would strike a different note. The regiment kindly provided historic context, photographic material and access to Fox Barracks where I was able to study one of the Jackal vehicles up close. At the Cheshire Military Museum the Fox and Ferret armoured vehicles provided further inspiration. 
The body of the horse is tank-like and incorporates toeholds, wheel arches, rear lights and smoke canisters. The legs and thighs are formed from wheels and tyre treads with the helmet-like head supported by gun parts and a spine and ribs derived from the Jackal anti-roll system. 
The whole sculpture stands 3m tall. Created from weathering steel, which contains copper and smaller bronze elements, the overall appearance will take on a rusted and aged appearance whilst the material’s unique properties provide a protective surface that will endure indefinitely.
