As well as being of symbolic and emotional importance to the regiment, the horse embodies courage, freedom, power, endurance, personal drive, passion and heroism. The animal appears to be moving forward but looking back in order to represent soldiers of the regiment past and present. 
Joanne Risley studied Fine Art at Mid-Cheshire College, Duncan of Jordanstone College of Art and then at The University of Ulster. 
She was elected a member of Manchester Academy of Fine Art in 2017. www.joannerisley.co.uk 
Materials Used - Rusted Corten steel, copper, and smaller bronze elements. 
Age of Memorial - The build was completed during 2021 and installed at the NMA in June 2022 and a dedication ceremony was held 12th June 2022. 
Symbolism - The Memorial has been created to allow visitors to remember those lost and to contemplate, surrounded by the memorials of all Yeomanry Regiments and positioned so that there is a full view from all angles of Yeomanry Avenue.

name: Children's Woodland
description:
CHILDREN’S WOOD 
The owl and cockerel features relate to raising awareness of cardiac risk to young people and the need for families/carers to bear in mind that problems of heart diseaguarse are not confined to older people and can occur at any time of day or night. 
The sculpture of a post-box, with birds in flight above it, was made by children of British armed forces personnel at their school in Germany and represents the transient lifestyle of such families. 
With the reduction in numbers of our armed forces abroad, the school was closed and the sculpture brought here. 
The idea is that ‘the birds are dispersing and then finding someone they know in the next flock’, like so many children of Service personnel over previous years/decades/centuries.

name: Chindit Memorial
description: Chindits Memorial. An obelisk in memory of the multi-national force which became known as ‘The Chindits’. On top it has a bronze Chinthe, a mythical beast which guarded Burmese temples, from which derived the name Chindits. The Chindits were the largest of the allied Special Forces of WW2. They were formed and led by Major General Orde Wingate DSO. The Chindits operated deep behind enemy lines in North Burma in the War against Japan with the intention of preventing supplies being transported to the battlefront. For many months they lived in and fought the enemy in the jungles, totally relying on airdrops for their supplies. They had some successes but suffered greatly from the climate and constant shortage of supplies. Few of them were fit for further service after emerging from the jungle.▪ Listed on brass plaques affixed to the sides are those regiments and units from which the Chindits drew personnel.

name: Christmas Truce Memorial and Shelter ; Football Remembers
description:
The Christmas Truce Memorial
The Christmas Truce took place in December 1914 
This memorial was sponsored by the Football Association 
There was a national competition for schools to design a memorial that reflected the events of the Christmas Truce 
35 schools were shortlisted and those designs were displayed at the National Memorial Arboretum 
The winning design was created by a school boy from Newcastle upon Tyne 
The competition was judged by Theo Walcott and Price William 
must be stressed that it is highly unlikely that there was ever a formal game of football in No Man’s Land during the Christmas Truce. An informal kick-a-about is much more likely to have been the case 
No primary

name: Church Lads' and Church Girls' Brigade
description:
Church Girls Brigade/Church Lads Brigade 
Dedicated on 22 June 2002, the garden was one of the first memorials to be created after the Arboretum was opened to the general public. 
It is dedicated to members of The Church Lads’ and Church Girls’ Brigade who served their country in war and peace. Also dedicated during the ceremony was the Lectern Bible which was donated by the Brigade Association for use in the Millennium Chapel in Advent 2001. 
It is estimated that around 50,000 Brigade lads served in the First World War, during which many honours and distinctions were awarded, including 21 Victoria Crosses. It is not recorded how many Brigade personnel served in the Second World War, nor the honours awarded, but an additional Brigade lad received the Victoria Cross in 1945 posthumously. 
Younger Brigade lads and girls also served on the Home Front in both World Wars. The 22 Berberis shrubs were selected to represent the Brigade’s military past but, more specifically, to represent its 22 Victoria Cross recipients. 
The pathways form a Christian Cross to represent the Brigade’s present path. The two benches commemorate the 16th Battalion of the King’s Royal Rifle Corps which was comprised entirely of past and present members of the Brigade in the First World War. This was known as a “Pals'. 
The title plaque on the plinth has some of its information recorded in Braille, for the benefit of those with impaired sight.

name: Civil Defence
description:
CIVIL DEFENCE
This memorial remembers the efforts of those who served their country by looking after the people here at home during the Second World War. These men and women served in many roles such as wardens, rescuers, firewatchers, and welfare workers. Many lives were lost. 
ARP stands for Air Raid Precautions (Warden Hodges in Dad’s Army) 
1.9 million people served in the Civil Defence during the Second World War 
Nearly 7000 were killed carrying out their role with the Civil Defence in the Second World War 
The large stone is a memorial to the humans while the small stone represents the animals that helped in the rescues. If you look closely at the large stone, there are drill marks on its side to signify the importance of mechanical help during a rescue. 
The stone to the right remembers those who were awarded the George Cross for Civil Defence duties 
The large memorial at the back of the garden honours members of Civil Defence during the ‘Cold War’ period 1949 - 1968

name: Civil Defence George Cross Awards
description:
Civil Defence George Cross Awards
This memorial commemorates the 12 men awarded the George Cross for outstanding bravery while engaged in Civil Defence work. Ten recipients, who were Civil Defenders during WWII, are also commemorated by a blue plaque, erected on 30th June 2007, by an oak tree behind this memorial. 
Nine men were awarded the George Cross for Fire and Rescue duties that frequently involved burrowing through burning buildings in danger of further collapse; in fact the first individual to be awarded the George Cross was Thomas Hopper Alderson who was part of this group. 
Three men were awarded the George Cross for bomb disposal work, one of whom, Charles Howard was killed when the bomb on which he was working blew up. For security reasons the citation for these three men sometimes read “For conspicuous bravery in carrying out dangerous duties”. 
Two men, Frederick Davies and George Henderson, were Civil Defenders who have been awarded the George Cross for gallantry since World War II. George Henderson was a Gibraltar fireman who received a posthumous award for his gallantry: for this reason a piece of stone from the Rock of Gibraltar has been placed in the memorial. 
The memorial was unveiled on 18th June 2011 by Jim Beaton GC, Chairman of the VC and GC Association. Jim Beaton’s own award was for the defence of Princess Anne when she was attacked in the Mall in 1974.

name: Clan, Houston, Scottish Shire, Bullard and King Line Steamers Memorial
description:
Clan Line Steamers, Houston Line, Scottish Shire Line, Bullard, King and Co. and King Line
This memorial is dedicated to all who served with Clan Line Steamers, Houston Line, Scottish Shire Line, Bullard, King and Co. and King Line Steamers and to those serving on the vessels lost or destroyed by enemy action. Cyprus Emergency (1955-1959) Map 
The memorial, located within the Mediterranean Campaigns of World War II Garden, is dedicated to all those who served during the ‘Cyprus Emergency’ 1955 – 1959 and in memory of the 371 who lost their lives together with 21 British Policemen. 
The memorial comprises a large Cypriot rock, which was transport to the Arboretum by the RAF, set on top of a polished granite plinth inscribed with the insignia of all the units involved. An outline map of Cyprus is displayed on the side of the rock which includes the dedication. Inside the rock is held the ‘Roll of Honour’ with details of the 371 who lost their lives together with 21 British Policemen killed..

name: Coastal Command Grove
description: No information available

name: Cockleshell Heroes Memorial
description:
Royal Marine Boom Patrol Detachment
"Operation Frankton"
"The Cockleshell Heroes"
Located in the Allied Special Forces Memorial Grove is a seat in the shape of a Canoe which
commemorates the men of Royal Marine Boom Patrol Detachment – later known as the “Cockleshell Heroes”. On the night of 7 December 1942, ten Royal Marine Commandos climbed out of the submarine “HMS Tuna” and were launched into five two-man canoes. Their destination was Bordeaux Harbour and their mission was to destroy as many ships as possible using limpet mines which attach below the water line. This audacious raid was a success. However, some marines were lost in the icy cold waters of the Gironde estuary on the route in, and others were captured and executed by the Germans. Only two Marines survived the mission. This memorial is linked to the Phantom Memorial Garden located beside the Aspects Centre.
This memorial was designed by Mike Colton.
Dedicated in 2013. The memorial comprises a wooden seat in the symbolic shape of a 15ft. by 2ft. 6in. Cockle Mark II canoe, as used by the Royal Marines during "Operation Frankton" in 1942. This seat and the two memorial plaques commemorate the Royal Marines who took part and the French civilians who assisted them during their attempted escape after the successful raid. Behind the canoe is a large metal relief picture of the Marines leaving HMS Tuna which was a practice casting before the Bronze Memorial which sits at the 'Cockleshell Heroes' memorial at St. Genes de Blaye in France was made.
This memorial garden was designed by Mike Colton. Dedicated in 2014.

name: Cold War 1949-1968 Memorial
description: Cold War Memorial

name: Combined Operations Memorial
description: Combined Operations Memorial

name: Cyprus Emergency (1955-1959) Memorial
description:
Cyprus Emergency (1955-1959)
The memorial, located within the Mediterranean Campaigns of World War II Garden, is dedicated to all those who served during the ‘Cyprus Emergency’ 1955 – 1959 and in memory of the 371 who lost their lives together with 21 British Policemen. 
The memorial comprises a large Cypriot rock, which was transport to the Arboretum by the RAF, set on top of a polished granite plinth inscribed with the insignia of all the units involved. An outline map of Cyprus is displayed on the side of the rock which includes the dedication. Inside the rock is held the ‘Roll of Honour’ with details of the 371 who lost their lives together with 21 British Policemen killed.

name: Defensively Equipped Merchant Ships (DEMS) Memorial
description:
DEFENSIVLY EQUIPPED MERCHANT SHIPS (DEMS) MEMORIAL GARDEN
Learning from the success of Defensively ARMED Merchant Ships in WWl, the Admiralty established the DEMS organisation in 1938.
In the first 6 months of the Second World War some 1,900 ships had been defensively equipped and by the end of 1940, a total of 3,400 were armed.
Guns were manned by personnel from Maritime Royal Artillery, Royal Navy and Royal Marines.
Their primary role was defence against surfaced U-boats and aircraft.
The 40mm Bofors gun was one of the types of gun fitted to merchant ships, used mainly as an Anti-Aircraft weapon. Some merchant ships had larger 3-inch or 6-inch guns fitted.
Defensively Equipped Merchant Ships (DEMS)
In the centre of the Defensively Equipped Merchant Ships (DEMS) memorial garden is a Bofors gun of the type which were fitted on merchant ships and manned by personnel from Maritime Royal Artillery (MRA), the Royal Navy and the Royal Marines.
During the Second World War, DEMS gunners were deployed on merchant ships in numbers varying from two on the smallest ships to up to 100 in the larger transporters. They fought off enemy aircraft, mine, submarine and surface attacks to ensure that the merchant ships could carry supplies to services and civilians.
Sacrifices were heavy, with over 4,100 personnel killed or missing. Their names can be found in the “Book of Remembrance - The Merchant Navy World War Two” in the Millennium Chapel.

name: Desert Rats Association
description:
8TH ARMY (DESERT RATS)
8th Army was a field army formation of the British army established in 1941 until 1945. The army was made up of many soldiers from around the Commonwealth. They fought in the Western Desert Campaign, Tunisia, Sicilian and Italian Campaigns. Special operations units were set up from 8th Army, including Popski's Private Army who have a memorial on our special forces area.
Located by Lions Shelter and Gulf War Memorial. The 7th Armoured Division was a division of the British Army that saw distinguished service during World War II, where its exploits in the Western Desert Campaign gained it the ‘Desert Rats’ nickname. Since then, the desert rats insignia has been worn by generations of military units, celebrating the kinship and tenacity of those men and women fighting in the desert. The stylised sculpture, whilst representing the Desert Rats insignia, also symbolises armour, both light and heavy. The sculpture sits on a stone plinth, with sloping sides to represent the angles used on some armour and tanks. The sides of the plinth are carved with a sand motif with the words “Desert Rats” engraved and fading in and out of the pattern to suggest movement through time and sand.

name: Devonshire and Dorset Regiment
description:
DEVONSHIRE AND DORSET REGIMENT 
The Devonshire Regiment was first raised in 1685 and served under various names, until 1881 when it officially became The Devonshire Regiment. The Dorset Regiment was formed in 1881. The two regiments were amalgamated in 1958, ultimately being merged with various other regiments (represented by several memorials on this walk) to form the Rifles in 2007. 
Three soldiers sculptured in cast bronze are depicted on this Portland stone memorial: 
On the left is a soldier of the Devonshire Regiment in 1916 at the Somme. 
On the right is a soldier from the Dorset Regiment in 1944 in Kohima, as part of the Burma Campaign. 
In the middle is a soldier from the Devonshire and Dorset Regiment on patrol in Northern Ireland in the 1970s. 
In 1960 a newly commissioned officer, Herbert Jones joined the Devonshire and Dorset Regiment as a Second Lieutenant and served with them until he transferred to the Parachute Regiment in 1979, attaining the rank of Lieutenant Colonel. In 1982, H Jones, as he was known, was part of the task force in the Falklands conflict. At the battle of Goose Green, he was killed after displaying great leadership and courage. For this, he was posthumously awarded the VC.

name: Diamond Grove
description:
The Diamond Grove 
The trees in the Diamond Grove have been sponsored by couples from the Second World War generation to celebrate 60 years of marriage, their Diamond Wedding anniversary.

name: Dieppe Raid Memorial
description:
M-212 The Dieppe Raid -18/19th August 1942- 'Operation Jubilee' 
Commemorating the 65th Anniversary, 18th August 2007 
On August 18th 1942 more than 6,000 Allied soldiers, of whom almost 5,000 were Canadian sailed 
from the south coast of Britain to attack the German held French Port of Dieppe. 
The Dieppe Raid was called a 'Reconnaissance in Force' by the Combined Operations planners, and 
was intended to be both a morale booster when the early stages of the war were going badly for the 
Allies, and as a testing ground for a full scale invasion of Fortress Europe, along with an opportunity 
to gain vital intelligence. 
The Dieppe Raid turned out to be a military disaster, where nothing was achieved and about 60% of 
the 5,000 soldiers who eventually landed ashore were killed, wounded or captured. 
The Dieppe Raid Memorial, located in the Allied Special Forces Memorial Grove, remembers over 
42,000 Canadians who lost their lives during WW2 with over 900 during the raid. 
A second plaque honours Lt. Col. C. Merritt of the South Saskatchewan Regiment, John Foote of the 
Canadian Chaplains Service and Capt. Patrick Porteus of No.4 Commando. All of which received the 
Victoria Cross for their bravery. The scale of the Ground, Naval and Air Force losses are detailed here 
and an accompanying plaque lists all the forces that participated in 'Operation Jubilee'. 
The lessons learnt led to the successful invasion on June 6th 1944. 
The memorial design was by Mike Colton who also helped dig the Old Red Sandstone out from a 
quarry at Consall Hall and transport it to the site. The stone represents the formidable defences of 
Dieppe. 
Dedicated in 2007.

name: Douglas Skene Grove
description:
Douglas Skene Grove 
Douglas Skene (1948 – 2007) was a dedicated military historian, a serving officer in the Royal Scots Greys and a member of the Territorial Army with the Royal Green Jackets. He practiced as an independent financial consultant, but his hobby was to lead tours to First World War battlefields. 
His other great love was trees and he enjoyed watching the Arboretum develop from its inception until his untimely death at the age of 59. Following his death, his family, friends and colleagues raised funds towards setting up the first grove of specimen trees at the Arboretum, a lasting legacy to his memory. 
Trees in the Grove include the barberry (Berberis valdivian) from Chile; the sweet buckeye (Aesculus flava) from South-East USA; the Chinese weeping cypress (Cupressus funebris) from central China; and the Japanese white pine (Pinus parviflora).

name: Duke of Lancaster's Regiment Memorial
description:
Duke of Lancaster’s Regiment Memorial 
The Duke of Lancaster’s Regiment is the Infantry Regiment of the North-West of England, known as the 'Lions of England'. The reigning monarch of the United Kingdom is the Duke of Lancaster. The regiment consists of two Regular Army Battalions (1 LANCS and 2 LANCS) and one Army Reserve Battalion (4 LANCS). It was formed on 1 July 2006 by the amalgamation of the King’s Own Royal Border Regiment, the King’s Regiment and the Queen’s Lancashire Regiment. The memorial includes a carved plinth of Cumbrian stone, which is set on a circular stone pavement. The impressive heraldic ‘Lion of England’, standing proudly on top of the plinth, commemorates those The Gordon Highlanders Memorial Representing the 200-year history of the Regiment and the soldiers’ family roots, the memorial is an ever-lasting statement for future generations. It is sculpted from local material to identify with the Gordon Highlanders. Underneath the main Gordon Highlanders cap badge, the inscription concludes with the Regiment’s motto – the Scottish word ‘bydand’, which translates to ‘steadfast’, or 'not to run away from danger and keep going no matter the di›culties'. who have died whilst serving with the Regiment since its formation. The memorial, with the Lion’s paw pointing towards Lancaster, was unveiled by Her Late Majesty Queen Elizabeth II, the then Colonel-in-Chief, The Duke of Lancaster’s Regiment on 17 May 2016.

name: Duke of York's Military School
description:
DUKE OF YORK'S ROYAL MILITARY SCHOOL
Memorial was unveiled 18 September 2017. It commemorates all pupils of the school known as 'Dukies' who gave their lives in service of their country. The school w DUKE OF YORK'S ROYAL MILITARY SCHOOL Map 
Memorial was unveiled 18 September 2017. It commemorates all pupils of the school known as 'Dukies' who gave their lives in service of their country. The school was founded in 1803 to provide educational opportunities to orphans and children of soldiers made destitute as a result of the Napoleonic Wars. 
Emblems associated with the school are depicted on the memorial, including The White Rose of York together with the school colours. 
It is only one of 3 schools in England that has been awarded colours in recognition of a large number of pupils who have joined the Armed Forces. as founded in 1803 to provide educational opportunities to orphans and children of soldiers made destitute as a result of the Napoleonic Wars. 
Emblems associated with the school are depicted on the memorial, including The White Rose of York together with the school colours. It is only one of 3 schools in

name: Durham Light Infantry Memorial
description:
DURHAM LIGHT INFANTRY 
The memorial depicts a statue of a Durham Light Infantry bugler dressed in combat uniform of the Korean War. An identical statue stands in Durham city centre.
The DLI amalgamated with other regiments to form the Light Infantry in 1968 (refer to the neighbouring memorial).
The bugle is the symbol of all Light Infantry Regiments and is present on their badges – dating from the days when they were the lightest and most mobile units in the British Army, and the bugle was essential for issuing orders.

name: Edward's Trust Garden
description:
EDWARD’S TRUST GARDEN Map
This wooden structure is for the Edward’s Trust, a charity which provides bereavement services, mainly for parents who have lost a child, or children affected by a death. The Trust was set up in 1989 by the parents of Edward Dent, who died aged just 7yrs, and is how it came to be called ‘Edward’s Trust’. At its centre is a ‘Tree of Hope’, where parents can hang a copper leaf bearing the name of their child as an act of remembrance. We are now entering the children’s activity and family picnic area, where we have some features relating mainly to children and young people:

name: Escape Lines Memorial ; Home Run
description: Escape Lines Memorial ; Home Run

name: Essex Regiment Memorial
description:
ESSEX REGIMENT 
This 4m high Portland stone obelisk, with Essex flints around the base, is the memorial for the Essex Regiment. It stands on paving in the shape of Gibraltar Fort, reflecting the regiment’s service there, with a bronze and gold Salamanca Eagle (created by Ian Rank-Broadley) on top.
The original eagle was taken from the French at the battle of Salamanca in 1812. The Royal Anglian Regiment, successor of the Essex Regiment, still have the Eagle as a shoulder patch on their uniforms.
On the side panels are a map of Essex and the regiment’s battle honours, including winners of the Victoria Cross. (Spelling of serjeant is correct here - some regiments used ‘j’ instead of ‘g’ at that time).

name: Ex-National Servicemen's Memorial
description:
NATIONAL SERVICE VETERANS 
This is dedicated to all those who served their country as National Servicemen between 1939 and 1960. Young men were called up to serve in the Army, Navy or Air Force for two years. 
The green granite sculpture has four wings which represent the four points of the compass as National Service was performed around the world, while the Crown indicates that they were in the service of ‘The Crown’. 
Many thousands of those named on the Armed Forces Memorial were National Service men. 
Veterans hold an annual parade here each June and are usually joined in the march-past by a few former Bevin Boys, whose memorial we will see shortly. 
A number of National Service Personnel served in the Korean Conflict 1950 to 1953

name: Falkland Island Resistance
description:
The Falkland Islanders Resistance Memorial Map
This memorial depicts three upland/ magellan geese in flight, heading south. The three geese represent lightness, movement and freedom.

name: Far East Air Force Memorial
description:
Far East Air Force Memorial
Dedicated in 2006, this memorial, comprising 42 hand engraved Lakeland slate tiles, commemorates the history of the Royal Air Force from 1948 to 1971, when the RAF was engaged in assisting the Malays through confrontation and a period of emergency. 
Malaysia gained independence in 1957 and Singapore separated from Malaysia in 1965. As both nations developed their own Armed Forces, the RAF reduced its commitment and withdrew in 1971. 
The Units listed on the memorial were the backbone of operations and provided bases for strategic reinforcement to the Far East, should it have been required.

name: Far East Prisoners of War Grove
description:
The Far East Prisoners of War (FEPOW) Grove is approached through the Changi Lych Gate, originally constructed at the POW Cemetery in Singapore. On its right is the memorial of the National Federation of FEPOW Clubs and Associations who were amongst the first to make a donation to the Arboretum. On its left is a map of the Japanese Empire six months after the outbreak of war in the Far East. Half of the approximately 50,000 British servicemen captured by the Japanese in the Second World War were forced to work on the Burma/Thai Railway. Other FEPOWs worked building airfields and roads, and many were transported to Japan to work in mines, shipbuilding yards and other heavy industries. Approximately 800 British POWs were amongst those who built a railway in Sumatra.
Most of the trees in the Grove are dedicated to individual FEPOWs from all three services and to internees. Other trees relate to groups of FEPOWs and four of these are worthy of special mention: The estimated 1,000 UK FEPOWs who died in North Borneo, principally on the “Death Marches”. The estimated 600 UK FEPOWs transported from Singapore who died in or near the Solomon Islands. All FEPOWs lost at sea while being transported. The civilian and military women and children who perished.

name: Far East Prisoners of War Memorial Building
description:
THE FEPOW MEMORIAL BUILDING 
Fundraising for the museum started on the 15th February 2002, the 60th anniversary of the surrender of Singapore to the Japanese, which is when the majority of FEPOWs were captured. The majority of funding was raised by an organisation called COFEPOW (Children of Far East Prisoners of War). COFEPOW came about after a lady named Carol Cooper, from Norfolk, read an article in a newspaper in 1994, concerning the diary of a former prisoner-of-war of the Japanese. She realised that this was the diary of her father who went to fight in the Far East when she was only 2 years old but had died working on the Burma railway.
▪ After receiving a transcript of the diary, she went to Burma in an attempt to find his grave. Her journey was made into a documentary by the BBC. Many other children and relatives of such prisoners then contacted Carol and COFEPOW was formed in 1997. It took 3½ years to raise the funds, the same amount of time that the FEPOWs spent in the horrendous conditions of the prison camps. The building was officially opened on VJ Day 2005 the 60th anniversary of the end of the war in South East Asia. It is designed to take the shape of a prison hut. Inside there are exhibits and artefacts covering the experiences of the servicemen and civilians who were taken prisoner. In the far right-hand corner of the museum is a copy of the Java Windows. These are replicas of the two made by a British Naval officer whilst a prisoner]and were situated in a small chapel that the Japanese allowed them to have, mainly for propaganda purposes. A close inspection of the British coat of arms will reveal that the lion has the face of Winston Churchill. Knowing that their captors had not discovered this helped to keep up morale. The original windows still survive today and can be found in All Saints Church in Jakarta, Indonesia. Also, look for the names being projected onto the wall at the end of the museum. This is a list of all those who were imprisoned, including the survivors and you can search for individual names using the touch screen. On another touch screen, data held by the Commonwealth War Graves Commission can be accessed.

name: Fauld Explosion Memorial
description:
FAULD EXPLOSION
This was one of the largest non-nuclear explosions in history, and the largest to occur on UK soil. 
Fauld is located about 10 miles from the Arboretum, between Burton on Trent and Uttoxeter. 
The large boulder forms a memorial to those who died in an explosion at the underground bomb and ammunition dump. 
In November 1944, bombs and ammunition stored in the Gypsum mine in were accidentally detonated killing 70 people 
It is believed that a quantity of undetonated explosive still lies below ground. 
The crater is still clearly visible to walkers today and is best seen walking from Hanbury village

name: Fellowship of the Services Memorial
description: Tangent Index The National Association of Tangent Clubs is one of the largest women's organisations in the UK, with around 500 Clubs and 10,000 members. Tangent members usually meet once a month, though this varies from Club to Club. Tangent offers a varied programme of events and activities which are unique to each individual Club, but all include a mixture of fellowship, friendship, fun and fundraising. The National Association of Tangent Clubs (Tangent) is part of the Round Table Family which is made up of Ladies Circle (aged 18-45)

name: Fire and Rescue Services Memorial
description:
FIRE AND RESCUE SERVICE
This impressive red granite memorial acknowledges the service and courage of past, present and future fire fighters. 
The 8 points of the star attached to the memorial represents the qualities needed to be a fire-fighter - Tact, Gallantry, Dexterity, Observation, Perseverance, Loyalty, Explicitness, and Sympathy. 
On the back the memorial bears the inscription ‘Firefighters Serving Humanity’ and the Latin motto ‘Flammas Oppugnantes Fidimus Deo’. This translates as ‘Fighting Fire Our Trust in God’ and is the motto of the Worshipful Company of Firefighters. 
The red stone of the memorial represents flame 
The grey paving stones and memorial plinth represents ash 
The memorial was unveiled on 20 May 2008 by HRH The Princess Royal, patron of the Firefighters Memorial Trust

name: Fire Bell Memorial to Betty Wills
description: Fire Bell Memorial to Betty Wills

name: Fleet Air Arm British Pacific and East Indies Fleets Aircrew Memorial
description:
Fleet Air Arm British Pacific and East Indies Fleets Aircrew Memorial
The memorial remembers the Aircrew members of the British Pacific and East Indies Fleets operating from H.M, Aircraft carriers who lost their lives during air attacks on enemy held territory or were captured and subsequently executed.
Also remembered on the memorial are “comrades-in-arms of allied services including the United States Army twentieth Air Force who lost their lives in similar circumstance in Southeast Asia and the Pacific 1942-1945”.

name: Fleet Air Arm Memorial (FLY Navy Federation)
description:
FLEET AIR ARM 
British naval flying started in 1909, with the construction of an airship for naval duties. In 1911 the Royal Navy graduated its first aeroplane pilots at the Royal Aero Club flying ground at RAF Eastchurch. 
In 1912, naval and army aviation were combined to become the Royal Flying Corps (RFC). The Naval Wing of the RFC lasted until July 1914 when the Royal Navy reformed its air branch, under the Air Department of the Admiralty, naming it the Royal Naval Air Service (RNAS). 
By the outbreak of the First World War, in August 1914, the RNAS had more aircraft under its control than the remaining RFC. The roles of the RNAS were fleet reconnaissance, patrolling coasts for enemy ships and submarines and attacking enemy coastal territory. 
In April 1918 the RNAS, which at this time had 67,000 officers and men, 2,949 aircraft, 103 airships and 126 coastal stations, merged with the RFC to form the Royal Air Force. 
In 1924, the Fleet Air Arm of the Royal Air Force was formed, encompassing those RAF units that normally embarked on aircraft carriers and fighting ships. The year was significant for British naval aviation as only weeks before the founding of the Fleet Air Arm, the Royal Navy had commissioned HMS Hermes, the world's first ship to be designed and built as an aircraft carrier. 
In 2009 the Royal Navy celebrated the centenary of Naval Aviation, and the memorial honours the sacrifice made by 6,749 men and women who gave their lives in the service of naval aviation over those 100 years. 
Over 80% of front-line Fleet Air Arm Squadrons are currently deployed on operations round the world. 
The memorial is a sculptured plinth of Portland Stone supporting a granite aircraft carrier. The inscription on the base is taken from Psalm 139 in the Bible

name: Flight Lieutenant J W Lucas DFC
description:
Flt Lt J W Lucas DFC 
This memorial is dedicated by the Lucas family to honour Flight Lieutenant James William Lucas D.F.C 1918-2001, who in commemoration of his dedication to duty as a Second World War pilot, was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross.
The memorial is a grey polish granite bench with a dedication panel of black polished granite beneath the seat. The panel is inscribed with a dedication and features a propeller and the badge of Bomber Command contained within a white circle.
The memorial is located within the RAF Memorial Grove (known as the RAF Wing) which comprises a collection of silver birch trees planted in the shape of an eagle’s wings.

name: Foresters Friendly Society Memorial
description:
Foresters Friendly Society Memorial
The Ancient Order of Foresters Friendly Society was formed in 1834 to provide fraternal mutual support to members in times of sickness and bereavement. Two members of the Order Lance Corporal William Charles Fuller and Lance Corporal William Angus were awarded the Victoria Cross for valour during the First World War.

name: Free Spirit Horse Memorial
description:
Free Spirit Horse Memorial
A tribute to the unique contribution made by horses throughout history in times of War. Recognising their continuing service to humankind in Work, Rehabilitation, Education, Sport and Leisure. In 2013 a group of people with a love of horses came together with a vision to create a memorial acknowledging the horse’s unfaltering service to humankind and to celebrate the unique relationship between horses and humans that exists through sport, history, work, rehabilitation, education and leisure. This beautiful sculpture and its carefully planned setting were unveiled in 2019, made possible through generous donations and the work of local craftspeople who contributed their skills to realising the vision of Free Spirit.
Free Spirit is a unique project that embodies the inclusiveness that is reflected in the non-judgmental partnership between horse and human. Gartmore Riding School in Hammerwich and many contributors raised funds to create a life-sized bronze statue acknowledging the horse’s unfaltering service to humanity, to be displayed at the National Memorial Arboretum, Staffordshire. There are few people left today that remember the essential role the horse played through history and how until a generation ago the horse was part of everyday life. The memorial expresses endurance, service and partnership and represents determination and trust, inspiration for which came from young people. The project brought together individuals from all ages and backgrounds sharing the importance of the horse to different generations, ethnicities and religions. The groundwork has been carefully designed to welcome all visitors, regardless of mobility or disability, allowing all members of society to enjoy the memorial together. The provision of spaces between the seats creates multiple points of access for wheelchair users; a lower plinth height and plaques incorporating Braille and Makaton allow the visually impaired to enjoy the memorial through a tactile experience. Free Spirit brought the essential contribution that the horse has made to humanity to new audiences and generations in a number of projects, including art, music and history, and worked across the local community and beyond. The opportunity to meet a pony has never been easily accessible to many of the young people visiting by the project, and Free Spirit recognises that the unique relationship between horse and human can increase confidence and self-esteem, and that this connection leaves a legacy that continues to bring joy to this and future generations. The horse is part of our story, and the people involved in its inception and creation were particularly proud to see so many young people engaging with the project. Inspired by the thoughts and feelings of these young people, Birmingham songwriter Dominic Malin wrote a signature song for Free Spirit. The song embraces the qualities associated with the horse and the music reflects the past, engages with the present and carries a message into the future. It is an honour to have horses in our lives and Free Spirit represents this for centuries and generations to come.

name: Gallipoli Memorial
description:
GALLIPOLI 
This memorial is to the many thousands of lives lost in the First World War at Gallipoli in Turkey between April 1915 and January 1916, when the Allies were attempting to open a supply route into the Black Sea for Russia and to enable them to attack Germany from a different direction. 
It is estimated that the Allies lost 265,000 men through battle fatalities, injuries and sickness. 
ANZAC (Australia & New Zealand Army Corps) day is 25th April each year, the day the Australian & New Zealand forces landed on the beaches at Gallipoli. 
The memorial includes a tree sculpture of 9 dead Oak trees which have been pollarded. This gives the effect of the outstretched arms and hands of the soldiers appealing for help as they lay injured. 
The arched displays include a map of the area created in a glass mosaic, and a moving poem. 
(9 trees because combatants from 9 main countries were involved at Gallipoli – Great Britain, France, Australia, New Zealand, Newfoundland, India; against Germany, Austria Hungary and the Ottoman empire [Turkey])

name: Garden of the Innocents
description:
The Garden of the Innocents 
A memorial to all children who are victims of war and terrorism. The white planting symbolises innocence and the raised beds are in the shape of jigsaw pieces that do not fit together, symbolising the confusion and bewilderment children suŽer through war and violence. In the centre of the garden is an elder tree ‘Sambucus nigra’, planted in memory of Anne Frank. Every year on Anne’s birthday, the blossoms of the tree are cut so the tree never bears fruit, just as Anne herself was prevented from reaching maturity.

name: GCHQ Memorial
description:
GCHQ (GOVERNMENT COMMUNICATIONS HEADQUARTERS) 
The globe of pink granite is a tribute to all those who have served, and continue to serve, in the vital departments gathering information to support the British Government in its overseas and domestic operations.
On the theme of communications, the morse code message reads ‘GC&CS’ (the former name of the organisation being Government Code & Cypher School). The binary code reads ‘GCHQ’.
GC&CS was formed in 1919. During WW2 it was stationed at Bletchley Park, working on the breaking of the Enigma code, and began to call itself GCHQ. In the 1950s it moved to Cheltenham, which is where its main offices are now.
GCHQ is the UK’s intelligence and cyber agency. Its mission is to help keep the country safe through intelligence gathering for the purposes of:
Counter terrorism
Cyber security
Tackling serious and organised crime
To gain strategic advantage over potential hostile nations
Supporting defence
The location of the memorial is deliberately concealed to suggest the organisation’s involvement with covert operations.

name: General Post Office Memorial Garden (GPO)
description:
GENERAL POST OFFICE MEMORIAL GARDEN
In the first half of the 20th Century, the Post Office was the largest peacetime state employer in the United Kingdom, responsible for operating the postal, telephone and telegraph services. In wartime its staff had to rise to the immense challenge of meeting both civil and military communication requirements. Many transferred to the armed services where they often applied their experience and skills to communication work. 
In 1939 73,000 GPO workers were called into the services, just when mobilisation and evacuation caused millions of people to change address, so increasing the amount of mail posted and the problems of delivering it during the blackout. Post Offices played a key role by distributing millions of ration books, public information leaflets, and paying out allowances. 
GPO staff served in all arms of the fighting forces and 3,800 of them died. 
The path is laid out in the shape of the Royal Mail insignia. 
The older EIIR pillar boxes are from the period 1952 - 1991 and ‘Royal Mail’ appeared on them first in 1991. All have the crowns of the relevant Sovereign at the time. There are boxes for Edward VII and George VI. 
The green Victorian wall post box was blown out of its wall in Deptford, London during the blitz - note the damage - but the local people rebuilt the wall and replaced the box to keep the service running. 
2023: The memorial garden is due to be redeveloped

name: George Cross Island Association (Malta) Memorial
description:
MALTA 
In the middle is a memorial to Malta, known as The George Cross Island. The people of Malta defended their island against the German/Italian invasion in 1941. Although the islanders were close to starvation and running out of 
ammunition, they fought on regardless to defend the island successfully. 
The island was an essential base for the British. 
In recognition of the bravery of the islanders, on 15 April 1942, King George VI awarded the George Cross to the people of Malta.

name: Gibraltar Memorial
description:
GIBRALTAR 
▪ Gibraltar has been under British control since 1704. "The Rock" is a deepwater harbour which during WW2 provided the British and our allies with a strategic naval base. 
▪ Gibraltar proved useful again in 1982 when it supplied the British Task Force on its way to reclaim the Falkland Islands. 
▪ Today NATO still uses Gibraltar as a naval base for humanitarian missions. 
▪ The white marble plinth has a model of "The Rock" which has been carved from a 3-ton block of Gibraltar limestone. Around the plinth, it names some of the fallen from Gibraltar in both World Wars.

name: Gift of Life Memorial ; Donor Family Network
description:
DONOR FAMILY NETWORK
The Memorial honours those who have donated organs and tissue to save or improve the lives of others. It also recognises their families and patients who have received an organ transplant or whose lives have been transformed by tissue donation. Currently there are around 6,500 people waiting for a transplant in the UK and on average three people die every day because of the shortage of donor organs. The memorial was designed and created by sculptor Julia Hennessy-Priest. The Birmingham artist has spent years perfecting the work, which is inspired by the DFN logo, a colourful mosaic butterfly representing hope and new life, on top of a forget-me-not flower, as no organ or tissue donor will ever be forgotten.

name: Girls Venture Corps Memorial
description:
Girls Venture Corps Memorial 
The Girls Venture Corps Air Cadets is a voluntary uniformed organisation set up to meet the aspirations of young women between the ages of 11–20 and adult volunteers of all ages.

name: Glider Pilot Regiment Memorial
description:
Glider Pilot Regiment
The Regiment was established in 1942 and remained active until 1957, when it was absorbed into the modern Army Air Corps. The Regiment’s motto was “Nothing is impossible”, as the nature of their one way trips required the aircrews to subsequently join in combat operations on the ground. The Regiment’s highly trained aircrew was also used to great effect in covert activity. In the post war years, the Regiment remained active, undertaking liaison and reconnaissance roles in the Light Aircraft Flights operated by the Army. On 1 September 1957, the Regiment disbanded to create the foundation of what was to become the modern Army Air Corps. The memorial stone is sourced from Gelderland in the Netherlands to acknowledge the Regiment’s major role in the Battle of Arnhem.

name: Gloucestershire Regiment
description:
The Royal Gloucestershire, Berkshire and Wiltshire Regiment Map Index
This memorial commemorates the following regiments:
• The Gloucestershire Regiment (28th & 61st) 1694 – 1994
• The Royal Berkshire Regiment (Princess Charlotte of Wales’s) 1743 – 1959
• The Wiltshire Regiment (Duke of Edinburgh’s) 1756 – 1959
• The Duke of Edinburgh’s Royal Regiment (Berkshire and Wiltshire) 1959 — 1994 (The amalgamation of The Royal Berkshire and The Wiltshire Regiments in 1959)
• The Royal Gloucestershire, Berkshire and Wiltshire Regiment (1994 — 2007) (The amalgamation of The Gloucestershire and The Duke of Edinburgh’s Royal Regiments in 1994)
In 2007 The Royal Gloucestershire, Berkshire and Wiltshire Regiment merged with The Devonshire & Dorset Regiment, The Light Infantry and The Royal Green Jackets to form The Rifles.
The right to wear the ‘Back Badge’ on the back of their headdress was awarded to the 28th Regiment of Foot for extreme bravery at the battle of Alexandria in 1801. It was subsequently worn by The Gloucestershire and The Royal Gloucestershire, Berkshire and Wiltshire Regiments, and is now worn by The Rifles.

name: Golden Grove
description:
GOLDEN GROVE 
This is one of our many non-military sites. The trees, which have golden bark, leaves or fruit have been sponsored for people who have celebrated Golden Wedding Anniversaries. 
The banks have been raised like an Iron Age fort, and Girl Guides from Staffordshire planted masses of yellow daffodils around the inside of the banks.

name: Gordon Highlanders
description:
THE GORDON HIGHLANDERS 
The Gordon Highlanders have existed for 113 years: 1794-1994, their motto is ‘Byband’ meaning steadfast. The regiment took part in the attempt to relieve Major Charles Gordon at Khartoum. They were amalgamated with The Queens' Own Highlanders (Seaforth and Camerons) on 17 September 1994 to form the Highlanders (Seaforth, Gordons and Camerons). The Speyside sculptor – Stuart Murdoch, carved the design from granite local to the regiments home intending to make a clearly identifiable statement of strength and durability. The memorial was installed on 26th June 2020.

name: Green Howards
description:
The Green Howards Memorial Stone
The Concept
The Green Howards (Alexandra, Princess of Wales’s Own Yorkshire Regiment) was a British Army Infantry Regiment raised in 1688 by Colonel Francis Luttrell at Dunster Castle. It was based in Richmond, North Yorkshire and amalgamated for the first and only time in 2006 to form part of The Yorkshire Regiment.
The Green Howards has a vibrant Association with branches spread over North Yorkshire and Teesside and others as far away as London and Kent.
Although The Green Howards is well served with memorials honouring its fallen up to 1945, particularly at its home in Richmond and at Crépon in Normandy, there was nothing in stone, other than The Armed Forces Memorial, where all those who died whilst serving on duty or were killed in action after 1945 are honoured.
An application was lodged with the NMA on 8th January 2019 to place an appropriate and proportionate stone dedicated to those Green Howards named on the Armed Forces Memorial. It was further deemed appropriate to commemorate all those who have served with the Regiment from the time of its raising.
The Design Team
Major Michael Pickard, a retired Green Howard, was invited to design the stone in June 2018. He was assisted by Colonel Clive Mantell and Major Tony Warriner, the Chairman and Secretary of the Green Howards Association. It was designed, quarried, carved and erected in time for a dedication service on the 165th anniversary of the Battle of the Alma on the 19th September 2019.
The Design
The stone is a waisted, square section, silver/grey granite column, approx. 6 feet 4 inches high, in three parts set on a stone paved base.The top part is a solid hand-carved Norwegian King’s Crown with polished extremities and honed on the inner surfaces.
The middle part is a plain polished truncated pyramidal form resting on four lower tapered faces.
On one face of the stone the lineage displayed creates a permanent and lasting record of the 318 years of its history above a dedication to all those who have served with the Regiment.
On the opposite face is a record of countries where the Regiment has served since 1945 above a dedication to the proud memory of those Green Howards killed in action or on duty and honoured on the Armed Forces Memorial.
Everything on the stone is significant and interlinked:
• The two badges (one from the first half of the 20th c and the other from the second half) show the cipher of HRH Alexandra, Princess of Wales, interlaced with the Dannebrog, surmounted by a princess’s coronet and the date 1875 when the Regiment was designated ‘The Princess of Wales’s Own’ (Thus starting the close connection with the Royal Houses of the Kingdoms of Denmark and Norway).
• The crown at the top recognises the Kings of Norway who were Colonels-in-Chief from 1914 to 2006.
• The Battle of the Alma, the principal battle honour, celebrated every year on, or near, the dedication day is included to emphasise the importance of this anniversary to the Regiment: 19th September 2019.
•The 19th Regiment of Foot (XIX) features strongly because The Green Howards is one of just a handful of Line Regiments to retain its original designated number.
Material and Construction
The silver/grey granite was quarried and cut to shape in Chennai, Tamil Nadu, India and then carved and installed by Strongs Memorials Limited, 39 Park Road, Bloxwich, Walsall, West Midlands WS3 3SS
Project leader: Andrew Hodgson. Inscription carving: Andrew Walsh. CAD: Mark Abesamis and Robin Mills.
Position
The stone is positioned 100 metres to the West of the Armed Forces Memorial and close to both the memorials of The Yorkshire Regiment and the Prince of Wales’s Own Yorkshire Regiment.

name: Guardsmen of the Sky Memorial;Guards Parachute Association
Guinea Pig Club Memorial
description:
GUINEA PIG CLUB
The Guinea Pig Club, established in July 1941, was a social club and mutual support network for British and allied aircrew injured during the Second World War. 
Its membership was made up of patients of Sir Archibold McIndoe at Queen Victoria Hospital, East Grinstead, Sussex, who had undergone pioneering reconstructive surgery, generally after receiving burns injuries in aircraft. 
By the end of the Second World War the club had 649 members. 
The memorial, which stands over 2 metres high, is carved from green Cumbrian slate and resembles the shape of a Spitfire wing. 
The design features a crashed Hurricane at the bottom with its vapour trail weaving down from the top. The logo of the Guinea Pig Club is also carved at the top of the memorial. On the left hand side of the design, the meandering vapour trail of the falling Hurricane outlines the strong facial profile of the pioneering plastic surgeon, Sir Archibald McIndoe. 
Along the memorial’s right edge is an inscription “Out of the flames came inspiration” provided by Guinea Pig Dr. Sandy Saunders. The memorial was unveiled by HRH The Duke of Edinburgh, president of the Guinea Pig Club, on 2 November 2016. Index 
The Guinea Pig Club was established in 1941. Its membership was made up of patients of Archibald McIndoe at Queen Victoria Hospital, East Grinstead, Sussex, who had carried out experimental reconstructive plastic surgery on airmen who had received burn injuries in aircraft. The club remained active after the end of the war, and its annual reunion meetings continued until 2007. 
The outline of Archibald McIndoe’s face forms the left side of this memorial. 
The memorial was unveiled in 2016 by the Duke of Edinburgh.

name: Gulf War 1990-1991 Memorial
description:
Gulf War 1990-1991 Memorial
This memorial was dedicated in honour of the 47 British personnel who died in the liberation of Kuwait and all those who fought in the Gulf War. The memorial comprises three stainless steel supporting pillars representing each of Britain’s three Armed Forces. The centre stone of the memorial carries the image of the reverse of the Gulf Medal, engraved in black granite. Each of the 47 pavers on the memorial, which are laid out in concentric circles, carries the name of one of the fallen. Beneath the centre stone, there are 48 poppies from the Festival of Remembrance at the Royal Albert Hall in 2015, one poppy for each of the ‘47 fallen’ and one solitary poppy for all of the veterans who have passed away since the Gulf War. The memorial, which is aligned on a compass bearing of 302 degrees from true north - the compass bearing from Kuwait to the Arboretum, carries an inscription in English, Latin and Arabic. The inscription reads: ‘In memory of the 47 fallen comrades, and to all those who fought in Operation Granby (1990-91) - The Liberation of Kuwait, those who subsequently passed away and also those that continued to fight their own battles, long after the guns fell silent. Lest We Forget

name: Heroes' Square
description:
Heroes' Square 
Adjacent to the Remembrance Centre is Heroes’ Square, a cloistered courtyard, which provides a welcoming area to gather for events, relax with friends and to look at the breath-taking vistas across the Arboretum. 
Within Heroes’ Square are many crests, badges or cyphers which have been elegantly carved into the York Stone paviours, a material chosen for its visual appeal and hard-wearing qualities. 
The red oaks, providing a natural canopy above them, have been selected for their beautiful red foliage during the autumn, the season of Remembrance.

name: Hertfordshire Police 'Rayner, Mandy, PC'
description: If we look back to the top of The Beat we can see a traditional Blue Police lamp, they used to be situated outside most Police Stations. This one originates from Hitchin, Hertfordshire, Police Station, it was placed here in memory of Mandy Raynor, the youngest Policewoman to lose her life whilst on duty.

name: Hiroshima Stone
description:
Hiroshima Memorial 
The Hiroshima Memorial Cairn lies at the corner of the Anglo-Japanese Peace Garden and is surmounted by a granite stonefrom the ruins of Hiroshima. 
The nearby plaque reminds us of the efforts of the late Philip Malins MBE MC, the Midland Japanese Association and the East Midlands Japanese Association in enabling the memorial to be placed here. 
The following inscription curves round the base of the Cairn: 
This memorial, the topmost stone of which is denoted by the people of Hiroshima from the ruins of their city, destroyed by an atomic bomb in 1945, remembers the millions of people who died and suffered in the Second World War. It gives thank that the world has since been free from world war, which hope there will never be another and that the people of Britain and Japan will remain forever united in friendship.

name: HM Ships Glorious, Acasta and Ardent Memorial
description:
HMS Glorious, HMS Acasta & HMS Ardent
The Loss of HMS Glorious, HMS Acasta & HMS Ardent on 8th June 1940. 
Scharnhorst (Kapitain zur See Hoffman) and Gneisenau (Kapitan zur See Netzbandt), during the course of the Kriegsmarine’s Operation Juno, sank the aircraft carrier HMS Glorious (Captain Guy D’Oyly-Hughes DSO, 1159 crew and 59 RAF personnel were lost; only 39 survivors) and her two escorts HMS Acasta (Commander C E Glasfurd, there was only one survivor) and HMS Ardent-H41 (Lt Commander J E Barker, 152 crew killed and the 2 survivors became POW) in somewhat controversial circumstances. 
Why was HMS Glorious detached from the rest of the fleet sailing from Narvik and sailing with only two destroyers for escort? Why didn’t HMS Glorious have aircraft in the air watching for enemy warships? However, HMS Acasta torpedoed the Scharnhorst causing damage that put her out of action for the remainder of the year. 
Admiral Sir Charles Forbes recommended that both Commander Glasfurd and Lieutenant Commander Barker be awarded the Victoria Cross: they were awarded a posthumous Mention in Despatches. 
The first 2 letters of the ships names forms, GLARAC, the name of the association.

name: HMA Nairana & 835 Royal Naval Air Squadron Memorial Grove
description:
HMS Nairana & 835 Royal Naval Air Squadron Memorial Grove 
The memorial comprises eight oak trees located in a corner of the Royal Naval Review adjacent the Merchant Navy Wood.

name: HMS Antelope Garden
description:
Antelope Garden 
The garden was opened on 2 April 2007 by Captain Nick Tobin, the former Commanding Officer of HMS Antelope, which was sunk during the campaign. It is planted with a deciduous azalea (Viscosa Antelope), which produces a pink fragrant flower in May. 
Nearby is a tree, planted by Lady Fieldhouse in memory of her husband, Admiral of the Fleet Lord Fieldhouse of Gosport, in the County of Hampshire. As Commander in Chief Fleet in 1982, John Fieldhouse was the Commander of the Task Force and given responsibility for ‘Operation Corporate’, the mission to recover the Falkland Islands.

name: HMS Ardent Memorial
description:
HMS ARDENT 
To the left of the Falklands Memorial is the anchor from HMS ARDENT, one of the ships lost in the Falklands conflict. 
Several years prior to the conflict she was anchored in Portland Harbour when a storm blew up and she was in danger of being driven ashore; to prevent this they severed one of her anchors and took her out to sea; the anchor was left on the sea bed. Following the loss of Ardent, Babcock Ltd. raised the anchor, renovated it and donated it to the South Atlantic Medal Association as a tribute and memorial to the ship and crew. 
This memorial is one of the original Anchors from the Type 21 frigate, HMS Ardent. The anchor was lost in a storm in Portland harbour in 1980. 
HMS Ardent was lost in action on 21 May 1982, defending the landings to retake the Falkland Islands. The HMS Ardent association was formed by the survivors. 
The anchor was recovered some years later and offered to the Association as a permanent memorial to all those shipmates who lost their lives in the 
the South Atlantic. The memorial was dedicated on 21 May 2015 in the presence of HRH The Duchess of Gloucester GCVO.

name: HMS Argonaut Memorial
description:
HMS ARGONAUT
Four different ships have carried the name HMS Argonaut, the first was in 1782; the second was a WW1 Cruiser; and the third, a WW2 Cruiser which took part in the D-Day landings in 1944. 
The final Argonaut, a Frigate, took part in the Falklands conflict where it was badly damaged; Able Seaman Iain Boldy and Able Seaman Matthew J Stuart lost their lives. Their names appear on the back of the memorial, as well as on the AFM. 
Margaret Allen, the wife of lain Boldy, was instrumental in the creation of this memorial which shows the ship's crest, under which is part of a poem written by Margaret. 
Four ships named HMS Argonaut have served with the Royal Navy. 
For the last three ships, the names of the crew members who died while serving on the ship are recorded on the reverse face of the memorial. 
The fourth HMS Argonaut (the Leander-class frigate – Pennant Number F56), was commissioned in 1967 and saw service across the world including escorting the RMS Queen Mary on her final voyage to the USA. 
In April 1982, she set sail for the Falkland Islands in the South Atlantic to join the existing naval task force as part of Operation Corporate. The ship was badly damaged while patrolling in San Carlos Bay on 21 May 1982 and two of her crew were lost. 
The memorial is dedicated to all those lost whilst serving on HMS Argonaut and was unveiled on 21 May 2017.

name: HMS Barham Memorial
description:
HMS BARHAM MEMORIAL
HMS Barham was a Queen Elizabeth Class Battleship armed with 8 15-inch guns: she was launched on 31st December 1914 and entered service the following year. Most notably she was part of the 5th Battle Squadron at the Battle of Jutland in 1916, when it was attached to Vice Admiral Beaty's Battle Cruiser Squadron. 
She saw extensive service in the first half of WW2 and took part in the Battle of Matapan in March 1941 when the Italian Fleet was defeated. 
On 25th November 1941 she was sunk off the Libyan coast by U-331 
The memorial is dedicated to all crew members of HMS Barham from entering service in 1915 until sinking on 25th November 1941: she served in both world wars. 
She was the fourth ship to be named HMS Barham after Charles Middleton, 1st Lord Barham (1726-1813). He was the 1st Lord of the Admiralty who gave Lord Nelson his orders when he sailed to join the fleet prior to the Battle of Trafalgar. 
HMS Barham was a Queen Elizabeth Class Battleship (27,500 tons) armed with 8 15-inch guns: she was launched on 31st December 1914 and entered service the following year. Most notably she was was part of the 5th Battle Squadron at the Battle of Jutland in 1916, when it was attached to Vice Admiral Beaty's Battle Cruiser Squadron. 
She saw extensive service in the first half of WW2 particularly with the Mediterranean Fleet under the command of Admiral Andrew B Cunningham and took part in the Battle of Matapan on 28th March 1941 when the Italian Fleet was defeated. 
On 25th November 1941 she was sunk off the Libyan coast by U-331: her commanding officer Captain Geoffrey Clement Cooke, 55 officers and 806 ratings were killed. There is a famous sequence of the sinking filmed by a Pathe cameraman aboard HMS Valiant: it is available on the internet.

name: HMS Bruce Memorial
description:
HMS Bruce
The grey polished memorial stone is dedicated to the Officers, Instructors, Men and Boy Seamen that served in HMS Bruce between 1947–1950. It contains the inscription “May they find safe haven”. 
The memorial was presented by the HMS Bruce Association

name: HMS Bulwark, Albion and Centaur Memorial
description:
H.M. Ships Bulwark, Albion, Centaur 
The memorial is in proud memory of the ships companies FAA Squadrons, Royal Marines and Embarked Forces H.M. Ships Bulwark, Albion, Centaur 1953-1981

name: HMS Caledonia Memorial
description:
HMS Caledonia Memorial 
HMS Caledonia was used for Artificer Apprentice training from 1937 to 1985. A stone memorial tablet containing the Caledonia insignia at the top includes the inscription: This tree is dedicated to all Caledonia trained Artificer Apprentices.

name: HMS Cavalier Memorial
description:
HMS Cavalier Memorial 
This memorial is dedicated to all those who served on the HMS Cavalier and was donated and erected by the HMS Cavalier Association. The insignia badge of the HMS Cavalier is displayed at the centre of the memorial. HMS Cavalier joined the 8th Destroyer Flotilla Home Fleet and quickly saw action. In February 1945 she took part in three operations off Norway. “Selenium”, a strike against enemy shipping, “Shred” to provide fighter cover for a minesweeping flotilla and “Groundsheet” an aircraft mine laying strike. 
Cavalier was one of three destroyers sent from Scapa to reinforce the escort of Artic Convoy RA64 which had left the Kola Inlet on 17th February. After being attacked by U-boats and enemy aircraft on 23 February the convoy was scattered in a hurricane combining force 12 winds with icing. Cavalier went to round up the convoy with the other escorts and on 1 March 31 of the 34 merchant ships arrived safely in Clyde. 
This mission earned HMS Cavalier a well deserved “Battle Honour” Arctic 44. 
HMS Cavalier is now preserved at the National Destroyer Memorial in The Historic Dockyard, Chatham.

name: HMS Charybdis & HMS Limbourne
description:
HMS CHARYBDIS AND HMS LIMBOURNE
The HMS Charybdis and HMS Limbourne Memorial remembers the 502 sailors, marines and crew who lost their lives when both ships were torpedoed by German destroyers and sunk in the English Channel in October 1943 during Operation Tunnel. 
Operation Tunnel was mounted when the Royal Navy gained intelligence the Germans would be moving a convoy along the Brittany coast on the night of 22nd/23rd October 1943. The cruiser HMS Charybdis accompanied six destroyers should have been a formidable force for the engagement, but it is thought that the German shore-based radar gave the enemy advance warning of the movements of the British ships. Although the Charybdis picked up the approach of enemy ships on her radar, it was too late to anticipate a joint torpedo attack by a group of German destroyers. 
The Charybdis was hit by a torpedo first, and the destroyer HMS Limbourne soon afterwards, both ships sank, and the German ships withdrew, undetected. 
The HMS Charybdis and HMS Limbourne Memorial remembers the 502 sailors, marines and crew who lost their lives when both ships were torpedoed by German destroyers and sunk in the English Channel near Guernsey on 23rd October 1943 during Operation Tunnel. 
Operation Tunnel was mounted when the Royal Navy gained intelligence the Germans would be moving a convoy along the Brittany coast on the night of the 22nd/23rd October 1943. The cruiser HMS Charybdis accompanied six destroyers should have been a formidable force for the engagement, but it is thought that the German shore-based radar gave the enemy advance warning of the movements of the British ships. Although the Charybdis picked up the approach of enemy ships on her radar, it was too late to anticipate a joint torpedo attack by a group of German destroyers. 
The Charybdis was hit by a torpedo first, and the destroyer HMS Limbourne soon afterwards, both ships sank, and the German ships withdrew, undetected.

name: HMS Cossack Memorial
description:
HMS Cossack Memorial 
There have been six ships bearing the name HMS Cossack. The fifth ship, HMS Cossack – LO3, was arguably the most famous of the 16 Tribal Class destroyers that served with the Royal Navy during the Second World War. 
As a large, heavily armed destroyer, HMS Cossack saw much action and was involved in the pursuit and sinking of the German battleship Bismarck in May 1941. On 23 October 1941, while escorting a convoy from Gibraltar to the United Kingdom, HMS Cossack was struck by a torpedo causing immense damage: 159 of her 219 crew were killed. She eventually sank on 27 October and survivors were picked up by HMS Legion, HMS Carnation and the Free French Ship Commandant. 
The memorial bench is dedicated to Shipmate George Toomey, the founder of the HMS Cossack Association, and to the memory of all those who served in the Cossacks. 
To the right of the memorial bench is the Cossack oak tree planted by the HMS Cossack Association in memory of the 159 officers and men who died in HMS Cossack 23 October 1941. The plaque commemorates all those who served in HM Ships Cossack 1938-1941 and 1945-1960.

name: HMS Dunedin Memorial
description:
HMS Dunedin
HMS Dunedin, a Danae-class light cruiser, was launched in 1918. During the 1920s and 1930s she served as part of the New Zealand Division of the Royal Navy, sailing around the Pacific. Returning to England in 1937, she served at Portsmouth as a Boys Sea Training Ship until August 1939 when she was allocated to the 12th Cruiser Squadron based on Kirkwall for service on the Northern Patrol. 
Dunedin spent time hunting for German battleships and during 1940 was operating in the Caribbean Sea intercepting German merchant ships. On 15 June 1941, the German tanker Lothringen was captured by HMS Dunedin, denying German U-Boats of vital oil supplies. Important, classified Engima material was also discovered aboard the tanker during its capture. 
On 24 November 1941, whilst steaming in the Central Atlantic Ocean, east of the St. Paul's Rocks, HMS Dunedin was torpedoed and sunk by the German submarine U-124. Of her 486 crew, only four officers and 63 men survived. 
The memorial to HMS Dunedin was unveiled on 26th July 2003 by the last four known survivors.

name: HMS Formidable Memorial
description:
HMS Formidable 
HMS Formidable was an Illustrious-class aircraft carrier (28,661 tons full load) that saw extensive service during the Second World War. She was commissioned on 24 November 1940.
HMS Formidable took part in the Battle of Cape Matapan on 27 March 1941. On 26 May 1941, she received serious damage while transporting aircraft to Malta, being hit by two 1000-kilogram bombs that put her out of action for six months. After repairs in the United States, she re-equipped with Vought Corsair and Martlet fighters.
In 1942, she travelled across the Pacific and served briefly in the Indian Ocean, returning to the Mediterranean in October. HMS Formidable then provided air support for the North African campaign and Italian campaign (1943), including the Allied invasion of Sicily, before taking part in an Arctic convoy. On 17 November aircraft from HMS Formidable attacked U-Boat U-331 (the U-Boat that sank HMS Barham) and sank her.
On 17 July 1944, Swordfish aircraft from HMS Formidable were involved in an attack on the Tirpitz in Norway and took part in further attacks on Tirpitz in August.
During 1945 she saw service against Japanese forces with British Pacific Fleet and survived several kamikaze attacks while supporting the landings on Okinawa. On 4 May a Japanese kamikaze plane crashed into the flight deck, making a massive dent about 10 feet long, two feet wide and two feet deep in the armoured flight deck. A large steel splinter ruptured a steam line, and came to rest in a fuel tank, starting a major fire in the aircraft park. Eight crew members were killed and forty-seven were wounded: the 3" armoured steel flight deck of HMS Formidable prevented further damage by Kamikaze attacks. By 5pm the fires were brought under control, the crater in the deck was repaired and Corsairs were again able to land on Formidable. A further Kamikaze hit HMS Formidable's flight deck on 9 May, but the level of damage was nowhere near as serious.
The accumulation of damage through the war took its toll on the ship. The bomb damage received in the Mediterranean had left her with damage that was beyond economical repair. She was placed in reserve in 1947 and was sold for scrap in 1953.
The blue plaque on the face of the stone memorial contains details of HMS Formidable’s Battle Honours and a reference to Lieutenant Robert Hampton Gray VC, DSC, RCNVR of 1841 Squadron - a Canadian naval officer, pilot, and posthumous recipient of the last Victoria Cross (VC) of the Second World War. Robert Hampton Gray is thought to be one of the last Canadians to die during the Second World War.
Located behind the main memorial to HMS Formidable is an oak tree which was planted by the HMS Formidable Association on 22 September 2001 and commemorates in tribute “all who served in and flew from this great ship”.

name: HMS Gambia Memorial
description:
HMS Gambia 
HMS Gambia was a Crown Colony-class light cruiser of the Royal Navy and has been the only ship of the Royal Navy to bear the name. 
She saw active service in the East Indies with the British Eastern Fleet, and in September 1942, was involved in the Battle of Madagascar. Following a refit, she participated in Operation Stonewall to intercept blockade runners off the west coast of France. 
From 1943 - 1946 she was in the service of the Royal New Zealand Navy (RNZN) as HMNZS Gambia. She later served with the Far East Fleet and in 1950 was assigned to the 2nd Cruiser Squadron in the Mediterranean. 
In 1955, she became flagship of the 4th Cruiser Squadron on the East Indies Station and from 1960 remained in reserve at Portsmouth. 
The memorial is dedicated to the memory of the men of the Royal New Zealand Navy and the Royal Navy who served in HMS Gambia during her eight commissions 1942 – 1960. It was donated by the HMS Gambia Association 7th May 2005.

name: HMS Ganges Memorial
description:
HMS GANGES 
HMS Ganges was established in 1905 as a Boy Seamans’ training school. It accepted boys between the ages of 15 and 16 ½ with the purpose of training them to be sailors fit to serve in His/Her Majesty's fleet. It was eventually closed in 1976 when initial training of all Naval Ratings transferred to HMS Raleigh in Cornwall. 
The HMS Ganges Association Memorial is located near to the Merchant Navy Convoy Wood. It comprises four cornerstones which represent the four countries of the United Kingdom from where the boys came. The stones are Cromar Lightning from Scotland, Plum Slate from Wales, Irish Quartzite from Ireland and Green Lakeland Slate from England. Each of the stones displays a carved national floral emblem: Scotland - Thistle, Wales - Daffodil, Ireland - Shamrock and England - Rose. 
The main central plinth is a piece of White Portland Stone onto which is carved the H.M.S. Ganges crest above the following dedication: 
This memorial is dedicated to the memory of all who passed through H.M.S Ganges at Shotley in Suffolk between the years 1905 and 1976." 
The memorial sits on a bed of green/blue shale, to represent the sea, which is enclosed within a course of Staffordshire Blue Bricks. 
Ganges was a Royal Navy Training Establishment at Shotley Gate near Ipswich for boys aged 15 and 16. It provided a tough regime involving education, (maths, English, navigation and naval history), physical education and parade ground drill. 
Between its establishment in 1905 and closure in 1976 around 160,000 recruits passed through its gates and it was often referred to as "the establishment that fed the fleet".

name: HMS Glory Memorial
description:
HMS Glory 
The memorial is dedicated to all who served on the Light Fleet Carrier HMS Glory between 1944 - 1957 and to those who lost their lives during that service. It was unveiled on 6 October 2007.

name: HMS Hood Memorial
description:
HMS Hood Memorial 
HMS Hood, named after the 18th Century Admiral Samuel Hood, was commissioned in 1920 and was the last battlecruiser built for the Royal Navy. For many years she was considered the largest and most powerful warship in the world - her prestige being reflected in the nickname "The Mighty Hood". 
HMS Hood was sunk in action with the German Battleship Bismarck in the Denmark Strait off Greenland on 24 May 1941. 
The memorial, which was dedicated on 25 October 2008, is of grey polish granite and displays HMS Hood’s crest, a Cornish Chough holding a gold anchor, which is based on elements of Lord Samuel Hood’s coat of arms. It is dedicated to the memory of the 1415 officers and ratings who died including 24 Commonwealth, 4 Polish Midshipmen and 5 Free French Sailors. Only 3 of the ship’s company survived. 
In 2015, the ship’s bell was recovered from the wreck of HMS Hood and conserved. It had been the expressed wish of Ted Briggs, one of the only three survivors, for this to be recovered as a memorial to his shipmates

name: HMS Kenya Memorial
description:
HMS Kenya Memorial
HMS Kenya was a Crown Colony-class cruiser of the Royal Navy. Commissioned in 1940, she saw action during the Second World War hunting for the German battleship Bismarck in May 1941 and as part of Operation Stonewall, to intercept U-boats. She later took part in naval operations during the Korean War. 
The memorial, by the HMS Kenya Association, is dedicated to the comradeship and memory of the officers and men who served aboard HMS Kenya in times of war and peace from 1940-1962. 
The memorial is a light grey granite plinth displaying the name and an outline drawing of HMS Kenya on the front. On top of the plinth a polished black granite tablet is inscribed with a dedication and a list of battle honours reflecting her years of active service..

name: HMS Neptune and Kandahar Memorial
description:
HMS Neptune and HMS Kandahar 
In December 1941, the destroyer HMS Kandahar and the cruiser HMS Neptune were sunk by mines in the Mediterranean with a loss of over 800 lives. 
The tragedy ranks among the heaviest crew losses experienced in any naval theatre of the Second World War and was the second most substantial loss of life suffered by the Royal Navy in the whole of the Mediterranean campaign. 
At 0300 on the 19th December the cruisers HMS Neptune (Captain Rory Chambers O’Connor), HMS Aurora (Captain William G Agnew CB) and HMS Penelope (Captain Angus Nichol DSO) and the destroyers Kandahar (Commander William Geoffrey Arthur Robson DSO, DSC), Lance (Lt-Commander R W F Northcott), Havok (Lt-Commander G R G Watkins DSC) and Lively (Lt-Commander W F E Hussey DSC) , the combined Forces B and K, steamed into a newly laid Italian minefield and HMS Neptune hit two mines and then while attempting to go astern hit a third. HMS Aurora and HMS Penelope also struck mines. HMS Kandahar attempted to pass a tow to the Neptune and struck a mine and had her stern blown off. Captain O’Conner warned all ships to stand clear. HMS Neptune sank later with the loss of all but one of her 765 crew; 150 were from New Zealand. 
On 20th December HMS Jaguar (Lt-Commander Lionel Rupert Tyrwhitt DSC) saved all but 91 of the crew of HMS Kandahar and then torpedoed the hulk. On 24th December, Able Seaman John Norman Walton, the only survivor from HMS Neptune was picked up by an Italian ship after spending 5 ½ days on a Carley raft. 
The pyramid shaped memorial is positioned so that it aligns with the position off the coast of Libya where the wreck of HMS Neptune lies. 
Concealed within the stone is a roll of honour of the 837 men who died and a painting of the sky as it was on the night of the sinking.

name: HMS Prince of Wales and HMS Repulse Memorial
description:
HMS PRINCE OF WALES AND REPULSE 
The Destruction of Force Z – The Sinking of HMS Prince of Wales and HMS Repulse in the South China Sea by the Japanese 22nd Air Flotilla. 
HMS Prince of Wales was a George V Class Battleship built by Cammell Laird, Birkenhead and commissioned in March 1941. She displaced 35,000 tons and had a main armament of 10 14 inch guns. 
She participated in the pursuit of the German Battleship Bismark and was struck 7 times during the battle resulting in the loss of 14 men. In August 1941, HMS Prince of Wales transported Sir Winston Churchill to meet Franklin D Roosevelt at Placenta Bay, Newfoundland where they created the Atlantic Charter. 
HMS Repulse was a Renown Class Battle Cruiser built by John Browns, Clydebank. She displaced 30,370 tons and had a main armament of 6 15-inch guns. 
She was commissioned in August 1916. She took part in the Battle of Heligoland Bight, was involved in refugee work at the outbreak of the Spanish War and in 1940 operated out of Norway and was on convoy duties until July 1941.

name: HMS Royal Arthur Memorial
description:
HMS Royal Arthur 
This polished grey stone obelisk shaped memorial is dedicated to all the men and women who entered service in the Royal Navy at HMS Royal Arthur at the former “Butlins Holiday Camp” Skegness between 1939 - 1945 and to all the officers and ratings who passed through HMS Royal Arthur, Corsham, Wiltshire in the years 1945 – 1993.
A gold naval anchor is inscribed in the memorial’s pyramidal top below which is the badge of HMS Royal Arthur displayed in blue and gold.
The inscription below includes a dedication remembering all HMS Royal Arthur shipmates who have ‘crossed the bar’ (a naval term used when comrades have passed away which is taken from Tennyson’s

name: HMS Sheffield
description:
HMS SHEFFIELD 
HMS Sheffield was a Type 42 guided missile destroyer and the second Royal Navy ship to be named after the city of Sheffield in Yorkshire. Commissioned on 16 February 1975 the Sheffield was part of the Task Force 317 sent to the Falkland Islands.
