On May 4 1982, the 4,100-ton destroyer was struck by a missile fired from an Argentine fighter bomber as it carried out a scouting mission off the Falklands - which Argentina had invaded and claimed as their own weeks earlier. 
The ship caught fire when a French-made Exocet missile hit HMS Sheffield and went deep into its control room. 
The blaze caused a poisonous smoke to be released and most of the crew abandoned ship. 
The “Shiny Sheff” 
The Shiny Sheff memorial honours the service of all those who served in the three ships of that name over 65 years and the 20 members of the Ship’s Company killed in action during the Falklands Conflict in 1982: 
The Cruiser (C24) 1937-67. World War 11 service 
The Destroyer (D80) 1970-82. Gulf and Falklands conflict 
The Frigate (F96) 1986-2002. Gulf. Awarded the Wilkinson Sword of Peace 
In 2020 with the 40th anniversary of the Falklands Conflict rapidly approaching the HMS SHEFFIELD Association agreed that a memorial should be placed at the National Memorial Arboretum to honour all those who served in the three ships of that name and that there should also be a place of remembrance for the 20 men lost when the second vessel of the name was damaged in action on the 4th of May 1982. In the spring of 2021, the artist Peter Naylor was commissioned to design a memorial which reflected all three ships and their close association with the city of Sheffield and its industries. The City of Sheffield Master Cutler was approached for assistance in making the memorial. The fabrication of the memorial was led by William Cook steel casting and supported by Tinsley Bridge, Outokumpu, and Charles Day Steels. The Association are extremely proud that their memorial was made of stainless steel by skilled craftsmen in the city of Sheffield. The memorial consists of a stainless-steel bow of a warship set in a stainless steel base, within in the deconstructed cruiser’s crest. The circular crest on the top of the memorial represents both destroyer and frigate. 
Materials Used 
Sheffield Stainless steel cast and sheet 
The memorial was constructed in January to April 2022 with ground-breaking in April 2022, it was unveiled by Mrs Penny Salt, widow of Captain Sam Salt, the Commanding Officer of the Destroyer HMS SHEFFIELD during the Falklands conflict. Mrs Salt consecrated the memorial on the 4th of May 2022 with a bottle of sea water collected in the South Atlantic by HMS Forth. 
Symbolism 
Positioned close to the South Atlantic Memorial and the corner of the Naval Field the memorial links the South Atlantic conflict with the large part played in that conflict by the Royal Navy and supporting Maritime services. 
The design of the memorial and its manufacture in stainless steel proudly links all three ships with the City of Sheffield and its world-famous steel industries. When they were constructed all three warships were presented with ship’s bells and fittings of stainless steel made in Sheffield. 
The memorial represents a warship at speed as it cuts through a dull grey sea during operations. The sea is set in the deconstructed pentagonal crest of the cruiser which links the second world war generation of sailors to the modern era. 
The warship crest on the top of the memorial takes the sheaf of arrows from the city of Sheffield Coat of Arms. The sheaf of arrows is a wordplay on the river Sheaf which runs through Sheffield and is also a reference to the iron and steel making heritage of the city.

name: HMT Lancastria Memorial
description:
THE HMT LANCASTRIA 
HMT Lancastria a troopship, which was sunk off the coast of France, near St Nazaire, in June 1940. Lancastria was carrying both service personnel and civilians; it is unknown how many were on board at the time but some estimates are up 9,000. This was such a catastrophe that that Churchill ordered a “D Notice” - a total news blackout - for fear of the damage this may do to the country's morale. 
In WW2 many ocean-going pleasure liners were requisitioned by the British Government to support the war effort. 
HMT Lancastria's capacity was 1,300 passengers, it was deployed to St Nazaire, France, to assist in the evacuation of British Nationals and troops from France, two weeks after Dunkirk. 
On the 17 June 1940 it was agreed to load 3,000 onto the ship but that number increased during the boarding, estimated between 5,000 and 9,000. 
The Captain of Lancastria could have left port around 14:00 but the RN destroyer which was to escort it had been bombed by the Germans. 
So Lancastria's Captain decided to wait for an escort. Index 
Unfortunately, while waiting, a fresh air raid began at around 16:00 and Lancastria was hit by three or possibly four bombs. 
A number of survivors reported that one of the bombs had gone down the ships only funnel causing the ship to sink quickly - around 15-20 minutes. 
Opinions differ on actual loss of life but the general consensus is at least 3,000, up to around 7,000. 
A simple stone memorial is located in front of the ‘Lancastria Oak’ within the Merchant Navy Woodland, bearing a circular plaque inscribed with the Lancastria Association badge and emblem. 
The story of the Lancastria is little known but represents the biggest disaster in British maritime history. 
On 17 June 1940, the 16,000-ton Cunard liner Lancastria lay five miles off St Nazaire embarking troops, RAF personnel and civilian refugees, including women and children, who were being evacuated from France, which was then on the point of collapse. The exact number of people on board may never be known, but almost certainly exceeded 6,000; some estimates were as high as 9,000. 
The Lancastria was attacked and hit by bombs from German aircraft. The ship sank rapidly and, according to the estimate of the Commanding Officer, Captain Rudolf Sharpe, only around 2,500 of those on board were saved. 
Due to the scale of the tragedy and in the interests of public morale (this also being the day that the French government decided to seek an armistice with Nazi Germany), Winston Churchill forbade publication of the news at the time, hence the story of the Lancastria has never been generally known, although it is Britain’s worst maritime disaster. 
Since the Second World War, the Lancastria Association and Lancastria Association of Scotland have established memorials to the victims and carry out remembrance services every year.

name: Home Front Memorial
description: HOME FRONT MEMORIAL Map The term "home front" covers the activities of the civilians in a nation at war. World War II was a total war; homeland production and sustainability became even more invaluable. Life on the home front during World War II was a significant part of the war effort for all participants and had a major impact on the outcome of the war. Governments became involved with new issues such as rationing, manpower allocation, home defence, evacuation in the face of air raids, and response to occupation by an enemy power.

name: Hong Kong Volunteer Defence Corps Memorial
description:
HONG KONG VOLUNTEER DEFENCE CORPS 
The light grey plaque belongs to the Hong Kong Volunteer Defence Corps, formed in 1854 and consisting of infantry, artillery, engineers, medical and other trades. During WW2 the corps numbered over 2,000 volunteers. They stood down in 1945.

name: Hunt Class Destroyers Memorial
description:
HUNT CLASS DESTROYERS
The Hunt Class Destroyers were designed as convoy escorts with anti-aircraft capabilities. They were completed between 1940 and 1942; of the 86 completed 14 were transferred to other Allied Navies. Between them they sank 5 Italian submarines and 16 German U-boats. 
The plaque on the memorial lists all ships by name with a separate list for the 25 sunk in date of loss order: details of the circumstances and location of the loss are also given.

name: Inner Wheel Grove
description:
THE INNER WHEEL GARDEN
The Inner wheel was founded in Manchester on 10 January 1924. This date is now celebrated as World Inner Wheel Day
Many of its members are female spouses, partners and relatives of Rotary International Members
The design of the grove is based on the Inner Wheel badge
The entrance to the grove was enhanced by the erection of wrought iron gates, which were dedicated in March 2009.
The motto of the Inner Wheel is “Service and Friendship”
The Inner Wheel is one of the largest women’s international voluntary organisations in the world

name: Intelligence Corps Memorial
description:
INTELLIGENCE CORPS 
The monolith is a memorial to those who served in the Intelligence Corps.
This British Army unit was originally formed in 1914. It is responsible for collecting, analysing and disseminating military intelligence and also for counter-intelligence and security.
The corps’ personnel are engaged in a range of activities, including analysing human intelligence, signals and image intelligence, electronic warfare, counter-intelligence, field security, carrying out interrogations and dealing with cyber threats.
Members of the corps have taken part in most of the Army's deployments since 1945.
The motto translates to ‘knowledge gives strength to the arm’. The roses (‘Cognito’), inspired by the motto and the badge, were specially commissioned for the memorial.

name: Irish Infantry Grove
description:
IRISH INFANTRY GROVE 
Large oak tree is from a stand of oaks which was one of the few species in Ireland to survive the Ice Age. 
During WW1 over 250,000 Irishmen volunteered to fight for the British Army. Thousands lost their lives, on the Menin Gate alone hundreds are recorded. 
The garden itself was consecrated in 2000 and commemorates all who have served and continue to serve. The original idea for this garden was to create an acre of Ireland in the heart of the British Isles. The paved map of Ireland commemorates each of the Irish regiments. 
In WW1 37 VCs were awarded. In WW2 8 VCs were awarded. 
The youngest ever recorded British soldier to have died was an Irish lad named John Condon, aged 14yrs. He died on 24 May 1915 at the 2nd battle of Ypres and is buried at the Commonwealth War Graves Commission cemetery at Poelkapelle. On his stone it clearly states his age as 14 years. 
All the trees and shrubs in the garden are of Irish origin. The tree in the corner is taken from a stand of oak in Northern Ireland, one of the few trees said to have survived through the ice age 10,000 years ago.

name: Italy Star Association 1943 - 1945
description:
ITALIAN STAR 
This memorial recognises the achievements and sacrifices of the British Forces fighting in Italy in WW2.

name: Japanese Hell Ships Memorial
description:
Hell Ships
The second cairn lists the names of the 26 Japanese merchant ships carrying prisoners of war and/or civilians on what became known as ‘HELL SHIPS’, that were sunk by Allied action with the loss of more than 19,000 lives. It includes the Suez Maru, giving a figure of 546 casualties which includes those who were other than British (mostly Dutch). The wooden crosses around the edge give the location of military

name: Kenya Police Memorial
description:
Kenya Police Memorial
Although the bench, tree and plaques were dedicated on 20th October 2004, the memorial itself was dedicated on 7th June 2015 to remember all ranks who served in the Kenya Police and Kenya Police Reserve up to the year 1963, when Kenya was granted independence from Britain. 
The memorial consists of a 6 feet tall obelisk of black Indian marble whichhighlights significant events in the history of the force. The photographs etched on the memorial depict various aspects of their work including air patrols as shown by the aircraft flying past Mount Kenya. 
On 10th August 2022 a Hexahedral Stone plinth (also of black Indian marble)was placed in front of the memorial: on it is the Kenya Police insignia (bronze) which was originally installed above the force headquarters in Nairobi. It was returned tothe UK after Kenya gained independence.

name: King's African Rifles Memorial
description:
KING’S AFRICAN RIFLES 
To its left is the memorial for the KING’s AFRICAN RIFLES, whose origins date back to the 1890s. Their first major battle was against the ‘MAD MULLAH’ in Somaliland, which lasted from 1900 – 1920. They also fought the British side in both World Wars but were disbanded in 1964 as their home African countries had by that time gained independence from Britain.

name: King's Royal Hussars Memorial
description:
King’s Royal Hussars Memorial 
Dedicated to mark the 300th anniversary of the rising of the earliest antecedent regiments, the Light Dragoons and the Prince of Wales’s Own Hussars. The regiment and its antecedent regiments have taken part in many wars and campaigns over 300 years including the Duke of Wellington’s Peninsular War, the Indian Mutiny, the Boer War and both World Wars. It was during the Battle of Vitoria (June 1813) that the Duchess of York’s Own Light Dragoons captured a silver chamberpot belonging to Joseph Bonaparte (brother of the Emperor) and as a result acquired the nickname 'The Emperor’s Chambermaids'. The o›cers still drink from the pot on mess nights.

name: King's Shropshire Light Infantry Memorial (KLSI)
description:
KING’S SHROPSHIRE LIGHT INFANTRY 
The KSLI was officially formed in 1881, although the regiment can trace its roots back to 1755. The colourful memorial depicts the Regiment’s colours and battle honours, along with the bugle cap badge.

name: Kingfisher Wood
description:
Kingfisher Wood 
The Kingfisher Wood is a mixed woodland of individually dedicated native trees. It is named after the kingfishers seen flying along the nearby riverbank.

name: Kohima Tennis Court
description: Kohima Tennis Court

name: L/Cpl Kevin 'Dinger' Bell Memorial
description:
L Cpl Kevin “Dinger” Bell REME 
A small memorial to the right of the nearby Royal Electrical and Mechanical Engineers (REME) Memorial remembers Lance Corporal Kevin ‘Dinger’ Bell from REME who was killed in Bosnia. It originally marked the spot in Bosnia where he died but was brought back to the United Kingdom when troops pulled out.

name: Ladysmith Memorial
description:
Ladysmith Memorial 
The Ladysmith Memorial was commissioned on 21 October 2012 and is dedicated to all “Field Gunners” from the Boer War through to the present day. 
Ladysmith, South Africa, 15 October 1899 - under heavy fire, General Sir George White defending the town of Ladysmith, requested a few guns in support from the Naval contingent in Simonstown. The request found Captain Percy Scott RN in Simons Bay. His crew had, in 24 hours, prepared two 4.7-inch guns and four 12-pounders for land warfare. Under the command of Captain Hedworth Lambton RN, the Naval Brigade set out over land for Ladysmith. Crews from HMS Powerful and HMS terrible were formed for this task. 
After oxen failed to haul the guns across the rough terrain, only one option was left. The Naval Brigade (Bluejackets) had to haul the guns by muscle power themselves and still managed to arrive within 48 hours. Soon after their arrival at Ladysmith the siege of 119 days began. More men from the ships set out with more guns of both 4.7” and 12-pounders with a six in monster called “ROMA”. 
The Determination, Teamwork and Dedication of the Bluejackets captured the public’s hearts back home and, on the ships, return the Naval Brigades were to be paraded. This was so popular that the following year a tournament was staged at the 1900 Military Tournament at the Royal Agricultural Hall in Islington, London. The Field Gun Competition was born. 
Later the Royal Tournament moved to Olympia and then to Earl’s Court. Earl’s Court became the home to the Command Field Gun Competition with crews from the ports of Chatham (CHATS), Devonport (GUZZ), Portsmouth (POMPEY) and Fleet Air Arm (Air), who joined much later in 1947. In 1919 a set of rules was agreed and has fundamentally remained the same until the demise in 1999.

name: Leonard Cheshire Amphitheatre
description:
SIR LEONARD CHESHIRE AMPHITHEATRE 
Group Captain Sir Leonard Cheshire was a WW2 ace and was awarded the VC, OM, DSO & two Bars, DFC and Mentioned in Despatches. 
He was Group Captain when he joined 617 Squadron, famously known as the Dambusters, as its Commander 
After the war he was heavily involved in charity work and set up a charity with his wife Sue Ryder, called The Ryder-Cheshire Foundation. 
Sir Leonard was instrumental in starting a germ of an idea for the NMA. A conversation took place in the late 80's between Sir Leonard and Commander David Childs and both were concerned that we, as a country were beginning to forget to remember the sacrifice that so many made for us. 
From that conversation came a germ of an idea for some kind of a National Centre of Remembrance, which David Childs saw through to fruition.

name: Leyton Orient Somme
description:
Leyton Orient Somme
The O’s Somme Memorial honours the service and sacrifice of the 41 players, staŽ, club o›cials and supporters of Clapton Orient Football Club (now Leyton Orient FC) in the First World War. It is the first Memorial to commemorate a football club at the National Memorial Arboretum, which is very apt as Clapton Orient were the first English Football League club to enlist en masse into the British Army. They joined the 17th Battalion Middlesex Regiment, which was later to become known as ‘The Footballers’ Battalion’. The football and boots are reminiscent of that time.

name: Lichfield and District Garden
description:
LICHFIELD AND DISTRICT GARDEN
The seat with a canopy represents the three spires of Lichfield Cathedral 
Arranged around the seat is a planting of trees, one for each parish with the Lichfield District 
The trees were sponsored by each parish

name: Lichfield Wood
description:
Lichfield Wood 
The mix of native trees in the City of Lichfield Wood includes species relating to districts of the city such as The Cherry Orchard. Many of the trees have been sponsored by local groups and individuals associated with the Lichfield District area.

name: Life Guards Memorial
description:
Life Guards Memorial
The Life Guards the memorial, together with the Blues and Royals Memorial, is part of the memorial to the Household Cavalry Regiments. It was placed on site in 2016 and is dedicated to The Life Guards Regiment which was founded in 1660. 
The memorial was officially dedicated on 28 September 2017 by Field Marshal The Lord Guthrie of Craigiebank GCB LVO OBE DL Colonel of the Life Guards. 
Two black polished granite stones slabs, each bearing the badge of The Life Guards and The Blues and Royals respectively mark the entrance to the memorial garden.

name: Light Dragoons Memorial
description:
Light Dragoons 
The Light Dragoons were formed by the amalgamation in 1992 of the 13th/18th Royal Hussars and 15th.19th Kings Royal Hussars. The earliest of their ancestor regiments can be dated to 1715. The regiment has seen service in many campaigns including Waterloo in 1815, Crimea (including the Charge of the Light Brigade in 1854), WW1, WW2 (including the Normandy Landings in 1944) and more recently served in Iraq and Afghanistan. 
An outline of the antecedent regiments and amalgamations is shown below. 
Light Dragoons 1992 
13th/18th Royal Hussars (Queen Mary’s Own) 1922 
13th Hussars 1861 
Light Dragoons 1715 
18th Royal Hussars (Queen Mary’s Own) 1919 
18th (Queen Mary’s Own) Hussars 1910 
18th Hussars 1858 
15th/19th King’s Royal Hussars 1922 
15th King’s Hussars 
King’s Hussars 1759 
19th (Queen Alexandra’s Own Royal) Hussars 1908 
19th Hussars formerly 1st Bengal European Light Cavalry (H.E.I.C.) 1862 
HEIC means the Honourable East India Company.

name: Light Infantry (The Rifles) Memorial
description:
LIGHT INFANTRY 
This Portland stone monolith and adjacent benches are ‘In proud memory of all who served in the Light Infantry’. The 8 regiments represented on the two benches formed the Light Infantry in 1968 (refer to the neighbouring DLI and KSLI memorials). At one time, the Light Infantry was the largest infantry regiment in the British Army.
In 2007, the Light Infantry became part of a new larger regiment, The Rifles, which still retains the bugle cap badge featured on the stone monolith.
The Colonels-in-Chief of the Rifles, the Paras, the Intelligence Corps, and REME are the Queen Consort, King Charles lll, the Princess Royal, and the Countess of Wessex respectively.

name: Lions Club International Shelter
description:
Lions International (Shelter No 4)
The Lions is a charitable organisation dedicated to serving local, national and international communities. The memorial is a shelter dedicated to the memory of Lions from Great Britain and Ireland in grateful thanks for their service.
Opened on 14 September 2011, by HRH The Countess of Wessex, Royal Patron of the Lions Clubs of the British Isles and a member of Wokingham Lions Club, this shelter provides a place to reflect on how much ordinary people can do when they work together.
There are millions of volunteer Lions Clubs members around the world who are working hard to improve their local communities. They do this by raising money for good causes, as well as supporting international campaigns, helping those less fortunate and having fun by organising all kinds of activities.
Before their 2017 centenary, Lions Clubs everywhere adopted the message: “Where there’s a need, there’s a Lion” and took on a challenge to serve 100 million people.
The Lions shelter also features details on memorials from the Woodland Zone including the First Gulf War 1990-1991, the Society of Friends (Quakers) and the Merchant Navy Convoy Wood.
The featured hands-on elements include an original Second World War ship’s wheel and bell. The Memorial Stone Masons feature includes original mason’s tools and a section of stone worked from rough hewn rock to the finished inscription.
Views of the Merchant Navy Convoy Wood are enjoyed from this shelter.

name: Lisbon Maru
description:
LISBON MARU
The Lisbon Maru Memorial was erected in memory of the 828 victims who died in one of the worst war crimes perpetrated by the Japanese during World War Two. British prisoners of war captured at the fall of Hong Kong were being transported to Japan to work as slaves. After their ship was torpedoed the Japanese rescued their own troops but locked the POWs in the holds leaving them to drown, and shot at those who managed to break out. In 1942 the Japanese began sending POWs from their captured territories to Japan to work as slave labour in various industries so as to free up the workforce to be enlisted into the armed forces. The second shipment of POWs from Hong Kong was on the Lisbon Maru. On 27 September 1942 the Lisbon Maru, a Japanese armed freighter with Japanese troops on board, sailed from Hong Kong bound for Japan. It also carried 1,816 British prisoners of war held in atrocious conditions. Cramped, airless, and in unimaginable squalor they were incarcerated below deck in three cargo holds. The freighter bore no markings to indicate their presence. On 1 October an American submarine, the USS Grouper, on patrol off the Zhoushan archipelago in the East China Sea, engaged the Lisbon Maru holing it below the waterline with a torpedo. Although initially taken under tow, the line snapped and the ship drifted and foundered. The Japanese evacuated their troops, battened down the hatches over the holds and left a guard force to prevent the prisoners from escaping. For 24 hours the prisoners were held in sub-human conditions in darkness with no food, water, fresh air or sanitation; and dysentery was rife. There was a breakout before the ship sank the next day and many of the prisoners of war escaped from the two forward holds, some of whom were cut down by machine-gun fire. Most of those in the third hold, by then below the waterline, tragically drowned. Those who did escape were shot at in the water as they attempted to swim to the shore; many were killed or wounded but local Chinese fishermen courageously rescued 384 of the survivors. Later, the Japanese recaptured all but three.
Of the original 1,816 men on board 828 died in this terrible atrocity and a further 200 or more succumbed from their sufferings within a few months.

name: Liverpool Scottish
description:
THE LIVERPOOL SCOTTISH 
Founded in 1859 as a volunteer force sponsored by the Highland Society of London. They have seen action in both WWs and conflicts since. They now form part of The London Regiment, one of their nicknames "Cockney Jocks". Interestingly from 1953-2002 the Pipe Major of The London Scottish held the prestigious position of "Piper to the Queen Mother". 
Known as ‘The Scottish’, the regiment was raised in 1900 as an infantry battalion of the King’s (Liverpool Regiment) and later affiliated with the Queens own Cameron Highlanders, hence the name 'Liverpool Scottish'. The most decorated member was Captain NG Chavasse VC & Bar, who was awarded a VC for saving the lives of some twenty badly wounded men in no-mans land at Guillemont in WW I, his plaque can be seen in the RAMC Avenue. The Liverpool Scottish lineage came to an end, on 30 April 2014, when the last surviving platoon was disbanded, and personnel re-affiliated entirely to the Duke of Lancaster's Regiment. The memorial was dedicated in July 2022.

name: Loch Class Frigates Memorial
description:
LOCH CLASS FRIGATES CAIRN  
The memorial is dedicated to the men of the Ship’s Companies who served the Loch Class Frigates and their variants in the North Atlantic, Artic, India (Burma) and Pacific Oceans during the Second World War and in all spheres until 1970. 
The circular stone memorial, resembling a cairn, is finished with stones from each of the 28 named Scottish Lochs. 
The ships remembered here were named after Scottish Lochs. A stone brought from each of the named lochs has been built into the cairn next to the stone for the ship that was named after it. 
A frigate is a small warship; in WW2 mainly used against submarines. A Corvette is rather smaller and was used mainly to protect merchant ship convoys.

name: LST and Landing Craft Memorial
description:
The L.S.T. and Landing Craft Association Memorial 
Landing Ship, Tank (LST), or tank landing ships were built during the Second World War to support amphibious operations by carrying tanks, vehicles and cargo and landing troops directly on to shore. As their unique design meant that they could provide amphibious assaults to any beach they were used extensively around the world in both the European and Pacific theatres. 
The L.S.T. and Landing Craft Association Memorial is dedicated to all those who served in or in support of Landing Ships and Landing Craft especially those who gave their lives in service of their country.

name: Malaya and Borneo Veterans Memorial
description:
MALAYA AND BORNEO VETERANS’ MEMORIAL
This memorial is dedicated to the many thousands of men who fought in Malaysia, Borneo, Singapore and Brunei. The large granite stone is expected to last 2000 years, providing a lasting memorial to the estimated 30,000 men who fought in the Second World War, the Malayan Emergency, the Confrontation and further conflicts in southeast Asia. It is intended as a place of quiet reflection for thousands of men and their families, remembering those who made the ultimate sacrifice and those who have departed subsequent to the end of hostilities.

name: Malayan Volunteer Force Memorial
description:
ALAY VOLUNTEER FORCE MEMORIAL
The Malayan Volunteers Group, mostly children of volunteers with some veterans, was formed in 2005 to commemorate and raise awareness of the Malayan volunteers in the Malayan Campaign and captivity 1941 – 1945. Some 18,000 volunteers of different races and creeds served in the Malayan Volunteer Forces, Medical Auxiliary Service and Observer Corps, receiving 100 Campaign Awards. In captivity, they contributed practical and medical skills, knowledge of local languages and secret radios, saving lives and giving hope of victory. Others taught in ‘Changi University’.

name: Masonic Masons (Freemasons) Memorial
description:
FREEMASONS 
Freemasonry is an ancient tradition dating back several hundred years. The garden contains much symbolism the main points being: 
Chequered pavement represents the lights and darks, joys and sorrows of life. 
The rough ashlar (stone) represents man passing over the chequered pavement adopting the principles of love, relief and truth becoming much improved, represented by the smooth ashlar. 
Square & compasses within circle. Square – desire to fulfil life by square and honest conduct – compass that this desire should be exercised throughout the circle of our lives. 
Round balls and pillars – celestial and celestial globes which symbolises that freemasonry has no boundaries. Walls acknowledge ancient art of stonemasons.

name: Master Mariners Sundial
description:
Master Mariners Sundial 
The 20 foot (six metre) diameter ‘human’ sundial was designed by Christopher St J H Daniel and placed in situ by Mark Frith in Dunhouse stone and blue Elterwater slate. 
The dial represents an oval outline chart of the world and the shadow of a person standing on the date scale indicates Greenwich Mean Time (GMT) on the surrounding numbers. So, to get the correct and very accurate time, stand on the appropriate month, add seven minutes (the difference in time between GMT and the Alrewas time) and in the summer add the extra hour. 
It was presented by the Honourable Company of Master Mariners and dedicated in 2001 to commemorate the loss of 2,535 ships of the Merchant Navy and the 32,000 merchant seamen who gave their lives in the Second World War.

name: Mediterranean Campaigns of World War 2
description:
MEDITERRANEAN CAMPAIGNS OF WW2 GARDEN 
The Mediterranean Grove is laid out geographically, at the far side we have the North African coastline where we remember the 1st and 8th Armies. A stone memorial for the famous Rats of Tobruk, who endured one of the longest sieges in British and Commonwealth military history. Palestine, Malta, Cyprus, Palestinian Police and Monte Cassino. Italy giving the boot to Sicily is planted with Black Pines, each one linked to a major battle of the Italian Campaign.

name: Memorial Rose Garden
description: Memorial Rose Garden

name: Merchant Navy Association Memorial
description:
MERCHANT NAVY ASSOCIATION
Although there had been merchant vessels throughout history, at the end of WW1, in recognition of their service, King George V bestowed the title Merchant Navy on them. 
The title "Master of the Merchant Navy and Fishing Fleets" is held by the reigning Monarch. 
The Merchant Navy Association (MNA) was formed in 1989. Its purpose is to ensure the welfare of both serving and former Merchant Navy personnel. 
This memorial, dedicated on the 1 October 2003, represents past and present Merchant Navy personnel. The memorial stone came from a Cornish quarry. The white seams in the rock represent the sea washing over the rocks ashore.

name: Merchant Navy Convoy Wood
description:
The Merchant Navy Convoy Wood 
The Merchant Navy Convoy Wood is dedicated to over 46,000 British merchant seafarers and fishermen lost in conflict during the 20th century, including two World Wars, Falklands, Kuwait, Vietnam, Iran, Iraq and others. 
During the Second World War, 31,908 seafarers perished, proportionately more than any of the Armed Services. 
Originally the wood had 2,535 trees, each representing a British vessel lost at that time; the number of trees has been significantly reduced by the need to thin out the wood as the trees matured. Oak was the material originally used for building ships. Additionally, the wood was planted with bluebells to represent the sea. 
The ships cargoes included food, troops, armaments, ammunition and fuel carried to the United Kingdom and every theatre of war. The seafarers were civilians who faced the enemy and the sea with equal bravery and courage, to keep the supply lines open to Britain and its allies.

name: Mercian Volunteers Memorial
description:
Mercian Volunteers 
The Mercian Volunteers Regimental Association created the Mercian Grove in 2004 with four oak saplings and a stone memorial. 
It commemorates all those regular and Territorial Army (TA) soldiers who served with Mercian Volunteers and its constituent units between 1967 and 1988. 
For 21 years, its battalions were part of the British Army’s contribution to NATO during the Cold War and had a specific role in Germany. Its direct successor is the 4th Battalion The Mercian Regiment. Private Luke Cole, one of its TA soldiers, was awarded the Military Cross in 2007 whilst serving in Afghanistan.

name: Mercian Wood
description:
Mercian Wood 
Mercian Wood is a mixed woodland of native broadleaf tree species containing individual dedications.

name: Mesothelioma UK
description:
Mesothelioma UK - Supporting our Armed Forces
In memory of members of the UK armed forces who have been diagnosed with the asbestos-related cancer, mesothelioma. Mesothelioma is a cancer caused by asbestos that affects around 2,700 people in the UK each year. A number of those diagnosed are, or were, serving members of the Armed Forces. As part of a Government-funded project, national charity, Mesothelioma UK supported research into the effects of mesothelioma within our armed forces. Findings from the research informed the development of the charity’s UK-wide specialist service for armed forces personnel and veterans who have been affected by mesothelioma. As part of the project, the charity wanted to create a memorial to honour those who have lost their lives to the disease or are living with it. The memorial depicts building blocks of life, engraved with information about mesothelioma, asbestos and our Armed Forces. 
Materials Used
Ancaster Weatherbed limestone
Name of Designers
Graeme Mitcheson M.M.R.S.
Age of Memorial
The construction began in spring 2023. A dedication ceremony is due to be held in October 2023.
Symbolism and meaning
The building blocks of life are represented by solid blocks of carved stone, constructed in a format not dissimilar to the game Jenga. The sculpture shows that even though the tower of blocks has been damaged in the middle, it is strongly supported above and below. This represents the aims of the charity. In addition to the tall tower of blocks. Each face will have carved across the surface of the stone, an inscription that describes both the aims of Mesothelioma UK and details of the disease. Some of the sections are slightly jumbled as the blocks have collapsed. The inscriptions are designed in such a way that the viewer is compelled to study the jumbled words and to try to rearrange the sentences in their heads, all the time learning a little about the charity and about mesothelioma. The Memorial has been created to allow families and friends of those affected to be able to visit the memorial and pay their respects or celebrate a key milestone.

name: Military Medallists' Memorial
description:
MILITARY MEDALLISTS’ MEMORIAL
The Military Medal was first established by King George V on 25 March 1916 to award Warrant Officers and other ranks for bravery in battle on land. It was awarded to members of the British Army and related services such as QAIMNS when the medal could be awarded to women after a ruling in 1916. The Military Medal was awarded for acts of bravery that were not deemed high enough for the DSM. In WW1 over 115,000 MMs were awarded with around 6000 bars. WW2 saw some 15,000 MMs along with 177 bars. The medal ceased to be awarded in 1993 and was replaced by the Military Cross. The final MMs were awarded for service in the last round of troubles in Northern Ireland between 1969-1993. (1969-2007) The memorial recognises all who were awarded the Military Medal since its inception in 1916.

name: Millenium Shelter
description: Millenium Shelter

name: Millennium Chapel of Peace and Forgiveness
description:
Millennium Chapel 
The Chapel welcomes people of all faiths and none and aims to provide a quiet space for reflection, where everyone will feel comfortable. It is the only place in the country where the Act of Remembrance is observed every day. The act, consisting of the Last Post, the Two Minute Silence and the Reveille, starts at 10.50am. All are invited to participate and reflect on the sacrifice of those who have given their lives in the service of their country. The Chapel is constructed largely from wood, reflecting the environment surrounding it, and the National Memorial Arboretum’s commitment to sustainability. The roof is supported by 12 columns of Douglas fir, each carved with one of the 12 disciples, by ex-Royal Marine and Shropshire woodcarver Jim Heath. 
At the entrance to the Chapel, the Millennium Prayer written by 13 year-old competition winner Anna Crompton is carved into cherry wood. The chapel’s altar, along with the lectern and pulpit, was made locally by young oŽenders at Swinfen Hall Prison. The altar cloth, showing the Tree of Life, was commissioned by the Women’s Section of the Royal British Legion, intended to remind us of the passing seasons. The altar candlesticks were created by Robert Pritchard-Gordon, a Birmingham silversmith, who collaborated with Arthur Price, the internationally reputed tableware company and Robert Carr, a Lichfield jeweller. These represent the twelve knives used by apostles. They are bound by barbed wire as a reminder that people still starve as a result of war and imprisonment 
On the wall behind the altar are three crosses. The central one is the ‘Sword of Sacrifice’, found at Commonwealth War Graves Commission cemeteries. Either side of this are crosses made from the wood of trees actually grown in the Arboretum. The uprights are made of ash taken from trees in the Ulster Ash Grove and the crosspieces are made of hazel taken from trees in the Royal Army Medical Corps Wood.

name: Millennium Wood
description:
Millennium Wood 
Millennium Wood is a woodland of native broadleaf tree species including oak, ash and field maple. The trees are individually sponsored with remembrance plaques and labels.

name: Monte Cassino Association Memorial
description:
MONTE CASSINO 
A major addition in 2012 was a memorial to the 1944 battle for Monte Cassino, an historic hilltop abbey in Italy, which cost the Allies 55,000casualties to dislodge the defending Germans in order to advance on to Rome

name: Mousey Memorial
description: Mousey Memorial

name: NAAFI ; Navy, Army and Air Force Institutes
description:
NAAFI; Navy, Army and Air Force Institutes
Sevitor Servientium Serving those who Serve The NAAFI Memorial honours the courage and sacrifice of the 550 members of the Navy, Army and Air Force Institutes who gave their lives whilst providing service to the Armed Forces during the Second World War. The Navy, Army and Air Force Institutes, aŽectionately known as ‘NAAFI’, was created by the British Government by combining the Expeditionary Force Canteens and the Navy and Army Canteen Board on the 9 December 1920. Over the years, NAAFI has proudly supported the British Armed Forces worldwide wherever and whenever. This includes the conflicts in the Falklands, NATO obligations during the Bosnian conflict, the two Gulf Wars and Afghanistan amongst many others. Today a smaller, but still dynamic and agile NAAFI operates a broad range of services in Germany, Gibraltar, Brunei, the South Atlantic Islands and in the UK onboard HM Ships and supporting exercises. NAAFI’s ethos and core purpose has not changed, it remains committed to serving the services by providing a taste of home to the British Armed Forces and their families and is ready to operate whenever called to do so.

name: National Association of Memorial Masons (NAMM)
description:
National Association of Memorial Masons 
The Association was formed in 1907 to promote excellence and craftsmanship within the memorial masonry trade. 
Through its strict codes of business practice and working practice, the National Association of Memorial Masons (NAMM) demands the very highest standards of its members. 
The NAMM memorial ‘exhibition’ was created to provide a permanent marker to celebrate 100 years of service to both its members and bereaved families. It is a timeline of memorialisation from Stone Age to the present day. 
The garden also aims to encourage children to understand how history, remembrance and heritage are linked to memorialisation. 
The ‘exhibition’, designed as a Centenary Garden, was officially opened by HRH The Princess Royal on 
20 May 2008.

name: National Ex-Prisoner of War Memorial
description:
NATIONAL EX-PRISONER OF WAR ASSOCIATION
The gates here remember those who were detained as prisoners of war by German forces during WW2. They are an exact replica of the memorial built by British Army engineers near Falling bostel, Germany, where two large ‘stalags’ were located, not only to remember the POWs who finally gained their freedom in April 1945, but also to mark the beginnings of a new friendship with the local German population.

name: National Miners' Memorial
description:
NATIONAL MINERS MEMORIAL 
The memorial commemorates the men, women and children who worked in the UK coal mining industry and served or died in the service of their country 
The artist for the memorial was Andy de Comyn 
Andy de Comyn was the artist for the ATS, WRAF, WRAC, Mercian Volunteers and Shot at Dawn memorials at the NMA 
Francesca de Comyn was the illustrator 
47 miners were awarded the Victoria Cross in the 2 world wars (45 during 1914-18 and 2 during 1939-45) 
Sapper William Hackett, Royal Engineers, is the only miner to be awarded a VC for his work in tunnels underground. He refused to leave a wounded fellow miner in a tunnel after a collapse.

name: National Voluntary Civil Aid
description: National Voluntary Civil Aid

name: Naval Service Memorial
description:
Naval Service Memorial 
The Naval Service Memorial is located at the heart of the Naval Section of the Arboretum and commemorates those who have served, serve today and will serve tomorrow, regardless of rank, trade or fighting arm. 
The striking memorial was created by Graeme Mitcheson, from a theme developed by Lt Cdr Nigel Huxtable. It is comprised of 13 coloured glass panels on a white granite terrace and includes a figure of Kilkenny limestone. 
The glass depicts the colours of the five oceans – steel grey with spume lines for the Atlantic, turquoise for the Indian, ultramarine for the Pacific and white for the Arctic and Southern oceans. 
Yellow is for the rising sun, red for the setting sun and the blood spilled at sea, and on land. 
On the memorial’s terrace stands a figure of a sailor, head bowed in respect to shipmates everywhere, cap held in the ‘at ease’ position. The figure faces west, where the sun sets. The terrace has a carved inscription of the Tennyson poem ‘Crossing the Bar’ – a phrase used when shipmates pass away. 
The glass panels cast a shadow suggesting the shape of a warship. Visible only in sunlight and for a few hours per day, it is best seen on 11 November. 
The curved shapes suggest waves and motion while the scale and colour hint at sails in a harbour. The idea for the ‘warship shadow’ came when the designer was in his garden, on a summer’s day, watching shadows cast by washing hanging on the line. 
The Naval Service Memorial was unveiled on 15 June 2014 by HRH Prince Michael of Kent. 
The coloured glass memorial was commissioned by the Royal Naval Association to mark the 60th anniversary of its being granted a Royal Charter. 
The 13 glass panels depict the different colours of the oceans of the world, while yellow is for the rising sun and red the setting sun. There are also splashes of red representing the blood spilled at sea, on land and in the air in defence of our nation. 
The panels cast a shadow, suggesting the shape of a warship, which is best seen around lunchtime when the sun is directly behind. 
The single figure faces the setting sun, head bowed, and cap held in the 'at ease' position, showing respect to his fallen shipmates. 
On the terrace edge is a carved inscription from the Tennyson poem 'Crossing the Bar', which is the phrase used by Navy personnel when a shipmate has passed away.

name: Navy Wood
description: The Navy Wood consists of mixed native trees individually sponsored and dedicated to those who have served in the Royal Navy and Merchant Navy.

name: Neutral Irish Registered Vessels Memorial
description:
Neutral Irish Registered Vessels 
The memorial is dedicated to all those who were serving aboard the Neutral Irish Registered Vessels lost as a result of enemy action during the Second World War - especially the 149 Seamen who lost their lives. The memorial lists the companies ships that were lost in WW2.

name: Nigeria Police
description: Nigeria Police

name: No 101 Squadron RAF
description:
101 SQUADRON 
101 Squadron is one of the Royal Air Force's oldest and most prestigious squadrons. It is still active today, flying out of RAF Brize Norton, Oxfordshire. 
In WW1 they flew bi-planes and pioneered night bombing over the Western Front. 
In WW2 the Squadron served in Bomber Command and participated in the greatest air battles the world has ever witnessed. 
In more recent times they have seen operational service in, amongst others, Falklands, Iraq, Syria and Afghanistan. 
The Squadron's Latin motto "Mens agitat molem" translates to "mind over matter".

name: No 2 Squadron RAF Memorial ; No II (AC) Squadron RAF, Shiny Two
description:
NUMBER 2 SQUADRON 
Number 2 Squadron is the most senior squadron of the RAF, formed on 13th may 1912 0n the founding day of the RFC as one of the first three squadrons formed. 
Numbers 2 and 3 were equipped with fixed wing aircraft while number one with airships. 
Number 2 was the first squadron to fly the English Channel into France at the start of WW1. 
Its principal role was not Air – Air combat but army co-operation but it still had a flying Ace in its ranks (five enemy A/C shot down) Arthur William Hammond it also had the first Aviation VC's first was 2nd Lieutenant William Rhodes Moorhouse and Lieutenant Alan Arnett “babe” Mcleod (see paving slab on causeway to McLeod). 
Number 2 nicknamed the shiny two Motto Hereward Guardian of the Army. The Squadron's tail badge is the wake knot derived from the coat of arms of Hereward the wake. 
The Squadron is now equipped with Eurofighter Typhoon FGR4's at RAF Lossiemouth.

name: No 47 Squadron RAF Memorial
description:
No. 47 Squadron RAF Memorial
No. 47 Squadron Royal Flying Corps was formed on 1 March 1916 at Beverley as a home defence unit to protect Hull and East Yorkshire against attacks from German Zeppelins. The Squadron saw active service in East Africa, the Eastern Mediterranean and India during the Second World War and later supported the Berlin Airlift. In more recent times the Squadron supported United Nations (UN) and NATO operations in the Balkans by delivering aid to besieged cities and also assisted coalition forces in operations in Iraq and Afghanistan. Also in this area… Take a look inside our original Type 24 Pillbox, where soldiers during the Second World War were expected to use the reinforced concrete walls for protection, whilst fighting an invading enemy. There is an information panel just outside if you’d like to find out more. The memorial’s five figures represent two airmen from the First World War and Second World War and the other three figures represent a modern air crew. An introductory plinth displays the Squadron badge depicting a demoiselle crane’s head in front of a fountain. The memorial also includes nine corten steel plaques that represent the Squadron’s battle honours.

name: No 49 Squadron Memorial
description:
49 Squadron RAF 
The memorial to 49 Squadron is made of polished South African Dark Grey granite. The circular headpiece, fixed to a rectangular base, depicts the squadron’s badge - a racing greyhound surmounting the motto 'Cave Canem' (Beware of the Dog) and is surrounded by the inscription: 49 Bomber Squadron Royal Air Force. The badge was officially recognised on 14 June 1937 following the Squadron’s relocation to Worthy Down.
The base of the memorial is inscribed with the words:
In memory of those who served on 49 Squadron 1916 – 1965
49 Squadron was originally formed during the First World War at Dover in April 1916. Its first 18 months were spent as an aircrew training unit equipped with BE2Cs, RE7s and Martinsydes. Between 1917 and 1918 the squadron was tasked with day bombing raids and high and low level bombing until the end of the war when it was subsequently disbanded in July 1919.
During the Second World War the reformed squadron operated as a front line bomber squadron and took part in most major operations by Bomber Command equipped with Lancaster Bombers. In peacetime the squadron carried out routine training and also saw action in Kenya.
In 1956, equipped with Valiant B1 aircraft (the first of the V Bombers), the squadron was tasked with carrying out a series of nuclear tests based on Christmas Island in the Pacific Ocean.
Reverting to the normal medium bomber role the squadron moved to Marham in 1961. On 5 June 1964 Her Royal Highness Princess Marina, Duchess of Kent, presented 49 Squadron with its standard.
49 Squadron was disbanded at RAF Marham on 1 May 1965, when all Valiant aircraft were withdrawn from service.
Honours and awards gained by members of 49 Squadron during the Second World War include:
1 Victoria Cross (VC)
(Awarded to Flight Lieutenant (later Wing Commander) Roderick Alastair Brook Learoyd for his bravery during the successful low level attack on the Dortmund Ems canal, 12 August 1940. It was the first VC awarded in Bomber Command.
1 Empire Gallantry Medal (later the George Cross)
7 Distinguished Service Orders
131 Distinguished Flying Crosses
2 Conspicuous Gallantry Medals
105 Distinguished Flying Medals

name: No IX Squadron RAF
description:
9 SQUADRON 
The Final British attack on the Tirpitz to place on the 12th November1944by a mixed force of 32 Lancasters from 9 Sqd and 617 Sqd they dropped 29 tallboy bombs on the ship landing two direct hits and one near miss. Several bombs landed within the torpedo nets which removed much of the sandbank that had been constructed to prevent the ship capsizing. To his day members of both squadrons claim that it was their Bomb that sank the Tirpitz. 
The 9 Squadron Memorial is dedicated to all those who have served in the Squadron since its formation in 1914. The memorial bears the inscription "The oldest bomber Squadron in the world". 
The Squadron crests are engraved on the faces of the memorial, including the IX Squadron (B) badge depicting a bat accompanied by the motto,"Per noctum volamus" which translates "Throughout the night we fly", reflecting the Squadron's night bombing duties. 
The Final British attack on the Tirpitz to place on the 12th November1944by a mixed force of 32 Lancaster Bombers from 9 Sqd and 617 Sqd they dropped 29 tallboy bombs on the ship landing two direct hits and one near miss. Several bombs landed within the torpedo nets which removed much of the sandbank that had been constructed to prevent the ship capsizing. To his day members of both squadrons claim that it was their Bomb that sank the Tirpitz. 
The Squadron is still in operation today.

name: No. 30 Squadron Association Memorial
description: No. 30 Squadron (transport - the black bell shaped one);

name: No. 8 Group Path Finder Force
description:
RAF PATH FINDER FORCE MEMORIAL (NO. 8 GROUP) 
Path Finder Force formed August 1942, part of Bomber Command (they were used for target-marking to increase accuracy of bombing raids). Mainly RAF but also personnel from other Commonwealth countries. It was steadily transformed from a token ‘hit & miss’ Force to one that could deliver anything from a single Bomb to 100’s of tonnes of bombs accurately onto a target anywhere in Western Europe. ‘Cherry-picking’ crews from other areas of the RAF was frowned upon at the time but it would have been the Crème de la Crème of crews that had the skills and experience needed. The airmen committed to doing another 60 operations, later reduced to 45 (and the more you did, the less the chance of surviving). Crews for specific missions were hand-picked. Aircraft used included Halifax, Lancaster, Wellington and Mosquito and Stirling. Project to get a memorial started in 2014. It was originally unveiled at the PFF Reunion at RAF Wyton (August 2017), 75 years after No.8 Group was formed. Memorial weighs 5 tonnes – logistically difficult getting it transferred to the NMA - eventually installed in July 2020

name: Normandy Veterans Memorial
description:
NORMANDY LANDINGS 
As early as 1942, the Allies had started thinking about an invasion whittled down to either the Pas-de-Calais or the bay of the Seine. 
Sg Maj Stanley Hollis Green Howards awarded only VC on D- Day itself although 4 other VCs were awarded during the campaign 6 June to 22 August.. 
On the surface, the Pas-de-Calais was the more attractive option - the Germans were convinced of this. 
In a short window given by the weather and tides, the operation was launched on 6 June 1944 with the Normandy Landings. 
Almost 7,000 vessels were involved in the huge naval effort, Operation Neptune. 
Over 11,500 aircraft took part in the landings. 
i. Throughout the night, RAF bombers pounded German batteries along the French coast. 
ii. At daybreak 1,300 heavy bombers of the USAF took over the attack. 
iii. The Royal Engineers are combat soldiers with a technical edge and have a role in every area of the battlefield. At the front they support the rest of the Army, bridging rivers, using explosives to destroy bridges or clearing routes through minefields. Aircraft dropped 7.2 million pounds of bombs on D Day. 
Around 156,000 Allied troops landed the first day 
Nearly 62,00 British soldiers -73,000 American and 21,400 Canadian 
Within five days, almost 330,000 troops and over 100,000 tons of supplies had been landed 
More than two million Allied troops were in France by the end of August. 

▪ This memorial is for the Normandy Landings, also known as D-Day, which started on the 6th June 1944, code named Overlord/Neptune. 
▪ This assault was the beginning of the end of WW2 and Hitler's tyranny. 
▪ 5,300 British ships and landing craft carrying 150,000 troops and 1,500 tanks landed on the first day, supported by 10,000 aircraft. 
▪ For the following 11 weeks, the battle progressed through Normandy with 60,000 allied troops killed and 200,000 wounded. A total of about 500,000 allied troops took part. 
▪ The five large stones represent the beaches where the allied troops landed. Code named Sword, Gold (British landings) Utah, Omaha (American landings), Juno (Canadian landings).

name: Northern Ireland Prison Service Memorial
description:
Northern Ireland Prison Service Memorial
The memorial commemorates the 32 men and women of the Northern Ireland Prison Service who lost their lives as result of their employment during 1942 - 2016. Many were killed off duty by shooting or by having their cars booby-trapped.The memorial was upgraded, new names added and placed in its current position in July 2023.

name: Northern Rhodesia Police Memorial
description:
BLESMA
BLESMA stands for British Limbless Ex-Service Men’s Association 
BLESMA was formed in 1932 
BELSMA works to assist those who have lost limbs as a result of service in any branch of Her Majesty's Armed Forces. 
The garden is planted mostly with fruit trees which are kept purposely at a low height to allow easy access for those in wheelchairs both to smell the blossom in spring and harvest the fruit in autumn. 
An apple or pear, of course, does not need to be peeled for eating (requiring two hands) 
The circular benches do not have any arm rests. A service person may have lost their arms.

name: Not Forgotten Association Memorial
description:
NOT FORGOTTEN ASSOCIATION Map 
In 1919 American soprano Marta Cunningham visited a Ministry of Pensions hospital, having heard that there were ‘perhaps a handful’ of soldiers wounded in WWI still residing there. She called on the Matron and asked if she had a few lonely patients who would like to come out for tea. The Matron looked surprised and replied that there were in fact 600 injured patients lying in the hospital, with many more across the country. Marta was horrified by what she saw. 
An avid charity worker during the Great War, Marta soon set about contacting her friends to organise tea parties, concerts and outings for those able to attend. During one of these early invitations one injured soldier said: “We don’t want no charity Miss, we are forgotten by everybody and we’d better stop so.” But, undeterred, in August 1920, Marta formed the “NOT FORGOTTEN” Association for the ‘comfort, cheer and entertainment’ of the war wounded and within a year some 10,000 men had been entertained. 
The memorial is made of solid green polished granite with a sculptured elephant’s head on top. The elephant and sword form the basis of the emblem of the association. 
The plaque on the ground outlines the part of Marta Cunningham in setting up the Association. 
The Not Forgotten Association is a charity that continues to provide events for wounded serving personnel and disabled veterans, which improve physical and mental health, address isolation and loneliness, and provide a sense of community and balance.

name: Nursing Memorial,The
description:
National Nursing Memorial 
The National Nursing Memorial honours all nurses who died in the First and Second World Wars, providing care to the Armed Forces of the Crown wherever it was needed. There are various memorials to individual and collective heroines, but none has recognised them all. 
The memorial, located within a secluded spot of the Royal Army Medical Corps’ woodland, comprises a large stone globe etched with the names of all nurses lost on active service during the First and Second World Wars. The globe, created by stonemason Nick Johnson, is supported by a pair of sculpted bronze hands made by artist Georgie Welch. They rise from a circular stone base plinth inscribed on the surface with further names. The inscription - As Stars In A Dark Sky They Lit Up Our World appears around its edge. 
Adjacent to the memorial is a stone plinth displaying the following description: 
The memorial was erected at the behest of the New Cavendish Club, previously the Voluntary Aid Detachment (VAD) Ladies’ Club in commemoration of all the VAD and professional nurses who lost their lives in the 1st and 2nd World Wars. 
The memorial marking the sacrifice and loss of the VADs and nurses was dedicated on 4th June 2018 by HRH The Countess of Wessex GCVO. 
▪ This memorial honours all nurses who died in WW1 and WW2 providing care to members of the armed services. 
▪ Memorial comprises of a large stone globe etched with the names of 1265 nurses who lost their lives in active service during both World Wars. It includes nurses from QAIMNS, VAD Nurses, Red Cross, FANY, Order of Saint Johns, TFNS, TANS, PMRAFNS, QARNNS and FNN. 
QAIMNS - Queen Alexandra's Imperial Military Nursing Service 
VAD. - Voluntary Aid Detachment 
FANY. - First Aid Nursing Yeomanry 
TFNS. - Territorial Force Nursing Service 
TANS. - Territorial Army Nursing Service 
PMRAFNS. - Princess Mary's Royal Air Force Nursing Service 
QARNNS. - Queen Alexandra's Royal Naval Nursing Service 
FNN - Flying Nightingale Nurses 
The globe was created by stonemason Nick Johnson and is supported by a pair of sculpted bronze hands created by artist Georgie Welch.

name: Nyasaland Police Memorial
description:
Nyasaland Police
Interred in this memorial is a scroll containing the names of officers who served in the Nyasaland Police from 1921 – 1964.

name: Ocean Fairway Blue Funnel Line Memorial
description:
Ocean Fairway Blue Funnel Line Memorial  
The memorial is a tribute to the Merchant Navy Officers and Seamen of the Blue Funnel Line, Glen Line and NSMO who served during the Second World War and especially those who made the ultimate sacrifice. It was donated by the Ocean Association of Retired Masters and Chief Engineers, the Nestorian Association of Ocean Group plc.

name: Ocean Fairway Elder Dempster Line Memorial
description:
Ocean Fairway Elder Dempster Line Memorial 
The memorial is a tribute to the Merchant Navy Officers and Seamen of the Elder Dempster Lines and W.M. Cory & Son Ltd who served during the Second World War and especially those who made the ultimate sacrifice. It was donated by the Elders of the Elder and The Ocean Association of Retired Masters and Chief Engineers of Ocean Group plc.

name: Oddfellows
description:
THE ODDFELLOWS MEMORIAL
The Oddfellows were first formed in this country in 1810, over 200 years ago. Today they have a network of 121 branches and 309,000 members in the UK. Their aim is to improve the quality of people's lives through friendship, care and charitable support. Like the Masons, they have their own traditions exclusive to them. Many members of the Oddfellows served in both WWs. 
After WW1 they set up the Orphan Gift Fund to care for orphaned children of their members and the fund still exists today. Part of their insignia is a three linked chain symbolising friendship, love and truth

name: Operation Market Garden / Market Garden Veterans' Association Memorial
description:
Market Garden Grove
These are the trees either side of Yeomanry Avenue near the Market Garden Memorial. They are dedicated to various Market Garden Veterans Associations. Technically this is not a memorial..

name: Orange Institution Memorial
description:
Orange Institution Memorial
The Orange Institution was formed over 200 years ago to commemorate the victory won at the Battle of the Boyne in County Meath, Ireland by William of Orange (King William III) over James II in July 1690. Since its formation many members of the Order have joined the British Armed Forces and served around the world.
A memorial to the service and sacrifice of members of the Orange Institution was unveiled at the National Memorial Arboretum on Saturday 2 September 2017 and was formally dedicated by the Grand Master of the Grand Orange Lodge of Scotland, Jim McHarg.
It is formed in the shape of a lectern with an open Bible on top dressed with an Orange collarette. The inscribed message in gold lettering reads: ‘This Memorial is Dedicated to God and erected to Joshua, in thanksgiving to all members of the Loyal Orange Institution who served and paid the supreme sacrifice in the service of their Country’.
An Orange Institution memorial behind the Ulster Tower in Albert, France is dedicated to all those members who lost their lives in service during the First World War.
An Orange Lodge in Cumbria was opened in memory of Private Abraham Acton who, as a member of the Whitehaven Lodge, was awarded the Victoria Cross for his bravery rescuing wounded comrades whilst under heavy enemy fire during the Battle of Rouge Banc in France in 1914. He was killed in action on 16 May 1915 during the Battle of Festubert, before he could collect his medal, and his body was never recovered. He was only 22 years old.

name: Order of St John Volunteers Memorial
description:
MEMORIAL TO THE VENERABLE ORDER OF THE HOSPITAL OF St JOHN OF JERUSALEM 
The memorial dedicated to the Order of St John was designed and installed to commemorate the thousands of volunteers who have helped the charity over the years in its mission to provide first aid in many different situations. Prince Richard, Duke of Gloucester, who is the Grand Prior of the Order of St John, officially opened the memorial in 2009; however, it took some fourteen years to completion and was not finally completed until 2022. 
The design of the memorial takes the form of the St John (Amalfi) Cross. The entrance is through one of the arms of the cross which is flanked by two granite panels depicting the badge of St John and the Priory of England and the Islands. At the centre of the cross is a black granite stone with the inscription: “In honour of all those who have faithfully served the Venerable Order of the Hospital of St John of Jerusalem and its foundations.” 
The other various priory emblems are fixed to the arms of the memorial in order of precedence (It should be noted that because the cross was designed to give a particular perspective when viewed from the front, the tops of the walls which form the arms of the cross are slanted and therefore are not necessarily horizontal. In order to ensure that all the plaques are in line with each other when the monument is viewed as a whole, individual plaques will not always be parallel to the tops of the respective wall to which they are attached.) 
The Venerable Order of the Hospital of St John of Jerusalem shares its origins with the religious Knights Hospitaller, who served in a hospice in Jerusalem which looked after pilgrims in the twelfth century. The English branch was dissolved by King Henry VIII in 1540 and briefly reinstated by Queen Mary in 1557. An early 19th century move to revive the Order in England eventually resulted in the creation of a British Royal Order of Chivalry. Her Majesty Queen Victoria granted the Order of St John a Royal Charter and became its Sovereign Head in 1888. The Order, as an Order of Chivalry, is unique in its corporate work for the benefit of society. It has two key foundations: the St John of Jerusalem Eye Hospital and St John Ambulance. 
The Order conducts its affairs around the world through the St John Eye Hospital Group, 11 Priories, 5 Commanderies and 32 Associations. The Priory of England and the Islands manages the day-to-day affairs of Order business in England, Northern Ireland, the Channel Islands and the Isle of Man. The Priory’s main role is delivered by its subsidiary charity StJohn Ambulance which delivers first aid and first aid training in the community. It also carries out Ambulance work in support of the NHS, and has a thriving Youth movement. 
The Order is also involved in welfare services alongside the British Red Cross Society of the International Red Cross through a residential home for ex servicemen and women, ex-nurses and ex-members of St John and the Red Cross. The welfare of patients in Service Hospitals is looked after by the Order of St John and British Red Cross Defence Medical Welfare Service. Furthermore, in association with the British Association of the Sovereign Military Order of Malta, through the Orders of St John Care Trust the Priory promotes the Trust’s work with residential care homes and alms houses. The Order’s Museum is located at St John’s Gate in Clerkenwell, London. There is also a flourishing St John Fellowship with branches throughout England and the Islands, as well operating in many of the overseas priories and associations.

name: Palestine Police Old Comrades' Association Memorial
description:
Palestine Police Memorial Old Comrades
The memorial, located within the Mediterranean Campaigns of World War II Garden, is in memory of all those who served in the Palestinian Police, a British colonial police force, in the period of British Mandate between 1922-1948.
The memorial displays the badge of the Palestinian Police together with a dedication remembering over 500 members of the force who died during the British Mandate. It also acknowledges that over 300 medals were awarded, including one George Medal, during this period.
The final ‘stand down’ parade for the Palestinian Police took place at Buckingham Palace on 20 July 1948, where in his address King George VI said of the force ‘you can look back on a job well done’.

name: Palestine Veterans' Association Memorial
description:
Palestine Veterans Association 
Palestine Veterans' Association Memorial, located within the Mediterranean Campaigns of World War II Garden, is dedicated to the memory of 784 members of the British Armed Forces who lost their lives whilst acting as a peace keeping force in the region.
The memorial plaque, which displays the badge of the Palestine Veterans' Association, includes the dedication: “When Comrades fall, we’ve shown them all, we never shall forget”.

name: Parachute Regiment and Airborne Forces Memorial
description:
PARACHUTE REGIMENT AND AIRBORNE FORCES 
Features the emblem of the Airborne Forces – the winged horse Pegasus with rider Bellerophon on a Portland stone plinth. In Greek mythology they flew to the lair of, and killed, the monster Chimera (pronounced Ky-meera). 
Beneath is a parachutist recovering his Bergen (pack), which would have been attached to his waist belt and hang below him as he came down. It would hit the ground first, making the soldier aware that he was about to contact the ground himself. 
The inscription around the top edge beginning “What manner of men are these….” is part of a quotation by Field Marshall the Viscount Montgomery. 
The establishment of airborne forces was instigated by Winston Churchill in 1940. It had its first operation in 1941 in southern Italy, code named Operation Colossus.

name: Parachute Squadron Royal Armoured Corps Memorial
description:
PARACHUTE SQUADRON (ROYAL ARMOURED CORPS) Map 
Formed in 1965 (the Cold War era), the Squadron had specialist roles of reconnaissance and long-range anti-tank capability. All their equipment and vehicles could be delivered by parachute. 
The squadron saw service in Aden; Cyprus with a UN Peacekeeping Force; and Northern Ireland. 
The unit was disbanded in 1976.

name: Pegasus Bridge Memorial
description:
Pegasus Bridge Memorial Flight
'Operation Deadstick'
On D-Day 6th June 1944 six Horsa Gliders were released by Halifax pilots of 298 and 644 Squadrons Royal Air Force. Gliding down over enemy territory in complete darkness the crews of the Glider Pilot Regiment crash landed 5 of the Gliders very close to the bridges over the Orne River and Caen Canal. Glider No. 4 landed by a bridge over the River Dives about 10 miles away. Capture of these bridges was vital to defending the D-Day landing beaches in Normandy to the North and the Airborne Forces drop zones to the East in the vicinity of Ranville. The operation was planned by Major John Howard and the successful assault by soldiers from the 2nd. Battalion Oxfordshire & Buckinghamshire Light Infantry who were supported by the Royal Engineers, Royal Army Medical Corps and a 7 Para liaison officer. The 5 metre high memorial depicts three stylised Horsa gliders spiralling down on a giant letter 'S' representing this Secret operation that was carried out in Silence, using Speed, Stealth and achieved complete Surprise. The concept of the memorial was by Mike Colton and the memorial brought to life by Bromley O'Hare, Blacksmith/Artisan with the sides left open to indicate that the Gliders were frail craft!
Memorial Established 2018.

name: Phantom Memorial
description:
Phantom Memorial Map
The Phantoms were a wireless communication unit for the Special Air Service (SAS). The memorial particularly remembers events of 1944 when F Squadron was in France to provide communications for Operation Loyton. The path is laid out in a ‘P’ design to denote the word Phantom; planting represents the 140 men and boys who did not return from concentration camps. The coral granite memorial stone was cut from a much larger stone at Senones, a few miles from Moussey, and represents the resolve of the villagers and resistance forces that protected the soldiers on the operation. The Cross of Lorraine was later added to the memorial to represent the Anglo / Norman link.

name: Pity of War
description: Pity of War

name: Polar Bear Memorial ; 49 West Riding Division
description:
POLAR BEAR (49th WEST RIDING INFANTRY DIVISION) Map
This was our first major memorial and was erected in 1998. The 49th saw active service in France and Flanders during WW1. They got their name from seeing active service in Norway and Iceland where they had to contend with very heavy snow drifts. Not thinking that they would survive, their commanding officer called them his Polar Bears. The Polar Bear was adopted as their shoulder flash and remains so today.
Peter Benson and his team of Essex woodcarvers took a year to create the structure. The bear was recently restored.
The traffic bulletin on Radio 5 kept including information ‘Motorists heading north along the M1/M6 should take care, there is a slow moving Polar Bear on the inside lane.’
This memorial has two poems by Jodie Johnson; the first written when she was aged 9 and the second at age 11.

name: Police Service Northern Ireland (PSNI) Memorial
description:
Police Service of Northern Ireland: PSNI Map
The memorial displays the badge of the Police Service of Northern Ireland above an inscription which commemorates all those who lost their lives in service of the people of Northern Ireland.

name: Polish Forces War Memorial
description:
POLISH MEMORIAL 
The elements to this memorial were made in Poland and brought here for construction. 
The four figures represent the Polish army, navy, air force & underground movement. During WW2 the Polish were the 4th largest fighting force on the Allied side, and note they are wearing British uniforms, which is all they had available. 
They were also instrumental in helping to crack the Enigma Code as explained in one of the wall panels. Even before the war there were Polish mathematicians working on the code, with considerable success. 
Apparently, a German man who was helping to build the Enigma machine was badly in need of money, so in 1932 he sold some of the paperwork to the French, who copied it to Poland. When Poland was invaded by Germany in 1939, the Polish underground people made sure all the mathematicians’ work came to the UK, giving our own code breakers at Bletchley Park something to begin their own work with.

name: Poppy Memorial ; 'RBL Never Forget Tribute Garden'
description:
POPPY MEMORIAL
The memorial, provided by The Royal British Legion (began in 1921), features a giant wreath around which poppies, inscribed with individual names and dates, can be planted as a permanent tribute. It’s a place where everyday heroes, as well as those killed in conflict, can be honoured. (Became ‘Royal’ in 1971). It has 12 segments representing the 12 months of the year, and those wishing to place a poppy can select the most appropriate segment.
• Leaflets are available in Reception explaining how a poppy can be placed, which is via the Royal British Legion, not the NMA.

name: Popski's Private Army
description:
Popski’s Private Army
Popski’s Private Army was founded by Major Vladimir Peniakoff in Cairo in October 1942. On 10 December 1942, it became officially operational as “No. 1 Demolition Squadron, PPA” an 8th Army Special Forces unit formed specifically to attack Field-Marshal Rommel’s fuel supplies, in support of General Montgomery’s offensive at El Alamein. The squadron, which also served in Italy, was disbanded in September 1945 as well as the Long
Range Desert Group (LRDG) and the Special Air Service (SAS), PPA was the last and smallest of the three main irregular raiding, reconnaissance and intelligence units formed during the North African Campaign. The stone built memorial is a truncated pyramid topped with the PPA astrolabe unit symbol replicated from Popski’s original design which is also echoed in the shape of the surrounding low hedge. The variegated laurel hedge represents the yellow of the deserts of North Africa and the greenery of Italy. Commemorative plaques feature on all four faces of the memorial. The front displays a small plaque showing PPA's astrolabe cap badge, a small plaque commemorating the unveiling on 30 March 2008 (Popski's Birthday), together with the PPA Roll of Honour. To the rear PPA Honours and Awards are listed. The right-hand plaque commemorates the 27th Lancers and all the units who comprised "Porterforce" with the Italian Partisans commemorated on the left-hand plaque. In 2010, two plaques telling the story Popski's Private Army were added to the memorial’s entrance. The design of the hedge around the memorial was by Mike Colton. Dedicated in 2008.
Note: - All the plaques are undergoing refurbishment. (19/2/23)

name: Posted - Service Children's Education Memorial
description:
Posted - Service Children’s Education Memorial
‘Posted’ recognises the work of Service Children’s Education (SCE), an Agency of the Ministry of Defence (MOD), dedicated to the education of the children of His Majesty’s Armed Forces, MOD Personnel and sponsored organisations stationed overseas. Military postings require most families to move every two years or so, either within the UK or to other overseas locations. It can sometimes be hard for children to regularly leave friends behind and start afresh. The memorial features a traditional red British post box on a black post with sculpted birds above representing the dispersal and regrouping experience of posted families.

name: Prince of Wales's Own Regiment of Yorkshire
description:
Prince of Wales Own Regiment of Yorkshire 
The Prince of Wales's Own Regiment of Yorkshire was formed on 25 April 1958 following the amalgamation of The West Yorkshire Regiment (The Prince Of Wales's Own) and The East Yorkshire Regiment (The Duke of York’s Own); these in turn date back to 1685 when they were the 14th and 15th Regiments of Foot. When several regiments were amalgamated in June 2006 the Regiment became the 1st Battalion of the Yorkshire Regiment whose memorial is nearby. Curiously, the Regiment mascots were two ferrets named Imphal and Quebec.
The one tonne slate memorial, located in the shadow of the Armed Forces Memorial, stands on a bed of York Stone Pavers and is inscribed with the badges of the ancestor regiments and the following dedication:
The West and The East Regiments (14th and 15th Foot) 1685 – 2006
To understand this Regiment, understand its people: Proud to be of Yorkshire.
Determined, tough and fiercely competitive on operations, in training and in sport.
Courageous, reliable and long suffering but not complaining!
We said what we thought, meant what we said and when a job needed doing, we did it right.
Banter and humour sustained us through all adversity.
Together, we were guided by our motto and never deterred by difficulties.
Nec asperea terrent
A list of the Regiment’s 158 Battle Honours, displayed on the Regimental Colours, is inscribed on the rear of the memorial with the Regimental Collect beneath.
The Prince of Wales's Own Regiment of Yorkshire memorial was dedicated on 29 April 2018 and attended by:
Major General EHA Beckett CB MB – The West Yorkshire Regiment (Prince of Wales’s Own) XIVth Foot
Major General HM Tillton CB CBE – The East Yorkshire Regiment (Duke of York’s Own) XVth Foot
Major General GJ Binns CBE DSO MC – The Prince of Wales’s Own Regiment of Yorkshire

name: Princess Mary's RAF Nursing Service (PMRAFNS) Memorial
description:
PRINCESS MARY'S ROYAL AIR FORCE NURSING SERVICE (PMRAFNS) This nursing service started as a temporary service in 1918 when the RAF was founded on 1st April, the service became permanent in 1921. 
It was a female only nursing service until 1980 when men were allowed to join. 
There are around 500 nurses serving today. 
There is a Plaque to Nurse Joyce Kathleen Atkin to the left behind the main memorial who was killed in the sinking of the Ship Khedive Ismall along side 52 other nurses a total of 77 female lives lost the largest loss of female lives. Torpedoed by Japanese submarine in the Indian ocean 12th February 1944.

name: Prison Officers Association (POA)
description:
Prison Officers Association Memorial
