Dedicated to all those who continue to serve the Crown, have served in the Armed Forces and all those lost in service, who joined the trade union via their work within our secure services including; public sector and private sector prisons, immigration centres, youth custody services, escort services and secure psychiatric institutions. The memorial recognises the dangers staŽ who work in these environments place themselves in, whilst serving to protect the public.

name: Quaker Services Memorial
description:
Quaker Services Memorial Map Index
During both World Wars, members of the Religious Society of Friends (Quakers) were active in relief work, which was recognised by the award of the Nobel Peace Prize in 1947. The Friends Ambulance Unit was an independent body led by Quakers and open to people of all denominations, giving conscientious objectors to military service an opportunity to serve in theatres of war. Bronze stars set in the paving mark the 17 lives lost. The Friends Relief Service was the o›cial arm of the Society for the relief of civilian distress. Twelve hundred people, nearly half of them women, from all denominations, served as members. The circular design of the memorial, which symbolises reconciliation between opponents, invites visitors to rest and contemplate; it also represents the unity and equality which Friends bring to their worship and lives. Quakers recognise the reality of conflict and have practical experience of the power of love in its resolution.

name: Queen Alexandra's Royal Army Nursing Corps Memorial
description:
QARANCS 
▪ The history of this Corps dates back over 100 years to the time of Florence Nightingale. She could see the need for nurses to be part of the British Army 
▪ She, along with others, was instrumental in lobbying for support of female military nurses. 
▪ In 1902 Queen Alexandra's Imperial Military Nursing Service (QAIMNS) was established. In 1949 the name changed to Queen Alexandra's Royal Army Nursing Corps (QARANC) and in 1992 men were allowed to join the Corps. 
▪ The QA's of today train and nurse in a small number of military hospitals around the UK, also where the UK has a military presence around the world, in such places as Germany, Poland, Cyprus, Canada, Afghanistan. 
▪ They are also attached to NHS hospitals in the UK. 
▪ They are always ready to be deployed anywhere in the world to support our troops unfortunately a number lost their lives. 
Sister Joyce Kathleen Atkin, Queen Alexandra’s Imperial Military Nursing Service was killed at sea on the 12th February 1944, when the SS Khedive Ismail was torpedoed by a Japanese submarine in the Indian Ocean whilst on route from Mombasa to Colombo. 
Nellie Spindler was a staff nurse; she was killed during the Battle of Passchendaele

name: Queen Alexandra's Royal Navy Nursing Service and the Voluntary Aid Detachment Memorial (QARNNS)
description:
QARANCS
The history of this Corps dates back over 100 years to the time of Florence Nightingale. She could see the need for nurses to be part of the British Army 
She, along with others, was instrumental in lobbying for support of female military nurses. 
In 1902 Queen Alexandra's Imperial Military Nursing Service (QAIMNS) was established. In 1949 the name changed to Queen Alexandra's Royal Army Nursing Corps (QARANC) and in 1992 men were allowed to join the Corps. 
The QA's of today train and nurse in a small number of military hospitals around the UK, also where the UK has a military presence around the world, in such places as Germany, Poland, Cyprus, Canada, Afghanistan. 
They are also attached to NHS hospitals in the UK. 
They are always ready to be deployed anywhere in the world to support our troops unfortunately a number lost their lives. 
Sister Joyce Kathleen Atkin, Queen Alexandra’s Imperial Military Nursing Service was killed at sea on the 12th February 1944, when the SS Khedive Ismail was torpedoed by a Japanese submarine in the Indian Ocean whilst on route from Mombasa to Colombo. 
Nellie Spindler was a staff nurse; she was killed during the Battle of Passchendaele

name: Queen's Lancashire Regiment 1970-2006
description:
THE QUEEN'S LANCASHIRE REGIMENT MEMORIAL 
The Queen's Lancashire Regiment was formed on 25 March 1970 until 2006 when it was amalgamated with The King's Own Royal Border Regiment and The King's Regiment to create The Duke of Lancaster's Regiment. 
The new regiment took the golden thread of the Rose of Lancashire as the cap badge from The Queen's Lancs. 
A box containing artefacts is entombed in the 5x5 metre base of the memorial. Amongst the items in the box is a photograph of the presentation of the Colours, a list of battle honours, a short history of the regiment, a regimental shield and regimental drumsticks. The final part of the memorial, a coloured glass panel displaying the Regimental Flag is yet to be added. 
The memorial will honour the 2 regiments that came together in 1970 to form The Queens Lancs. They are The Lancashire Regiment and The Loyal Regiment. 
25 March 2020 was 50th anniversary of the founding of the regiment.

name: Queen's Own Highlanders Memorial
description:
Queen’s Own Highlanders 
The regiment was formed on 7 February 1961 at Redford Barracks, Edinburgh, with the amalgamation of 1st Battalion, Seaforth Highlanders and 1st Battalion, Queen's Own Cameron Highlanders. 
The battalion was sent to Singapore in April 1961 from where it was deployed to Brunei in December 1962 in order to help suppress the Brunei Revolt at an early stage of the Indonesia–Malaysia confrontation. On return to Scotland in January 1964, it was based at Milton Bridge Camp, a former facility for German Prisoners of War, located south east of Glencorse Barracks. In June 1964 the battalion moved to Mercer Barracks at Osnabrück Garrison, part of British Army of the Rhine, remaining there until August 1966 when the battalion moved to Wavell Barracks in Berlin. 
The battalion returned to Redford Barracks in September 1968 from where units were deployed to Sharjah in May 1969. In April 1971 the battalion returned Osnabrück Garrison and moved into Belfast Barracks: from their units they were deployed to Northern Ireland at the height of the Troubles. In June 1976 the battalion returned to Scotland, this time to Ritchie Camp from where more units were deployed to Northern Ireland. Then in March 1980 the battalion was despatched for a tour at Stanley Fort in Hong Kong before moving to Tidworth in November 1981. Units of the battalion saw action in the Falklands War the following year. The battalion moved to Alexander Barracks, Aldergrove in November 1983 and on to Fort George in November 1985. In March 1988 the battalion moved to Buller Barracks in Münster from where units were deployed to Northern Ireland again and to the Gulf War in 1991. The battalion returned to Scotland again in October 1993 and moved into Dreghorn Barracks this time. 
Due to the Options for Change defence review the battalion was amalgamated with 1st Battalion, Gordon Highlanders on 17 September 1994 to form 1st Battalion, Highlanders (Seaforth, Gordons and Camerons).

name: Queen's Regiment Memorial
description:
Queen’s Regiment
Formed on 31 December 1966, by the amalgamation of the four county regiments of Queen’s Royal Surrey, Queen’s Own Buffs (Royal Kent Regiment), Royal Sussex and Middlesex, The Queen’s Regiment served in numerous operations around the world. 
The Regiment was later amalgamated with The Royal Hampshire Regiment to form The Princess of Wales’s Royal Regiment on 9 September 1992. 
The Dedication of The Queen’s Regiment Memorial took place on 15 May 2016 and was unveiled by Captain Harrie Welmer, Defence and Naval Attache to the Embassy of the Kingdom of the Netherlands. 
The memorial is dedicated to the fallen of the Regiment.

name: Queen's Royal Hussars Memorial
description:
Queen’s Royal Hussars 
The Queen’s Royal Hussars was created on 1st September 1993 by the amalgamation of the Queen’s Own Hussars and the Queen’s Royal Irish Hussars and is part of the Royal Armoured Corps. Their history dates to 1685 with the creation of (King's Own) Dragoons and Queen's own Dragoons. The battle honours of the antecedent regiments include Dettingham (the last battle in which a British Monarch was present), The Peninsula War, Crimea (including Alma, Inkerman, Balaklava & Sevastopol), The Boer War, WW1 and WW2 (which included Wl Alamein). More recent deployments have included Iraq and Afghanistan.
8 soldiers from these regiments have been awarded the Victoria Cross.
Colonels in Chief of the current regiment have included Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother and Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh.
The relationships of the antecedent regiments is shown in the following diagram.
Queen’s Own Hussars 1958
3rd (King’s Own) Light Dragoons 1818
 (King’s Own) Dragoons 1685
 (Queens’s Own) Hussars 1690
Queen’s Royal Irish Hussars 1958
4th Queen’s Own Light Dragoons 1818
Queen’s Own Dragoons 1685
King’s Royal Irish Light Dragoons 1693

name: Queen's Royal Lancers Memorial
description:
Queen's Royal Lancers 
The Queen's Royal Lancers (known as the Death or Glory Boys) was formed in 1993 by the amalgamation of the 16th/5th Queens Royal Lancers and the 17th/21st Lancers. The regiment can trace its lineage back to 1689 with the raising of Wynne's Regiment of Enniskillen Dragoon. The battle honours of the antecedent regiments include the Duke of Marlborough's four victories in the War of the Spanish Succession and the Duke of Wellington's victories in the Peninsular War, Crimea (Alma, Balaklava (Charge of the Light Brigade), Inkerman, Sevastopol), Boer War, WW2, WW2 and the Gulf War of 1991. 
The following table shows the relationship of the antecedent regiments. 
16th/5th Queens Royal Lancers 1922 
Queen’s Light Dragoons 1759 
5th (Royal Irish) Lancers 1858 
17th/21st Lancers 1922 
1876 
17th Lancers 1822 
Light Dragoons 1759 
21st Lancers 1897 
21st Hussars formerly 3rd Bengal European Light Cavalry (H.E.I.C.) 1862 
The H.E.I.C. is the Honourable East India Company. 
NB the 5th Regiment of Dragoons were originally raised as Wynne's Regiment of Enniskillen Dragoons 1689 and disbanded in 1799: they were reraised in 1858 as the 5th (Royal Irish) Lancers.

name: Queens Own Buffs - The Royal Kent Regiment
description: Currently no description on collections Index.

name: RAC Future Forests
description:
RAC Future Forests 
Future Forests is a scheme that measures emissions of carbon dioxide, the greenhouse gas which scientists think is responsible for global warming. The scheme helps to offset this pollution by planting natural forests and woodlands and investing in renewable energy. 
The Royal Automobile Club (RAC) Future Forests wood was sponsored by the RAC as part of the Future Forests scheme and as a tribute to their employees who have now retired.

name: RAF 214 Squadron Memorial
description:
214 (Federated Malay States) Squadron RAF Memorial  
The memorial commemorates the distinguished record of the No 214 (FMS) Squadron in bomber, radio, countermeasures, transport and in air-to-air refueling tanker roles. It remembers all those who served on the Squadron and those who gave their lives in war and peace. 
Formed originally as No.7A Squadron, Royal Navy Air Service on 28 July 1917, it became No 214 Squadron and was named the Federated Malay States Squadron in June 1941 in recognition of the gift of aircraft purchased with funds subscribed to the British Government through the Federated Malay States war fund. 
No 214 Squadron, Royal Air Force, was disbanded on 28 January 1977. 
The memorial is located within the RAF Memorial Grove (known as the RAF Wing) which comprises a collection of silver birch trees planted in the shape of an eagle’s wings. The wing honours both the Fighter and Bomber Commands.

name: RAF Administrative Apprentices Memorial
description:
RAF Administrative Apprentices Memorial
Commemorates all who trained as RAF Administrative Apprentices and Apprentice Clerks from 1925–1973 at Ruislip, St. Athan, Hereford and Bircham Newton.

name: RAF Air Loadmasters' Association Memorial
description:
Air Loadmaster Association 
The Air Loadmaster Association is one of only a few remaining associations for members of the Royal Air Force who have served as Air Quartermaster or Air Loadmasters (AQM and ALMs). 
The memorial, located within the RAF Memorial Grove (known as RAF Wing), is a truncated obelisk of white Portland Stone set in a blue slate bed edged with small stones. The front face of the pyramidal top is engraved with the letters RAF below which the face of the memorial is ornamented by engravings of Air Loadmaster insignia and a dedication to the fallen. 
During the service of dedication on 14 October 2011 a fly past took place to honour those killed in action, or in the course of duty.

name: RAF Armourers
description: RAF Armourers Memorial

name: RAF Barrage Balloons Memorial
description:
RAF Barrage Balloons Memorial 
The memorial, unveiled in November 2015, is dedicated to the memory of the men and women who served with the Balloon Barrage Squadrons of RAF Balloon Command during the Second World War.
The purpose of the Balloon Barrage was to prevent accurate bombing by forcing enemy aircraft to fly at higher altitude. This was achieved by steel cables held up by the balloons flown to a height of up to 5,000 feet. Aircraft which flew into the cables could be seriously damaged or brought down.
Barrage Balloons were filled with hydrogen gas and were flown from either fixed or mobile winches, each operated by ten men or 14 women and two NCOs.

name: RAF Benevolent Fund Memorial
description:
RAF Benevolent Fund 
The RAF BF offer support to all Serving and Former Members Of The RAF, Their Partners and Dependent Children. They are the RAF's Leading Welfare Charity With A Proud Tradition Of Looking After Our Own.

name: RAF Bomb Disposal
description: RAF Bomb Disposal

name: RAF Fire and Rescue Service
description: RAF Fire and Rescue Service

name: RAF Flight and Air Engineers Memorial
description:
FLIGHT ENGINEERS MEMORIAL 
Flight Engineers were introduced into the RAF in 1941, their primary role was to assist pilots in the flying of large multi-engined aircraft that had become too technically complex to be operated by a single pilot. By taking over the management of the aircraft's various systems, the Flight Engineer released the pilot to concentrate on the actual flying of the aircraft. 
The insignia of a Flight Engineer is a single wing. The single wing is known as a half brevet (which was given to increase rank without increasing pay).

name: RAF Locking Memorial
description:
RAF Locking Apprentices 
This memorial commemorates all Apprentices who trained at RAF Locking between 1952 and 1976.
The accommodation, messing and medical facilities were all housed in wooden huts. Training facilities were, however, mostly brick-built hangars. The Aircraft Apprenticeship comprised a year of basic mental and physical training followed by two years of more specialised instruction.
The apprenticeships covered the Ground Radar, Ground Wireless and Air Radio trades. During the mid-1960s, changes were made in the Apprentice Training system following the raising of the school leaving age from 15 to 16 and a two year apprenticeship was introduced and called the Craft Apprenticeship.
A further scheme called Technical Apprenticeships was introduced and successful graduates passed out as Corporals with an Ordinary National Certificate (ONC) as opposed to Junior Technicians. In 1970, a one-year course was introduced to be undertaken by Mechanic Apprentices but apprentice training finally finished in March 1976, ending 54 years of ‘Trenchard’s Brats’.

name: RAF Medical Services Memorial
description:
Royal Air Force Medical Services
The Royal Air Force Medical Services is a branch of the Royal Air Force providing health care to RAF service personnel at home and on deployed operations. The medical officers have specialist skills and provide essential support to aircrew, search and rescue missions and emergency relief operations around the world. 
The memorial to the Royal Air Force Medical Services is carved from an eight-foot (2.43 m) slab of Welsh slate and was created by Martin Cook. 
Its unusual position represents the angle of a scalpel blade, indicating the different angle the service takes from the rest of the RAF. A glass disc, inset at the top of the memorial, displays the Caduceus symbol - a winged staff entwined with two serpents. This symbol has its origin in Greek mythology and has since become associated with medicine

name: RAF Mountain Rescue Service (MRS), The
description:
RAF MOUNTAIN RESCUE
Was first organised during World War II to rescue aircrew from the large number of aircraft crashes then occurring due to minor navigational errors in conjunction with bad weather and resulting poor visibility when flying in the vicinity of high ground.

name: RAF No. 31 Squadron Memorial
description:
No. 31 Squadron 
Which has been in existence now for over 100 years. They are currently based at RAF Marham in Norfolk, flying Tornado aircraft.

name: RAF Physical Training Instructors
description:
RAF PHYSICAL TRAINING 
▪ The RAF School of physical training was formed on the 1st of April 1918. 
▪ The school's motto translates as 'Bold in Strength' which is symbolised in the Roebuck on the school's crest. The Roebuck was chosen because of its extraordinary alertness, energy, and physical fitness, qualities needed to be a PTI today.

name: RAF Search and Rescue Memorial
description:
RAF Search and Rescue Services
This memorial commemorates those who served in Britains Search and Rescue Organisations since February 1941 so “that others may live”.

name: Rail Industry Memorial
description:
THE RAILWAY INDUSTRY MEMORIAL
This memorial is the celebration of the magnificent achievements of the railway family which has served the United Kingdom with great distinction. On top of the memorial is a class F locomotive carved from matt black granite. The locomotive was designed in 1935 by William Stanier for the London Midland and Scottish Railway Company. They were built between 1935-46. 
On the rear of the memorial is a display of artwork depicting a series of railway activities.

name: Reconciliation Stone
description: No information available

name: Remembrance Glade
description:
Royal British Legion Remembrance Glade
The Glade is designed to provoke reflection and contemplation through symbolic forms, features and plants. It provides an ideal spot for those who just want to reflect on what Remembrance means to them. Denoting strength, the curved oak gateways provide an entrance into an inner sanctum. The glade is a perfect circle of white stemmed himalayan birches ‘Betula Jacquemontii’, creating a sense of harmony and unity. The mirror reflects truth and brings light.

name: Rhodesian African Rifles and Rhodesia Native Regiment Memorial
description:
Rhodesian African Rifles and Rhodesia Native Regiment Memorial 
Formed in May 1940 as the successor to the Rhodesia Native Regiment (RNR) the Rhodesian African Rifles (RAR) was the oldest regiment in the Rhodesian Army. 
The memorial’s design is based on the ruins of the 14th century city of Great Zimbabwe, near Masvingo in Zimbabwe, which is now a recognised World Heritage Site. 
The stone wall behind the memorial’s central column contains dedications honouring the fallen of the Rhodesia Native Regiment during the First World War and the 311 officers and men of the Rhodesian African Rifles who fell in campaigns during and since the Second World War. 
It was unveiled on 19 July 2015 by the Marquis of Salisbury KCVO, PC, DL President of the Rhodesian African Rifles Regiment Association.

name: Rhodesian Air Force Memorial
description:
Rhodesian Air Force 
The Rhodesian Air Force (RhAF) was an air force based in Salisbury (now Harare) which represented several entities under various names between 1935 and 1980: originally serving the British self-governing colony of Southern Rhodesia, it was the air arm of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland between 1953 and 31 December 1963; of Southern Rhodesia once again from 1 January 1964; and of the unrecognised nation of Rhodesia following its Unilateral Declaration of Independence from Britain on 11 November 1965. 
Named the Royal Rhodesian Air Force (RRAF) from 1954, the "Royal" prefix was dropped in 1970 when Rhodesia declared itself a republic – the official abbreviation changed appropriately. When the internationally recognised country of Zimbabwe came into being in 1980, the RhAF became the Air Force of Zimbabwe.

name: Roadpeace Wood
description:
Roadpeace Memorial/ Roadpeace
RoadPeace is the national charity for road crash victims. The RoadPeace memorial stone was erected on August 9th 2021.
The stone has been crafted by renowned carver and artist Martin Cook who has made pieces for Westminster Abbey, the British Museum, the Royal Family, RHS Chelsea Flower Show.
The stone was donated by England’s last working slate mine, Honister Slate Mine, based in the heart of the Lake District. The mine is at the top of Honister Pass – one of the steepest roads in the country – and slate is sourced from deep inside a neighbouring mountain, Fleetwith Pike. The memorial stone is at the RoadPeace Wood, an area at the NMA where individual trees have been planted to remember those who have lost their lives or been injured because of a road crash. Planting of trees in the RoadPeace Wood began in spring 2001 and the wood was named after the charity on 10 August 2002.

name: Robert Flockhart Memorial
description: Robert Flockhart Memorial

name: Rotary International and Rotary  Ridge
description:
ROTARY INTERNATIONAL MEMORIAL
Founded in 1905, the Rotary International is a movement of Men and Women who come together to create positive lasting change in our communities around the world. The organisation is currently present in over 200 countries. 
ROTARY RIDGE 
The hedge of golden Castlewellan cypress that acts as a windbreak and backdrop to the Arboretum, was first sponsored by local clubs in Rotary District 1060 as a tribute to the Rotary Clubs in Great Britain and Ireland and Rotary International, whose motto is “Service above Self”.  Trees are also dedicated to individual clubs and Rotarians.  Local Rotary Clubs have enthusiastically supported the Arboretum from the early years with individual Rotarians volunteering their skills, business contacts and expertise in many fields.

name: Royal Air Force Boy Entrants Memorial
description:
Royal Air Force Boy Entrants Memorial
Dedicated in memory of the many thousands of boy entrants who trained between 1934 and 1965 and to record their singular contribution to the Royal Air Force

name: Royal Air Force Cranwell Apprentices Memorial
description:
RAF Cranwell Apprentices
A Staffordshire blue brick plinth and memorial plaque, sponsored by the Royal Air Force Cranwell Apprentices Association in 2005, is dedicated to all aircraft apprentices who trained at Royal Air Force Cranwell from 1922 to 1952. The memorial was later upgraded with a new facing.
Cranwell is currently the home of the Royal Air Force College. It was taken over from the Royal Navy by the RAF on its formation in 1918, for officer cadet training, a role it fulfils to this day as the world’s first air force college..

name: Royal Air Force Dental Branch
description:
RAF Dentists 
The RAF Dental Branch was formed in 1930 as the importance of air power grew. By 1935 it was clear that the RAF needed to expand rapidly in response to developments in Europe. At the time, the RAF was served by 16 dental officers with permanent commissions, 29 with non-permanent/reserve commissions and 51 civilian practitioners. 
The need for improvements in oral health led to the creation of a course for dental hygienists at RAF Sidmouth in 1943. Each 16-week course trained selected Dental Surgery Attendants to scale and polish teeth, and to educate patients.

name: Royal Air Force Halton Apprentices Memorial Garden
description:
HALTON GROVE 
The memorial garden to the Halton Apprentices and its centrepiece, the RAF Apprentice wheel badge, remembers the association between Halton House in Buckinghamshire and the RAF which began in 1912, when the de Rothschild family allowed its use for training. 
Halton House was purchased by the Government from the de Rothschild family in 1919. 
The apprentices were known as 'Trenchard’s Brats', after Lord Trenchard the founder of the RAF (which was formed on 1st April 1918). 
The grove is a tribute to all those who passed through the training establishment learning various skilled trades. 
Usually the young men completed a 3-year apprenticeship with intakes from 1920 until 1993 and during those 73 years some 40,000 young men and women were trained. 
Frank Whittle, inventor of the jet engine, was a Halton apprentice. Here you will see a paviour dedicated to him and a larger one to Don Finlay the Olympic athlete who was also an apprentice. 
Another example of how people or organisations can be remembered the plaque and tree in honour of Sergeant Thomas GRAY, a former Halton Apprentice, who lost his life in 1940 when the plane in which he was navigator was shot down after a bombing raid to destroy a bridge in Belgium. 
He was awarded the Victoria Cross for bravery and his skill in navigating to the correct target, which they bombed successfully. 
Sergeant Gray had 6 brothers, 3 of whom were also killed in action during WW2. 
By pushing the buttons on the information board, you can hear audio presentations about some of the events and people involved at RAF Halton over the years. 
RAF Halton is still operational and nowadays provides training for most new recruits to the RAF, plus highly specialised training for members of all 3 armed services.

name: Royal Air Force Police Memorial
description:
The Royal Air Force (RAF) Police 
The Royal Air Force (RAF) Police has supported worldwide RAF operations since 1918. 
Peaking in 1945, the branch comprised 20,500 personnel and by 1948, RAF Police investigators had brought to justice the surviving killers of 50 RAF officers who had taken part in the Great Escape. 
His Majesty King George VI approved the RAF Police badge and motto in 1950 and throughout the 30 year ‘Cold War’ the branch provided security protection for the RAF’s nuclear deterrent. Having served in 66 countries since 1918, the RAF Police are today in the forefront of the war against terrorism, serving in current conflicts. The RAF Police Association was formed in 1984. 
The RAF nickname for their police is ‘Snowdrops’ because they wear white hats, and this is reflected in the flowers engraved on the edges of the stone.

name: Royal Air Force Regiment Memorial
description:
ROYAL AIR FORCE REGIMENT 
The Royal Air Force Regiment was formed in 1942 to provide specialist ground force protection for military airbases, without having to call upon the Army.
The large black granite memorial remembers all those who have lost their lives while serving in the Regiment, while inscribed on the reverse are listed the countries in which the Regiment had served up until the memorial’s dedication in 2001.
The pathway is shaped like an airport runway.
The Corps motto is “Per Ardua” which means “Through Adversity”
Peter Alliss, “The Voice of Golf” has a memorial stone in the garden as he served in the RFA Regiment

name: Royal Air Force Servicing Commando and Tactical Supply Wing Association Memorial
description:
RAF SERVICING COMMANDO AND TACTICAL SUPPLY WING 
Tactical Supply Wing (TSW) is a helicopter support unit of the RAF. TSW's primary role is supporting the deployment of helicopter operations, specialising in providing rotors-turning refuelling to helicopters and field refuelling of fixed-wing aircraft; this can done from the back of a transport aircraft, or deploy-able storage facilities, such as bowsers or pillow tanks, often in the field or at austere temporary sites. 
RAF Servicing Commando. Formed during WW2, served in the European and Far Eastern theatres of war before being disbanded in 1946. These units, called Servicing Commandos, would accompany the Allied Armies when they invaded Europe, either to make German airfields serviceable or to make operational the new airstrips built by the Army Airfield Construction Units. Eventually 12 Servicing Commandos were formed in the United Kingdom and three in the Middle East. The force consisted of 2,400 officers and men skilled in aircraft maintenance, armaments, communications and airfield activation skills and were capable of working on all types of aircraft to keep them flying under all kinds of conditions.

name: Royal Air Force Wing
description:
Royal Air Force Wing 
The RAF Memorial Grove (RAF Wing) comprises a collection of silver birch trees planted in the shape of an eagle’s wings.
The wing honours both the Fighter and Bomber Commands. The trees are individually dedicated to some of the Squadrons. The central ‘three bladed propeller’ made up of dwarf golden honeysuckle plants was sponsored by the Aircrew Association.

name: Royal Air Force Wood
description:
Royal Air Force Wood 
The Royal Air Force Wood is a woodland of mixed native trees alongside the River Tame dedicated to individuals who have served in the Royal Air Force. It includes a tree dedicated to Wing Commander Guy Gibson VC of ‘Dambusters’ fame.

name: Royal Air Forces Association Remembrance Garden (RAFA)
description:
Royal Air Force Association Remembrance Garden (RAFA)
The first national Remembrance Garden in memory of those that have served in the commonwealth air forces. The Eagle, named Winston, is made up of over 1000 hand forged feathers. 
The RAF Mountain Rescue, RAF Search and Rescue, RAF Medical, Dental and RAF Nurses (Princesses Marys) are all in a line and front the RAF area.

name: Royal and Sun Alliance Memorials
description:
Royal and Sun Alliance Insurance Limited Memorials
The memorials now displayed here underneath the railway bridge, were once located within the local o›ces of Royal and Sun Alliance companies across the UK. The memorials are made from diŽerent materials including bronze and marble. Together they commemorate over 915 employees from across the Royal Sun Alliance Insurance Group who served their country, and in many cases gave their lives during both World Wars. The memorials were originally unveiled by former companies that over the years all became part of the Group. Together, they create a lasting memorial and place of Remembrance, ensuring that the service given and sacrifices made by former colleagues throughout both World Wars will never be forgotten.

name: Royal Army Chaplains Memorial
description:
Royal Army Chaplains’ Department
The memorial is a tribute to all chaplains who have given their lives in war and conflict whilst serving in the Royal Army Chaplains’ Department (RAChD) as well as celebrating those who have served in it. Chaplains are ordained, Professionally Qualified Officers who have been selected to hold a commission in the Army. They wear the uniforms of the British Army and will accompany their soldiers wherever they go providing spiritual support, pastoral care and moral guidance to all, irrespective of religion or belief. Chaplains exercise leadership and management but do not command. They are non-combatants and they do not bear arms. Between 1914 and the end of hostilities in 1918, almost 4,400 Army Chaplains were recruited into uniform. Most of them saw service in the trenches and 179 lost their lives. Many were decorated for bravery with three being awarded the Victoria Cross. There are currently about 150 chaplains, known as ‘Padres’, serving with the British Army. Military veterans assisted blacksmiths in the creation of the memorial, which was unveiled by Lieutenant General James Everard CBE, Commander Land Forces on 21 July 2015. The ploughshare ends of the crossed swords reference the bible passage Isaiah 2:4 “they shall beat their swords into plowshares, and their spears into pruning hooks…

name: Royal Army Dental Corps (RADC) Memorial
description:
Royal Army Dental Corps 
The Army Dental Corps was formed on 11 January 1921. In recognition of their past services His Majesty King George VI granted the prefix ‘Royal’ on 28 November 1946, thus forming the Royal Army Dental Corps. 
The memorial was originally placed outside the old Connaught Hospital Building Aldershot. The sole member of the RADC remembered as an individual is Sergeant “Geordie” Muldoon who was killed in Northern Ireland on 23 March 1973. He is also remembered in the Ulster Grove. 
The memorial was originally placed in 1948 at the Corps Depot and Training Establishment at Connaught Hospital, Aldershot. On closure of the establishment in 1973, the memorial was moved to the new Training Centre in Evelyn Woods Road, Aldershot. It remained there until 2011, when it was relocated to the Arboretum, as the Corps’ centre of gravity was 
no longer in Aldershot. However, the Corps Standard and Book of Remembrance remain in the Corps Chapel in the Royal Garrison Church of All Saints in Aldershot. The memorial moved to the Arboretum in the Corps’ 90th anniversary year. The Army Dental Corps was formed in 1921 and granted the ‘Royal’ prefix in 1946. The Corps’ motto is ‘Ex Dentibus Ensis’, which means ‘from the teeth a sword’. This is taken from the legend of Cadmus who, in Greek mythology, slew a dragon that had killed his companions. On instructions from Athena, he sowed the dragon’s teeth in the ground and a race of fierce men sprang up called Sparti. The RADC provides dental services to members of the British Army. Those in the Corps are themselves soldiers. 
This memorial was refurbished in 2021 and a new dedication stone was unveiled by the Duchess of Gloucester, Colonel in Chief, on 8th September 2021.

name: Royal Army Medical Corps (RAMC) Memorial
description:
Royal Army Medical Corp 
This large woodland has red and gold leaved trees individually dedicated to members of the Royal Army Medical Corps (RAMC), which was formed in 1898. 
There are memorial plinths at both ends of the avenue of purple leaved trees planted as a tribute to the 29 members who were awarded the Victoria Cross, two of them gaining the award twice (and one George Cross). In the centre stands a magnificent statue by Alan Beattie Herriot depicting a member of the Corps bringing a wounded soldier back from the battlefield. 
The second memorial (which was installed earlier) shown above relates to the history of the rod and serpent goes back to ancient Greece. Aesculapius lived about 1265BC and was a doctor famous for bringing the dead back to life. Pluto, the God of the Underworld, appalled at not gaining the souls of the dead, complained to Jupiter, the head of all Gods, who obliged by slaying Aesculapius with a thunderbolt, represented by the rod. After his death, Aesculapius became a God worshiped in hundreds of temples, which became places of healing and had a pit containing a harmless snake with a forked tongue believed to have healing properties. Ever since, the rod and the serpent have become a symbol of medicine throughout the world. (NB Different spellings depending on whether the Greek or Latin names are used. The RAMC internet site uses Roman names.) 
Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth The Queen Mother was Colonel in Chief of the Corps and the RAMC planted a tree in the grove to commemorate her 100th birthday. 
The following RAMC holders of the Victoria Cross are recorded by plaques at this memorial: 
Crimean War 
Assistant Surgeon (later Lieutenant Colonel) Thomas Edgerton Hale VC 
Surgeon (later Surgeon General Sir) James Mouat VC, KCB 
Assistant Surgeon (later Surgeon Major) Henry Thomas Sylvester VC 
_Indian Mutiny 
Assistant Surgeon William Bradshaw VC 
Captain (later Major) Thomas Joseph Crean VC, DSO 
Surgeon (later Surgeon General Sir) Anthony Dickson Home VC, KCB 
Surgeon (later Deputy Surgeon General) Joseph Jee VC, CB 
Assistant Surgeon Valentine Munbee McMaster VC 
Staff Surgeon (later Surgeon General) Herbert Taylor Reade VC, CB 
1st Boer War 
L Corporal (later Corporal) John Joseph Farmer VC 
_2nd Boer War 
Major (Later Surgeon General Sir) William Babtie VC 
Lieutenant Henry Edward Manning Douglas VC, DSO 
Lieutenant (later Colonel) Edgar Thomas Edgar Inkson VC 
Lieutenant William Henry (later Major General) Snyder Nickerson VC, CB, CMG 
World War 1 
Captain Harold Ackroyd VC, MC 
Lieutenant William Barnsley Allen VC, MC 
Captain Noel Geoffrey Chavasse VC & bar 
Captain John Fox-Russell VC, MC 
Captain John Leslie Green VC

name: Royal Army Pay Corps
description:
Royal Army Pay Corps 
RAPC Memorial - Fide Et Fiducia (In Faith and Confidence) 
In celebration of the service given by those who wore the Royal Army Pay Corps or any of the antecedent cap badges ensuring their part in history is recorded for future generations. It is not primarily a memorial to those who made the ultimate sacrifice, although it serves that purpose as well, but it embraces everyone who served in the Corps. It is a project of regimental significance, supported by generous donations from our membership. 
Materials Used 
The plinth is made of Cumbrian Sandstone. The two books of regulation which surmount it are Forest of Dean sandstone. The plinth dimensions are 1300mm (l) x 800mm (w) x 1850mm (h) with a 300mm granite apron surrounding the monument. 
The lion was cast in bronze in Birmingham and then nickel plated. 
Name of Designers 
Nick Johnson – Master Monument Mason. 
Andy DeComyn – Sculptor. 
Age of Memorial 
In 2022, Nick Johnson (Master Monument Mason) and Andy DeComyn (Sculptor) were appointed by the Trustees of the RAPC Regimental Association, with ground broken on site a year later. The dedication ceremony was held on 14th June 2023. 
Symbolism 
The memorial shows a lion standing atop the two most commonly-used books of reference for the RAPC - the Regulations for Army Allowances and Charges and the Manual of Army Pay Duties. The lion is guarding a bag of coin, which lies open between its front paws. 
This represents the RAPC’s twin roles; it was both the Army’s guardian of the public purse, ensuring that monies were properly disbursed and correctly accounted for, but also the soldier’s guarantor of receiving fair, accurate and timely pay and allowances – not things that could be taken for granted in previous ages. 
The plinth is carved with the four cap badges that make up our formal antecedence, although the role itself dates back many centuries: 
The Army Pay Department 
The Army Pay Corps 
The Corps of Military Accountants 
The Royal Army Pay Corps (prior to being granted the regimental motto Fide Et Fiducia) 
The RAPC Memorial features prominently on the Army Parade next to the Beat. It offers those who served in the RAPC a place to contemplate their service and to remember old comrades – the RAPC was a widely-dispersed corps in which you served with every part of the Army but seldom with the same RAPC friends. It also offers families a unique opportunity to go somewhere to respect the service given by a relative who served in the RAPC. The RAPC disbanded in 1992 and its regimental homes of Devizes and later Worthy Down have been redeveloped or re-purposed. This monument is the RAPC’s only Corps memorial.

name: Royal Army Physical Training Corps (RAPTC) Memorial
description: Memorial Opposite the Basra Wall on the raised grass area is a memorial to The Royal Army Physical Training Corps (RAPTC), which is responsible for physical fitness and physical education and was formed in 1860 as the Army Gymnastic StaŽ. The memorial is made from black polished granite with a sandstone top and is shaped like a gymnastic vaulting box. The design has the inscription, motto and badge of the RAPTC together with the dates reflecting the name changes of the Corps. The sides of the memorial are inscribed with the words of the RAPTC Collect and Corps March. The memorial stands on a stone pavement with date inscribed sandstone balls located at each corner.

name: Royal Army Veterinary Corps (RAVC) Memorial
description:
Royal Army Veterinary Corps 
This black granite memorial was dedicated in May 2014 in the presence of HRH The Princess Royal, Princess Anne. The engravings depict the work of the Corps with horses and dogs, from WW1 up to the present day.
It is interesting to note that the first veterinary surgeon joined in 1796, when their primary aim was to ensure that animals were properly cared for, so maximizing their fitness for duty. That founding principle still applies today.
Note the three red plaques behind, honouring three members of the RAVC killed in action during recent times:
Corporal Bryan CRIDDLE killed in 1973 by a remotely detonated ‘milk churn’ bomb in Northern Ireland. His dog, Jason, was blown 30 yards away by the explosion, but survived and attended his handler’s funeral at Blockley, nr Chipping Campden
Lance Corporal Ken ROWE killed with his sniffer dog Sasha, during a Taliban ambush in Afghanistan in July 2008
Lance Corporal Liam TASKER killed by small arms fire in March 2011 in Afghanistan. His dog Theo suffered a seizure and died on returning to Camp Bastion. Theo was awarded a posthumous Dickin Medal
Other famous animal winners of the Dickin Medal were:
Gustave (Pigeon) - Brought the first Commercial news of the D-Day to the UK
Paddy (Pigeon) – Quickest time to bring news from Normandy back to UK
Duke of Normandy (Pigeon) -,Brought news of the capture of a gun battery at Merville by Paras of the 21st Army Group Bing (Dog) - Bing was trained to locate the enemy and protect military personnel,
The Royal Army Veterinary Corps is responsible for the provision, training and care of animals and is part of the British Army.
The Army Veterinary Service was established by public demand in 1796 to address the welfare of army horses. It became the Army Veterinary Corps in 1903 and the Royal Army Veterinary Corps in 1918. In 1942 it amalgamated with the Remount Service and from 1946 became responsible for managing the Army’s dog resources.

name: Royal Artillery Garden
description:
ROYAL ARTILLERY 
The Royal Artillery dates back to the 18th century and grew to become larger than the Royal Navy after the Second World War. 
The garden has two seats designed in the shape of gun carriages 
Charcoal from the alder was used in early gunpowder and the village name of Alrewas, just down the road, is believed to derive from the ancient English name of Alder Wash meaning “alder trees at the water” (the River Trent runs at the side of Alrewas). 
UBIQUE is a Latin word meaning ‘everywhere’ (The Royal Artillery served “everywhere “ that the British armed forces go) 
Also remembered in this garden are the Royal Artillery Horse.

name: Royal Australian Air Force Memorial
description:
Royal Australian Air Force
Eucalyptus trees planted in line with the lime trees of Millennium Avenue represent local associations with 463 / 467 Squadrons Royal Australian Air Force.

name: Royal Auxiliary Air Force Memorial
description:
The Royal auxiliary Air force 
Similar to the Territorial Army, whose members receive payment for keeping up to date with training and may be called up for active service.

name: Royal British Legion Poppy Field
description:
Royal British Legion (RBL) Poppy Field 
In June, the wildflower display with the distinguishable poppy is simply stunning. The 200-metre meadow is lined with 44 tall English oaks ‘Quercus robur’, intended, as they grow to provide a dramatic tree-lined vista.

name: Royal Canadian Air Force Memorial
description:
Royal Canadian Air Force 
It is made of three pieces of granite in the colours of their national flag, red, white, red. With their national emblem of a maple leaf on the top, it is designed that on the 11th hour of the 11th day of the 11th month, if the sun is shining, the leaf on the top of the memorial casts a shadow on a corresponding maple leaf set into the grass.

name: Royal Corps of Signals Memorial
description:
ROYAL CORPS OF SIGNALS 
The statue is of Mercury, messenger to the Gods, which is also the cap badge of the Royal Corps of Signals. He is affectionately known as Jimmy, possibly after Jimmy Emblem, who was a member of the Corps and Army Boxing Champion in 1924, though this is not certain. Take note of ‘the wind’ on which Mercury is standing. 
The Royal Signals was formed in 1920. It was formerly The Royal Engineers Signal Service. 
The Signals provide communications and ensure the passage of information, which is vital to successful military operations. 
The motto is ‘Certa Cito’, which translates to ‘sure and swift’. 
Colonel-in-Chief is the Princess Royal.

name: Royal Dragoon Guards Memorial
description:
The Royal Dragoon Guards Regimental Memorial 
The Royal Dragoon Guards – ‘Our Castle, Our Strength and Shield’. The Royal Dragoon Guards was formed in 1992, as a result of the amalgamation of the 4/7th Royal Dragoon Guards and the 5th Royal Inniskilling Dragoon Guards. 
The two antecedent regiments were themselves the result of amalgamations in 1922. The 4th/7th Royal Dragoon Guards formed from amalgamation of the 4th Royal Irish Dragoon Guards and the 7th (Princess Royal’s) Dragoon Guards, and the 5th Royal Inniskilling Dragoon Guards formed from amalgamation of the 5th (Princess Charlotte of Wales’) Dragoon Guards and the 6th (Inniskilling) Dragoons. 
All four of the original antecedent regiments were raised between 1685 and 1689, during the protracted contest for the English throne between James II and William of Orange. 
This memorial is dedicated to all those who fought, served and died while serving in The Royal Dragoon Guards and its antecedent regiments, from 1685 to the present day. Accordingly, the memorial carries the cap badges of the regiments, together with the motto of The Royal Dragoon Guards: Quis Separabit (who shall separate us), which is taken from the eighth chapter of St Paul’s Letter to the Romans. 
Age of Memorial 
The current memorial replaces an earlier memorial installed in 2008. The trustees of the Regimental Charity, informed by both the serving and veteran cohorts of the Regiment, agreed the original memorial failed to capture the spirit and tradition of the Regiment and those who had served it. The current memorial was dedicated on Saturday 11 March 2023. 
Symbolism 
The Memorial is cut in the shape of a castle, to represent the Watergate that forms part of the ramparts of Enniskillen Castle, where the 6th (Inniskilling) Dragoons were raised in 1689. 
A device representing the Watergate was worn on the uniforms of the 6th (Inniskilling) Dragoons and later, embroidered onto their Regimental Guidon in 1751, when the first regulations standardising regimental dress were introduced. The Watergate continued to be worn on the uniform of the 5th Royal Inniskilling Dragoon Guards and to be carried on its Regimental Standard. Today, the Watergate is carried on the Regimental Standard of The Royal Dragoon Guards and forms the centrepiece of the Regimental cap badge, mounted in the centre of the Star of St Patrick, the cap badge of the 4th Royal Irish Dragoon Guards and later the 4/7th Royal Dragoon Guards. 
Green was the regimental colour worn on the facings, (collar and cuffs) of the 5th Dragoon Guards and continued in the uniform of the 5th Royal Inniskilling Dragoon Guards. Today, that tradition continues in the colour of the Regiment’s beret, and the trousers worn with barrack, service and ceremonial dress. 
The engravings on the face of the memorial represent the cap badges of the antecedent regiments. 
The 4th Royal Irish Dragoon Guards and 4/7th Royal Dragoon Guards using the Star of St Patrick: the former with a shamrock surmounting the cross of St Patrick and the Regimental Motto, Quis Separabit, in the surrounding garter; the latter has the Princess Royal’s coronet at its centre, surmounting the cross of St George. 
The 5th (Princess Charlotte of Wales’) Dragoon Guards has the white horse of Hannover at its centre, surrounded by the letter V representing the Roman number 5 and the letters DG to represent Dragoon Guards. Around the garter is the Regimental motto, Vestigia Nulla Retrorsum (Never a Rearward Step). 
This also served as the motto of the 5th Royal Inniskilling Dragoon Guards, whose cap badge was a monogram of the 5th Dragoon Guards, surmounted by the reigning monarch’s crown. 
The cap badge of the 7th (Princess Royal’s) Dragoon Guards depicts a lion rampant surmounting the Princess Royal’s coronet. The lion rampant was the family crest of Lord Ligonier, who commanded the Regiment in 1720. The Regiment was renamed the 7th Dragoon Guards in 1788, the name carried in the scroll below the Princess Royal’s coronet. 
Lastly, the Watergate of the 6th (Inniskilling) Dragoons, flying the flag of St George mounted on a scroll carrying the name Inniskilling (the Island of Kathleen), which is the traditional Irish spelling for the town of Enniskillen. 
Below the cap badges, in silver, is the Regimental Motto (Quis Separabit). This was the original motto of the Order of St Patrick, created by King George III in 1783. This chivalrous order lasted until the partition of Ireland in 1922, although King Charles III remains the Sovereign of the Order to this day. His Majesty King Charles III is the current Colonel in Chief of the Regiment.

name: Royal Electrical and Mechanical Engineers (REME) Memorial
description:
ROYAL ELECTRICAL AND MECHANICAL ENGINEERS (REME) 
The Corps of Royal Electrical and Mechanical Engineers maintains the equipment used by the British Army. They serve wherever in the world the Army is deployed.
The memorial is dedicated to past and present members of the Corps and depicts both their former and current badges.
During WW2 the Army had difficulty providing training in maintenance and repair of its increasingly sophisticated vehicles and weapons. REME was established in 1942 to meet these technological challenges.
The corps has the rare distinction of being granted the Royal prefix on the day of its formation.
Its motto is ‘Arte et Marte’ which translates to ‘By skill and fighting’.
Major Ivan Hirst of REME took on the Volkswagen plant in Wolfsburg in 1945, initially to make and repair cars for the British Army. Eventually, he helped turn VW into today’s well-known brand.

name: Royal Engineers (RE) Memorial
description:
ROYAL ENGINEER 
The garden to its left honour’s members of the ROYAL ENGINEERS. The blocks of stone are set on metal supports in a very technically challenging way, to demonstrate the Engineers’ skills. The stones came from the Falkland Islands. 
The Royal Engineers are combat soldiers with a technical edge and have a role in every area of the battlefield. At the front they support the rest of the Army, bridging rivers, using explosives to destroy bridges or clearing routes through minefields. 
The Royal Engineers trace their origins back to the military engineers brought to England by William the Conqueror and claim 900 years of unbroken service to the Crown. However, the origins of the modern corps along with the Royal Artillery lie in the Board Of Ordnance established in the 15th century, In1716 the board formed the Royal Regiment of Artillery and established a corps of engineers consisting entirely of Officers 
The corps has no battle honours their motto is Ubique and Quo Fas et Gloria Ducunt (Everywhere & where Right and Glory lead us) the same as the Royal Artillery. The Motto signifies that the corps has seen action in all the major conflicts of the British army and most of the minor ones. 
In 1911 the corps formed its Air battalion the forerunner of the RFC and the RAF. 
Several corps have been formed from the Royal Engineers 
Royal Flying Corps 
Royal Corps of Signals 
REME 
Royal Corps of Transport 
Royal Logistic Corps 
The Royal Albert Hall was designed by Captain Francis Fowke and Major-General Henry Y D Scott, Captain (later Major-General sir Joshua Jebb) designed Pentonville prison. 
55 British and Commonwealth Sappers have been awarded the Victoria Cross 
Notable VC winners were: 
John Merriott Rouse Chard. Officer commanding at Rorkes Drift Jan 1879 
Thomas Frank Durrant. Operation chariot St Nazaire 28 March 1942 unique in that it is the only award given to a soldier in a Naval action, and unusual in have been suggested by a German Officer. 
Phillip Neave 1914 at Neuve Chapelle the only man to hold a VC and an Olympic Gold Medal.(Studied at Cheltenham College)

name: Royal Fleet Auxiliary Memorial
description:
Royal Fleet Auxiliary (RFA) Memorial 
Dedicated in the presence of the RFA Commodore-in-Chief, His Royal Highness The Earl of Wessex. The Royal Fleet Auxiliary is a civilian-manned fleet of vessels owned by the United Kingdom, and provides support for various functions of the Royal Navy, such as resupplying fuel and ammunition to Navy ships while at sea. The triangular plinth of polished granite represents the bow of an RFA ship, and is surrounded by diŽerent coloured stones forming the shape of the ship’s bow wave.

name: Royal Fleet Auxiliary Ship 'Sir Percivale' Anchor
description:
ST PERCIVALE (ANCHOR) 
Sir Percivale was a Round table Class Logistics Landing Ship, she was the sister ship to Sir Tristram and Sir Galahad. St Percivale landed troops in St Carlos Bay was the first British Vessel to enter Port Stanley following the Argentinian Surrender. Sir Percivale was later used to support British operations in the Balkans.
The Sir Tristram was badly damaged in the Falklands Conflict but was returned to the UK at the end of the conflict, repaired and returned to service.
Following an air attack by Argentinian Aircraft on 24 May 1982 Sir Galahad was so badly damaged that she was deemed to be unrepairable and was towed away and sunk at the end of the conflict.
The central glade of the Merchant Navy Convoy Wood is an appropriate home to one of the anchors from Royal Fleet Auxiliary (RFA) Sir Percivale (a Round Table Class landing ship logistics, commissioned in 1968), donated by the Merchant Navy Welfare Board.
Outside the two World Wars, the largest loss of Merchant Navy lives was during the Falklands conflict. Sir Percivale landed troops in San Carlos Bay and was the first British vessel to enter Port Stanley following the Argentinian surrender. She later served in the Gulf War of 1991, was deployed in support of British operations in the Balkans and was present at the handover of Hong Kong to China.
She was decommissioned on 17 August 2004 and had been crewed throughout her life by officers and ratings of the Merchant Navy.
anchor was dedicated on 8 June 2011, the anniversary of the bombing of Sir Percivale’s sister ships Sir Galahad and Sir Tristram in Bluff Cove during the Falklands conflict in 1982.

name: Royal Gloucestershire, Berkshire and Wiltshire Regiment Memorial
description:
ROYAL GLOUCESTERSHIRE, BERKSHIRE AND WILTSHIRE REGIMENT
This amalgamated regiment was formed in 1994 and became part of the Rifles in 2007.
It was the only regiment in the British Army allowed to wear cap badges on the front and rear of their headdress. The second badge was awarded to their forebears (28th Regiment of Foot) for fighting ‘back-to-back’ against Napoleon's French Army in Egypt at the Battle of Alexandria in 1801. The rear rank was given the order to ‘about turn’ so the front and rear rank fought back-to-back.

name: Royal Hampshire Regiment Memorial
description:
Royal Hampshire Regiment 
The Royal Hampshire Regiment was formed following the amalgamation of North Hampshire Regiment (37th Foot) and South Hampshire Regiment (67th Foot) to become the Hampshire Regiment in 1881. 
It was awarded the title ‘Royal’ in 1946 for distinguished service in the Second World War. 
Throughout its history the Regiment has served in the major campaigns. It was amalgamated with the Queen’s Regiment in 1992 to form The Princess of Wales’s Royal Regiment. 
After the 67th had served in India from 1805 – 1826, it was decreed that the Colours and other appointments were to bear the figure of the Royal Tiger with the word ‘India’. 
The memorial’s plinth, which was created by stone mason Nick Johnson, tells the story of the Regiment both graphically and in words. The Bengal Tiger on top of the plinth was created by sculptor Sara Ingleby-Mackenzie.

name: Royal Hong Kong Police Memorial
description:
Royal Hong Kong Police Memorial
The Hong Kong Police Force was founded in 1844, when Hong Kong Island was ceded to Britain by China following the First Opium War. The first Police O›cers were European and Indian ex-soldiers, together with some locally recruited Chinese. In 1845, Charles May, a former London Metropolitan Police Superintendent, took command of the 171-strong Force. Hong Kong grew in importance as a trading port and, following the Japanese Occupation during the Second World War, as a manufacturing, financial and tourist centre. The Force was honoured with the title ‘Royal’ following very serious disturbances arising from the Cultural Revolution which took place in China in 1967. By 1997, when sovereignty of Hong Kong returned to China, the population of Hong Kong was some 6.5 million people, and the Force consisted of 28,000 regular police o›cers, with 5,700 auxiliaries and 6,000 civilian staff.

name: Royal Indian Navy and Indian Army Memorial
description:
Royal Indian Navy and Army Memorial 
Between the Yangtze Incident and Far East Air Force memorials, trees from the Indian sub-continent such as Kashmir rowan, cedar and Bhutan pine have been planted as a tribute to those who served in the Royal Indian Navy (1934 – 1947) and Indian Army. The memorial lies within a small area surrounded by a hedge. 
The British Indian Army (1858 – 1947) was a force recruited locally during the British Colonisation of India and commanded by British and Indian officers. Substantial numbers of Indian soldiers served in both World Wars. Note also the memorials to the Dogra, Baluch and Sikh soldiers. 
The Royal Indian Navy had its origins in the East India Company’s Marine, later the Bombay Marine. From 1830 to 1858 the Bombay Marine became the Indian Navy. After the end of Company rule in 1857 the name reverted to Bombay Marine until in 1877 it was renamed Her Majesties Indian Marine. In 1892 it became the Royal Indian Marine. With the introduction of the Indian Navy (Discipline) Act 1934, the Royal Indian Navy was formally inaugurated on 2nd October 1934; its ships carried the prefix HMIS. During WW2 the service greatly expanded, and the Women’s Royal Indian Naval Service was established. Two of its sloops HMIS Sutlej and HMIS Jumna played a role in the invasion of Sicily. In 1947 the Navy was split between India and Pakistan. From 1950 when India became a republic the ships have been prefixed INS.

name: Royal Leicestershire Regiment Memorial ; Leicestershire Tigers
description:
Royal Leicestershire Regiment 
The memorial to The Royal Leicestershire Regiment was dedicated on 27 September 2014 – the 326th anniversary of the founding of the Regiment.
The Regiment was conferred with the title ‘Royal’ by King George VI in 1946 in recognition of its services during the Second World War, where it was represented by a battalion in every theatre: an almost unique distinction.The Regiment takes its nickname – ‘The Tigers’ – from its badge, which incorporates a Royal Tiger and the inscription ‘Hindoostan’. The badge was awarded to the Regiment in 1825 by King George IV, in recognition of its exemplary conduct in India.
The Royal Leicestershire Regiment was awarded a total of 73 Battle Honours including those received for service at the battle of Namur in 1695 to the campaign in Korea in 1952. Over the years, four members of the Regiment were awarded the Victoria Cross.
The Regiment’s last operational tour was in Borneo in 1963-64, very soon after which it was incorporated into The Royal Anglian Regiment.
The memorial comprises a large Irish Blue limestone plinth, donated by André Vrona, of Ketton Stone from near Stamford, with an impressive tiger on the top of the plinth which was created by Theodore Gillick of Stamford.

name: Royal Logistics Corps Memorial
description:
ROYAL LOGISTIC CORPS 
Comprising different Corps and Units, all of whom supply services, food, ammunition, stores, transport, postal and courier service. The memorial, surrounded by edible plants symbolising the Catering Corps, was dedicated in 2000.
A Mulberry Tree, Morus, is dedicated to Captain Lisa Jade Head. Lisa was an army officer and the first female bomb disposal officer to be killed on operations. She was mortally injured in Helmand Province on 18 April 2011, 22 days after arriving in Afghanistan for the second time, while attempting to disable a cluster of improvised explosive devices. She disabled one device, but was hit when a second device in the chain went off. She was flown back to the Queen Elizabeth hospital in Birmingham. She died the following day.
• The RLC was formed in April 1993 by merging the Royal Corps of Transport, the Royal Army Ordnance Corps, the Royal Pioneer Corps, the Army Catering Corps and the Royal Engineers Postal and Courier Service.
• The RLC is the British Army’s largest Corps. From storing and moving equipment, fuel, ammunitions and supplies to cooking meals and fixing IT equipment and delivering mail, it supports Army operations around the world, by land sea and air
• The corps is responsible for thousands of motor vehicles as well as the Army’s storage, ordnance and fuel depots. It also operates the Army's air dispatch service, and maritime and rail transport. It provides pioneer labour and cooks, and is involved in explosive ordnance disposal.
• Members of the corps help manage and maintain IT systems that aid logistics, and fix problems with network infrastructures and operating systems. They ensure the secure delivery of mail for all three-armed services and also serve as photographers.
• In recent years, the corps has deployed units to Northern Ireland during the final years of ‘the Troubles’, served with the British Army of the Rhine in Germany, and undertaken peace-keeping duties in Cyprus, Bosnia and Kosovo (1999). It also served in the recent conflicts in Afghanistan (2001-14) and Iraq (2003-11).

name: Royal Mail Association Memorial
description:
Royal Mail Lines 
The memorial comprises a commemorative plaque and a line of trees dedicated to the ships of the Royal Mail Lines which were sunk or destroyed during the Second World War and to all who, as a result of enemy action gave their lives whilst serving aboard them. The memorial was donated by the Royal Mail Association.

name: Royal Malaysia Police Memorial
description:
ROYAL MALAYSIA POLICE MEMORIAL
The memorial is dedicated to all ranks of the former Malayan, Singaporean and Bornean Police Forces, subsequently united into the Royal Malaysia Police. All these forces served in the Second World War and subsequent counterinsurgency campaigns fighting alongside Commonwealth military forces between 1948 and 1989. In the ‘Malayan Emergency’, the Royal Malaysia Police suffered 1,300 fatalities.

name: Royal Marines Association
description:
THE ROYAL MARINES
The Corps was established in 1755 but their origins can be traced back to 1664 
The Marines were formed as the Royal Navy's infantry troops and were granted the "Royal" prefix by King George III in 1802, symbolised by the Lion and Crown of their badge. 
Their motto is 'Per Mare, Per Terram", which translates as "By Sea, By Land". They have been involved in every conflict since WW2. 
Ships’ Captains would always refer to the Royal Marines as "My Marines"; this is because, unlike the Royal Navy, the Marines have never mutinied. 
This memorial is of Dartmoor granite to represent the one part of the country that most Royal Marines will associate with their training. 
The Corps was established in 1755 but their origins can be traced back to 28 October 1664 when they were initially created as the Duke of York and Albany’s Maritime Regiment of Foot. 
The Marines became the Royal Marines in 1802, an honour conferred by King George III, symbolised by the Lion and Crown on their badge. Many brave men and their families are remembered in this reflective place. 
Any family that wishes to place a brass plaque on the benches, so that a loved one is remembered by name, can do so through the Royal Marines Association.

name: Royal Military Police Association Memorial
description:
ROYAL MILITARY POLICE 
This memorial was originally sited at the RMP headquarters in Chichester and was unveiled by the Queen in 1982. 
The model for the statue was Corporal Fox, and it has since been known as Foxy. Punishment for a minor offence was to polish the brass plaque on Foxy. He is sculptured in a resin which gives a cast bronze appearance. 
Formed in 1877 and known as Red Caps, they became part of the Adjutant General Corps in 1992. There are around 2,500 MP's in the British Army today.

name: Royal National Lifeboat Institution (RNLI)
description:
Royal National Lifeboat Institution (RNLI)
This memorial has been designed to reflect the work of the Royal National Lifeboat Institution (RNLI) crews and the relationship between crew members, a rescued person and all their families whose lives become interwoven during a rescue. It is intended not only as a celebration and recognition of the work of the RNLI but also to honour those crew members and people who have lost their lives saving others. The coastal scene creates a beautiful space in which to contemplate and reflect on the work of the RNLI. It embodies the journey of one member of a volunteer crew. As you enter you will see the statue of a lifeboat crew member. Take the path going to the left, and depending on the season, the colours of the plants are muted like the sea on a calm day. The stone monoliths represent more crew members heading out on a rescue mission. As you pass by the groynes and beach, you overlook the water. Throughout the year, the colours change to shades of red to embody danger and stormy waters. The stone cairn represents those rescued encircled by the crew and the last stone monolith on your journey symbolises the crews and survivors returning to safety and their families. In the north corner 29 trees reflect the pattern of the tides, which are so significant in the lives of lifeboat crews; there are 29 days (and 12 hours) between full moons.

name: Royal Naval Association Uttoxeter Memorial
description:
Royal Naval Association – Uttoxeter 
The memorial plaque is dedicated to all members of The Royal Navy, The Royal Marines and The Merchant Navy who have served in H.M. Forces from the Uttoxeter and Districts of Staffordshire.

name: Royal Naval Medical Services Memorial
description:
ROYAL NAVY MEDICAL BRANCH Map 
The Royal Naval Medical Service memorial commemorates the dedication that generations of 'medics', from all the constituent parts of the RNMS, have given to the care of patients and the advancement of naval medicine. 
The memorial was unveiled on 23 September 2016 by Surgeon Commodore P J Buxton OBE QHP FRCR RN Medical Director General (Naval). 
There have been medical personnel on HM Ships throughout history; initially referred to as "Saw - bones" because their main task treating sailors injured in battle usually meant limb amputations! 
In 1833, the Admiralty established the Medical Branch and deemed that all naval vessels should carry a "Sick Berth Attendant". 
Medical ratings both work and train alongside the QARNNS both at sea and in hospitals. 
They serve in all Naval establishments both at home and abroad and are present on board most Naval vessels and as field medics in the Royal Marines

name: Royal Naval Patrol Service Memorial ; 'HMS Europa, (RNPS)'
description:
ROYAL NAVAL PATROL SERVICE (Harry Tate’s Navy)
As part of its preparation for WW2, the Admiralty requisitioned fishing boats and their crews and named them the Royal Naval Patrol Service, which came under the auspices of HMS Europa. They were trained to use sonar for mine clearance and locating German U -Boats. Over the course of the war, the number of boats rose to 6,000, crewed by 70,000 men. HMS Europa was a Royal Navy Shore establishment active during World War 2 as the central depot for the Royal Naval Patrol Service (RNPS) It was established after the commandeering of Sparrows Nest Gardens, a private residence in Lowestoft

name: Royal Navy Artificers Memorial
description: Royal Navy Artificers Memorial

name: Royal Navy Coastal Forces Memorial
description:
Royal Naval Coastal Forces Memorial
The Coastal Forces Veterans’ Association was formed in 1974 by crews who served in the Royal Navy from 1939 to 1957 in the ‘Little Ships’.

name: Royal Navy Engineers Benevolent Society Memorial
description:
The Royal Navy Engineers Benevolent Society (RNEBS) Memorial 
The RNEBS supports the Engineering Artificers and Technicians of the Royal Navy. 
The Society was established to promote intellectual and general welfare and the provision of Death or Invaliding Benefits for Members. Any member of the Engineering Branch serving in the Royal Navy is eligible to join the Society. 
The Royal Navy Engineers Benevolent Society (RNEBS) Memorial was originally dedicated on 1 October 2011. It was refurbished and re-dedicated by The Reverend Paul Bentley, himself an ex-artificer, on 2 October 2016. 
The memorial sits on a circular stone terrace and is encircled by a dark inset band displaying the Royal Navy Engineers Benevolent Society in white lettering. The face of the memorial displays the coloured badge of the RNEBS above an inscription to commemorate Royal Naval Artificers who gave their lives in service of their country. 
Carved into either the side of the memorial are motifs associated with Engineering Artificers and Technicians. The top displays the carved face of a Green Man, a symbol that is also seen at the bottom of the RNEBS badge together with the motto Tubal Cain – a character referenced in the book of Genesis which suggests he may have been the very first artificer in brass and iron (KJV).

name: Royal Norfolk Regiment, Suffolk Regiment and Cambridgeshire Regiment Memorial ; Anglian Regiment
description:
ROYAL NORFOLK Regt; SUFFOLK Regt; CAMBRIDGESHIRE Regt
The Norfolk and Suffolk Regiments can both trace their history back to 1685, when they were formed to suppress a rebellion. They underwent a number of re-organisations and changes of role over the years, but eventually came together in 1959 as the 1st East Anglian Regiment. They were finally disbanded in 1967. The Cambridgeshire Regiment was more of a Territorial Army or volunteers’ regiment, dating back to 1860 but was also disbanded in 1967. Many of them were in Singapore at the time of its surrender in 1942 and spent the rest of the war as prisoners of the Japanese, with the awful conditions and experiences that we now know about. Their lineage is carried on today in the Royal Anglian Regiment.

name: Royal Norwegian Navy
description:
Royal Norwegian Navy 
Sponsored by the Royal Norwegian Navy this avenue holds native species of silver birch trees from Norway together with memorial plaques commemorating Norway’s important involvement in protecting the Merchant Convoys of the Second World War.

name: Royal Observer Corps
description:
ROYAL OBSERVER CORPS
The Royal Observer Corps was a Civil Defence organisation operating between October 1925 - December 1995 which was tasked with spotting, identifying and tracking enemy aircraft.
Composed mainly of civilian spare-time volunteers, ROC personnel wore a Royal Air Force style uniform. They were originally called the Observer Corps but were awarded the title Royal by King George VI in April 1941, in recognition of service carried out by Observer Corps personnel during the Battle of Britain.
The Corps was disbanded in 1995 following the end of the ‘Cold War’.

name: Royal Observer Corps Seaborne Wing
description: Royal Observer Corps Seaborne Wing

name: Royal Regiment of Fusiliers Memorial
description:
THE ROYAL REGIMENT OF FUSILIERS 
There have been Fusilier Regiments in the British Army for over 400 years. This memorial shows the Regimental Colour of the 1st Battalion and the Queen’s Colour. The Royal Regiment was formed from the amalgamation of 4 other Fusilier Regiments in 1968. 
 (Drummer Lee Rigby, who was murdered outside an Army barracks in London in May 2013, belonged to this Regiment. His name is now engraved on the AFM wall, Panel #227B).

name: Royal Regiment of Scotland
description:
Royal Regiment of Scotland 
The Royal Regiment of Scotland was formed in 2006 through the amalgamation of Scotland's historic infantry regiments to form a single fighting force.
The memorial is a low-level plinth made of Scottish granite which is located by a grove of Scots pines.
The memorial commemorates all those who have served since 1945 and especially those killed or who have died in the operational theatres in The Royal Regiment of Scotland and its Antecedent Regiments.
The Regiment’s cap badge is inscribe above the dedication and the motto, Nemo Me Impune Lacessit ("No one harasses me with impunity" ), is inscribed in large letters on the memorial’s base. The badges of all the regiments listed in the dedication are depicted on individual paviours around the memorial’s base.

name: Royal Scots Dragoon Guards
description:
Royal Scots Dragoon Guards Memorial 
The Royal Scots Dragoon Guards Memorial honours those members of the Regiment and its antecedent regiments who have fallen in service of their country, and all those who served in the regiments. The regiments are: 
3rd Dragoon Guards (Prince of Wales’s) 
The Carabiniers (6th Dragoon Guards) 
3rd Carabiniers (Prince of Wales’s Dragoon Guards) 
The Royal Scots Greys (2nd Dragoons) 
25th Dragoons 
The Royal Scots Dragoon Guards (Carabiniers and Greys) 
The memorial is based on a large Himalayan Blue stone which was quarried in Aberdeenshire. It has an inscription and badges of all the regiments engraved on a black granite tablet. 
Age of memorial - The memorial was made in 2019 and unveiled on 13 April 2019 by Lieutenant General Sir Norman Arthur KCB CVO.

name: Royal Tank Regiment
description:
ROYAL TANK REGIMENT 
The tank was developed simultaneously in Britain and France. The idea for the caterpillar tracks came from British agriculture.
Because of the stalemate in WW1 where both sides were dug into trenches and unable to advance more than a few yards at a time, it was thought that the tank would break the stalemate. Because of its design, it could travel and crush the barbed wire fences, drive across the trenches and could turn the guns onto the enemy.
The tank when being moved around the country for trials was packed in large wooden cases and as a security measure it was marked "water tank". The name on the drawing board was originally "land ship" but when it came to be named, they decided to drop the water and call it a tank, on the premise that you put things in a tank i.e. men and munitions. (there are other versions of how this came about).
On the plinth is a scale model of a Mark 5 tank from WWI, of which there were 2 main types - the ‘female’ tank armed with machine guns and the ‘male’ armed with cannons. There were a few ‘hermaphrodites’, armed with both.
The trees on the plot are largely of Ash to correspond with the Ash ‘swagger sticks’ of the officers. These came about after an officer cut a branch from an ash tree to measure the depth of mud before sending his tanks into it, a clever idea which became general practice.
The oak tree, surrounded by the seat, was grown from an acorn collected from Delville Wood, on the Somme battlefield, where the tanks were used in larger numbers. Other trees are from the Cambrai battlefield, Flesquieres and Bourlon Wood, where the Battle of Cambrai took place in November 1917.
At the sides of the plot in spring, daffodils flower in the pattern of a tank’s caterpillar tracks.
The flag of the Tank Regiment is 3 horizontal stripes, from the bottom upwards, brown to red to green. Stands for, “from the mud through the blood to the green fields beyond”. The Moto of the RTD is “Fear Naught” 4 Members of the RTG have been awarded the VC, one being awarded to 2nd Lieutenant Clement Robertson who walked in front of his tanks to mark the way over heavily ploughed fields so as they not lose their way.
The first successful tank battle took place at Cambrai in 1917 with about 300 Mark IV tanks. Horrendous conditions inside the tank, temperature of up to 45 degrees, crew of 8, noise from shells, engine and tracks. 3-4 mph over shell craters, the smell. They needed a strong stomach. The tank on the plinth is a Mark V (male).
In the centre of the circular seat is an oak tree, the acorn was brought back from Delville Wood. Ash trees are significant as the Officers would walk in front of the tanks with sticks made of ash, they prodded the ground to see how firm it was as tanks used to get bogged down. Officers of the Regiment carry ‘swagger’, sticks.
In the early 2000s 2 coach loads of recruits were brought to the Grove. They planted daffodil bulbs in straight lines to resemble the tank tracks.
Their flag is brown, red and green, ‘through mud and blood to pastures new’.
In WW2 37% of tank casualties were reported to be soldiers leaving the tank to brew up. Since 1945 all tanks have been fitted with a boiling vessel to make tea.
In WW2, tanks played a major part in the war - there were 46 variants, tanks of all shapes and sizes. There were:
Tankettes, about the size of a large car, mainly used for reconnaissance.
Medium size tanks, but not very successful, under gunned and armoured.
Light tanks, used mainly for training
Cruiser tanks, used mainly against enemy tanks
Infantry tanks, designed and heavily armoured, used to give close support to infantry unit. The most popular of these tanks appears to be the Churchill tank of which around 5,600 were manufactured.

name: Royal Ulster Constabulary George Cross Way (RUC GC Way)
description:
ROYAL ULSTER CONSTABULARY AND PSNI
The Royal Ulster Constabulary was renamed The Police Service Northern Ireland in 2001 and the PSNI memorial is the tall black tablet on our right. The 6 blocks of stone to our front were quarried from the 6 counties and are placed to form a symbolic map of Northern Ireland (Ulster). They commemorate, in particular, the 312 Police Officers who lost their lives to terrorist action, and many thousands who were injured or maimed during the period from 1922 - 2001. The RUC was awarded a collective George Cross and the pathway is known as the RUC George Cross Way. It is lined with 38 Yew trees, representing 38 police subdivisions in the Province, as named on the stone plaques as you walk along. .The George Cross (GC) is the highest award bestowed by the British government for non-operational gallantry or gallantry not in the presence of an enemy. The first stone bench on the left was placed by the RUC Widows Association.

name: Royal Welsh Regiment Memorial
description:
THE ROYAL WELSH 
The Regiment was first raised in 1689 in Wales and is therefore one of our oldest. This also explains the ancient spelling of WELCH, which is sometimes still used. 
This slate monolith weighs over 9 tons and has a time capsule buried in its top left corner giving the history of the Regiment. 
The main insignia on the front of the monolith is the cap badge of the Regiment itself, while those displayed on the curved slate wall are those of antecedent Regiments: 
Royal Welch Fusiliers 
South Wales Borderers 
Welch Regiment 
Monmouthshire Regiment 
Royal Regiment of Wales
