The Royal Welsh 
The inscription is taken from a poem called ‘War’ by the Welsh Language poet Ellis Evans (later known as Hedd Wyn), who was killed near Ypres on the first day of the Battle of Passchendaele in 1917. 
The slate path is in the shape of the "flash", unique to this Regiment, consisting of five overlapping black silk ribbons (9 inches for Officers and 7 inches for other Ranks) on the back of the uniform jacket at neck level. This goes back to the time when ‘pigtails’ were common, and a piece of cloth was intended to protect the uniform from greasy hair. 
Each Spring the memorial is surrounded by daffodils which is the second emblem of Wales, the first being the leek.

name: Salvation Army Memorial
description:
Salvation Army Memorial
General William Booth founded The Christian Mission in 1865. The organisation was renamed The Salvation Army in 1878. Members came from all walks of life and were to be found in both the Royal Navy and the regular Army. The Salvation Army oŽers practical support, unconditional friendship and practical help to people of all ages, backgrounds and needs. The two outstretched hands on the glass panel symbolise hope and help.

name: Sapper Support
description:
THE SAPPER SUPPORT MEMORIAL 
Sapper support is a charity run by former soldiers, many of whom were Sappers (Royal Engineers). The man who started the charity is an exSapper, Tim Evers, who set up the charity in 2014 after he learned one of his friends, himself a Sapper, had been suffering from PTSD and had committed suicide. 
The charity aims to help and support all service men and women suffering from PTSD and also our 999 emergency services. In 2017 it was voted the best new charity in the UK. 
The beautiful cast bronze memorial here at the Arboretum is designed to give families and friends a place to reflect and remember those who have left us battling with Post Traumatic Stress Disorder and other associated mental health illnesses. 
The inscription encourages people to hold the hand of the statue, to reach out and remember those who are no longer with us.

name: Scouting Memorial
description:
Scouting Memorial
Remembers the service given by Scouts across communities and throughout the Armed Forces and recognises the diŽerence Scouting has made. The design features stone seating circling a roaring campfire that moves and flickers. Three young Scouts, carved from solid stone, rest around the fire as if tired from a long and active day, while their adult leader keeps watch over them. A lone neckerchief next to them represents all the missing Scouts. The scene is one of peace and warmth that captures the essence of Scouting’s spirit of global friendship and adventure.

name: Second Tactical Air Force Memorial
description:
Second Tactical Air Force 
The memorial is dedicated to all who served with 137 and 139 Wings RAF 2nd T.A.F. / B.A.F.O (2nd Tactical Air Force / British Air Force of Operation). 
The memorial is located within the RAF Memorial Grove near Millennium Avenue.

name: Sensory Play Garden
description:
CHILDRENS SENSORY GARDEN 
Even the Children's garden has symbolism within it. You can see a circle of red posts for jumping and balancing on with a central black post symbolising a poppy. The boards under the climbing frame symbolise the duck boards used in the trenches in WWI, and the large circular climbing net represents a globe and hope for world peace. 
The large wooden figures at the entrance are characters from Wind in the Willows. They were carved by the Essex Woodcarvers. 
Dogs are not allowed into the garden

name: Shackleton Association Memorial
description:
SHACKLETON ASSOCIATION 
The Shackleton Association was conceived and founded in 1987 by John Botwood, who quickly assembled a dedicated group of mainly ex RAF members who had been associated with the Avro Shackleton during their service career and who were determined that the memory of this great aircraft should never be forgotten.

name: Shaw, Saville and Albion Ltd Memorial
description:
Shaw Savill & Albion Co Ltd 
Shaw Savill & Albion Co Ltd was a British shipping company that operated ships between Great Britain, Australia and New Zealand. 
The memorial, donated by the Shaw Savill Society, is dedicated to all who served in the ships of the Shaw Savill & Albion Co Ltd during the Second World War and especially to those who made the supreme sacrifice in the ships that were lost as a result of enemy action.

name: Sherwood Rangers Yeomanry Memorial
description:
Sherwood Rangers Yeomanry 
The Sherwood Rangers Yeomanry (SRY) is one of the five squadrons of the Royal Yeomanry (RY), a light cavalry regiment of the Army Reserve. Designated as 'A' Squadron, the Sherwood Rangers Yeomanry's current role is to support the Light Cavalry Regiments on operations by providing skilled reconnaissance soldiers. 
Originally raised as the Nottinghamshire Yeomanry Cavalry in 1794, the Regiment was used on several occasions in the 19th Century to maintain law and order. Since 1900, the Regiment has seen overseas service during the Second Boer War and both World Wars, earning 44 battle honours during these campaigns.

name: Shot at Dawn Memorial
description:
SHOT AT DAWN 
309 posts one for each soldier shot at dawn for deserting, attacking an officer, throwing away his gun, sleeping on watch. It is situated here as it is the furthest east on the site. When the sun rises it falls on the statue. He is Herbert Burden, serving with the Northumberland fusiliers, aged 17 when shot. The 6 juniper trees opposite represent the riflemen. The firing squad was picked from the prisoner’s own platoon, a lesson should they every consider doing anything similar. 
Jimmy Smith had seen active service in Gallipoli, badly wounded on the Somme, he was sent back to England. When he had recovered he returned to the frontline in time for the Battle of Ypres in Belgium in 1917 He could take no more, he deserted. He was sentenced to be shot. The riflemen fired wide but had wounded Jimmy. The officer in charge went over to Richard Blundell in the firing squad and told him to carry out the ‘coup de grâce’. Richard was Jimmy’s best friend. On visiting his father in the nursing home many years later, Richard’s son asked his father why he kept saying ‘what a way, what a way’. Richard said ‘what a way to get compassionate leave to kill your best friend’. Post 255 
Today we live in a more enlightened age and we recognise PTSD 
Rudyard Kipling wrote an epitaph: 
I could not look on death 
And being known 
Men led me to him 
Blindfold and alone.

name: Showmen's Guild of Great Britain
description:
SHOWMEN’S GUILD OF GREAT BRITAIN 
The memorial is dedicated to those members of the Guild who lost their lives serving their country in the two World Wars. It includes James, the carousel horse, reminding us that the Showmen moved around with travelling fairs.
It was a tradition that the first son of the family would become a showman himself, while the second son would join the military.
During the two World Wars, more than 3,000 showmen volunteered to fight. Of these, about a quarter were killed in the line of duty.
On the home front during WW2, show people raised money to pay for a fleet of 19 ambulances and £5,000 for a Spitfire in 1943. This was named ‘The Fun of the Fair’ and was allocated to a Polish squadron, seeing extensive action until it was shot down over France in 1945.

name: Shrievalty Avenue
description:
Shrievalty Avenue Map 
Millennium Avenue incorporates a number of lime trees sponsored by High Sheriffs, some of whom were in office at the time of the Millennium. All these trees were propagated from the 2,000 year-old lime tree growing at Westonbirt Arboretum in Gloucestershire. 
This Millennium sponsorship by High Sheriffs was singularly appropriate given that the office of High Sheriff (or Shire Reeve) is at least 1,000 years old, having its roots in Saxon times, well before the Norman Conquest of 1066. It is the oldest continuous secular office under the Crown. 
Originally, a High Sheriff was vested with many of the powers a Lord Lieutenant, High Court Judges and Magistrates have today. The office of High Sheriff remained first in precedence in the counties until King Edward VII, by Order in Council in 1908, gave that primacy to the Lord Lieutenant. The High Sheriff remains the Sovereign’s representative in a county for all matters relating to the Judiciary and to the maintenance of law and order. 
The involvement of the High Sheriffs in the Millennium Avenue underlines their service to their Sovereign and to the counties for more than a thousand years.

name: Shropshire Yeomanry Memorial Plinth
description:
Shropshire Yeomanry Plinth 
The Shropshire Yeomanry date their origin to the raising of the Wellington Troop in 1795 during the French Revolutionary Wars. 
The memorial was dedicated on Saturday 13 March 2010 by Colonel Evans, President of the Association. It was built by Bob Sadler after a ‘buy-a-brick’ scheme organised with Association members to raise funds. The central plaque was produced by stone mason John Beer.

name: Sikh Memorial
description:
THE SIKH MEMORIAL 
The bust on our right commemorates the 124,245 Sikh soldiers who fought with the British forces during the 4 years of WW1. 
Although only about 1% of the Indian population at that time were Sikhs, they made up about 20% of the British Indian Army and were highly regarded for their fighting abilities. 
Sikhs also fought alongside the Allies in WW2 of course. 
The medals are - 8-pointed star is the Indian Order of Merit; then The 1914 Star; The British War Medal; The Victory Medal. The last 3 came to be known as Pip, Squeak and Wilfred after the newspaper cartoon characters

name: Small Arms School Corps Memorial
description:
SMALL ARMS SCHOOL MEMORIAL 
 Founded in 1853 by Lord Hardinge, it is a small Corp of the British Army. Its personnel provide advice and instruction to infantry weapon trainers throughout the army in order to maintain the proficiency in the use of small arms and support weapons and range management. 
The memorial shows a soldier from around the 1800s holding a land Pattern Musket, known as "Brown Bess". This musket first saw service in 1704.

name: Soldiers, Sailors, Airmen and Families Association (SSAFA) Memorial
description:
SSAFA MEMORIAL 
SSAFA was originally formed in 1885 as the Soldiers, Sailors and Families Association. Within days of the outbreak of WW1, SSAFA was called upon to assist the Government to ensure that families didn’t suffer hardship when the men were called up. It was brought in to provide some of the structures and service which would automatically be provided by the State today. It was the only national Service charity in existence at that time and was already a well-respected organisation. 
The name changed in 1919 after the formation of the RAF to become Soldiers, Sailors, Airmen and Families Association SSAFA. 
Today the charity has professional staff supported by around 7,000 volunteers they help around 90,000 people every year.

name: Soroptimist International
description:
Soroptimist International 
Soroptimist International is a vibrant, dynamic organisation for today’s professional women. They are committed to a world where women and girls achieve their individual and collective potential, realise aspirations and have an equal voice in creating strong, peaceful communities worldwide. The name Soroptimist derives from the Latin soror, meaning sister, and optima, meaning best. It can be translated as ‘best of sisters’. Soroptimist International is the world’s largest women’s service organisation. For 100 years, Soroptimists around the world have worked to improve the lives of women and girls by focussing on education, empowerment and enablement through awareness, action and advocacy. The sculpture, features a limestone base with a design that reflects the diversity of Soroptimists. The women are holding hands showing unity and friendship, and are facing outwards to face the challenges ahead. On top of the limestone base is a glass structure made of individual blue toughened glass layers forming the iconic logo of Soroptimist International Great Britain and Ireland - the merging of the letters S and I. Soroptimist International Great Britain and Ireland has had a presence at the Arboretum since 2003, working towards the global initiative of ‘Planting Trees for a Brilliant Future’. To-date, over 65,000 trees have been planted world-wide and Soroptimist International works with the United Nations on the sustainable development goals.

name: South Atlantic Medal Association memorial and the Antelope Garden ; 'Falkland Islands Campaign Memorial'
description:
FALKLANDS MEMORIAL (South Atlantic Medal Association) 
In 1982, the Argentinians invaded the Falkland Islands; they have long believed the islands belonged to them and refer to them as The Malvinas. Britain's response was to send a Task Force to liberate them, whilst this was successful, it came at a price, and 255 service personnel lost their lives. 
As war was never declared this is referred to as the Falklands Conflict not war. 
The purpose of this memorial is threefold: 
1. To honour the Task Force; 
2. To remember those who gave their lives; 
3. To inform visitors about this important event in our history. 
The rocks are from the Falklands, and the Azaleas are a species created by a local garden centre called "Azalea Antelope" in memory of HMS Antelope, a Type 2l Frigate lost in the conflict. 
The plaque on the reverse of the central rock commemorates the 3 female Falkland Islanders who lost their lives during the conflict. 
The wall of Cotswold stone is modelled on the memorial that stands at San Carlos Cemetery. The central plaque on the wall shows the crest of Joint Service Operations, which is flanked by the 6 services that played a role in the conflict. 
The plaque at the base of the wall shows an outline map of the Atlantic Oceans and gives an indication of the vast distances the Task Force had to travel before engaging the Argentinians. 
Some stats: 
Human losses: 255 British; 3 islanders; 649 Argentinians. 
Ship losses: 4 - HM Ships Sheffield; Ardent; Antelope; Coventry. Argentinian ARA Belgrano 
Merchant Navy ship losses: I - Atlantic Conveyor with its cargo. 
Royal Fleet Auxiliary ships losses: 2 - Sir Tristram and Sir Galahad; 56, mostly Welsh Guards, died on the latter 

At the time of her sinking Captain Hart-Dyke was the Captain of HMS Coventry, his daughter is Maranda Hart the actress and comedian

name: Special Constabulary Memorial
description:
Spiritualists’ National Union Memorial
This memorial was dedicated in memory of Spiritualists who have served and continue to serve in the British and Commonwealth Armed Forces, and all Spiritualists who have served their country in times of conflict. The design comprises a circular bench made from polished beige granite topped with curved coping slabs to form a seat. Within the bench are seven curved pieces of Balmoral red granite, each one bearing symbolic words. The internal floor of the circle is paved with the same types of granite, depicting a seven-pointed star. Standing in the centre of the circle is an obelisk with a pyramid top.

name: Spiritualists' National Union Memorial
description:
Spiritualists’ National Union Memorial
This memorial was dedicated in memory of Spiritualists who have served and continue to serve in the British and Commonwealth Armed Forces, and all Spiritualists who have served their country in times of conflict. The design comprises a circular bench made from polished beige granite topped with curved coping slabs to form a seat. Within the bench are seven curved pieces of Balmoral red granite, each one bearing symbolic words. The internal floor of the circle is paved with the same types of granite, depicting a seven-pointed star. Standing in the centre of the circle is an obelisk with a pyramid top.

name: Staff Sergeant Phil Currass Memorial
description:
Sergeant Phil Curass 
This memorial is dedicated to Staff Sergeant Philip Preston Curass QGM who died on active service in 
The Falklands conflict on 19 May 1982. It comprises a modern stainless steel sundial set on a piece of 
stone from Old Radnor Quarry. 
The sundial is inscribed with the following dedication: 
Phil joined D Squadron 22 SAS in 1972 from the Royal Army Medical Corps. He completed 
operational tours in Dhofar (Oman) and in Northern Ireland. In 1979 he was awarded the Queen’s 
Gallantry Medal. During the Falklands War he helped liberate South Georgia and raided Pebble 
Island to destroy enemy aircraft. Phil lost his life during a ship to ship transfer prior to carrying out a 
diversionary raid near Goose Green. 
Husband, Father, Brother, Son and Soldier. dearly loved and sorely missed by his family. 
“There are moments when I wish I could roll back the clock and take all the sadness away, but I have 
the feeling that if I did, the joy would be gone as well.” Nicholas Sparks 
Lost in the South Atlantic 19th May 1982. 
On the top right of the sundial an arrow points in the direction of Pebble Island (some 7934 miles 
from this location).

name: Staffordshire Regiment Memorial
description:
STAFFORDSHIRE REGIMENT 
Originally there were two regiments, The North Staffs and The South Staffs. They amalgamated in 1959 to become The Staffordshire Regiment and in 2007 they became part of the Mercian Regiment. 
The memorial itself is made of Staffordshire stone, and is the only memorial on the site that has been designed and constructed by former members of the regiment. 
And a good example of one of our tree dedications is the single oak behind the obelisk, dedicated to Lance Corporal William COLTMAN, the most decorated NCO (non-commissioned officer) of WW1. 
Lance Corporal Coltman was awarded the Victoria Cross, the Distinguished Conduct Medal and Bar (meaning it was awarded twice), and the Military Medal and Bar, and was also mentioned in despatches. But he did not kill any Germans, for he was a stretcher bearer. 
died in 1974, aged 82. 
His medals are on display at Staffordshire Regimental Museum, just outside Lichfield.

name: Staffordshire Yeomanry Memorial
description:
Staffordshire Yeomanry Memorial 
The Staffordshire Yeomanry memorial plaque commemorates those who gave their lives in the campaigns of The Boer War, The First World War (The Great War) and The Second World War.

name: Stick Man Sculpture
description: no information available

name: Stillbirth and Neonatal Death Charity Memorial (SANDS)
description:
THE SANDS GARDEN 
Stillbirth and Neonatal Death Charity 
The aims of the SANDS organisation aim is to save babies lives and to support bereaved families 
SANDS was founded in 1978 and aims to support anyone affected by the death of a baby, providing services to parents and their families, promoting changes in antenatal practice and funding research that could help to reduce infant mortality rates. 
The garden has been designed to reflect the emotional journey that many parents face when coming to terms with their bereavement, starting with harsh foliage which becomes progressively softer as you move along the path. 
It is a very quiet and tranquil place for people to remember. 
At the heart of the garden is the Portland stone sculpture of a baby and the SANDS logo which represents an eye and a glass teardrop set into the ground.

name: Stirling X9-Y, 299 Squadron Memorial
description:
Stirling X9-Y, 299 Squadron Memorial Map
299 Squadron (Special Operations Service) Royal Air Force WW2
Memorial plaque is on a stone situated in the Special Operation Garden close to the Vera Atkins
memorial.
299 Squadron RAF Memorial - Special Operations Flights – Stirling X9-Y (Worry!).
Remarkably these lads, listed below, survived the war as well as all their hazardous missions: PO Bert
Horan, WO Jack Fry, WO Basil Jaggard, WO Reg Lowmanbaker, WO Maurice Davis & WO Gus Tyers.
This crew also participated in Operation Market Garden at Arnhem (September 1944) and Operation
Varsity (The Rhine Crossing) on 19th March 1945.
This memorial was contributed by WO Maurice Davis in 2006.
The 299 Squadron Motto 'Par Nobile Fratrum' (A noble group of brothers) symbolises the close
association with the Army Airborne Forces.
Behind the memorial is a Red Oak Tree which was grown from an acorn found in Oosterbeek
Cemetery!

name: Submariners Memorial
description:
The Submariner Memorial 
In 1921 the sum of £2130 was raised by public subscription to create a “Memorial tablet to the Officers and Men of the Submarine Service R.N.” on the Embankment. It was dedicated in June 1922 and remains a very important place in the hearts and minds of all submariners. Yet the Embankment is not the most peaceful nor easiest place to meet for collective or private acts of remembrance or for quiet reflection. Moreover, the Embankment Memorial recognises submarines lost in the two world wars but not the submariners lost since then. 
In the years since its opening the National Memorial Arboretum has grown into the centre of national remembrance and all armed and public services and many of their units and branches have placed memorials on this site. Indeed, the Submariners Association placed a small plaque here to submarines lost in the wars and another to our VC winners when the Arboretum opened. 
In recent years, however, there has been a growing call for a more fitting memorial for the nearly 6000 submariners who have given their lives in service and, for the first time, to have a memorial which recognises the sacrifice of their families. This was acknowledged in July 2019 when a group of retired submariners came together to form a charity - The Submariner Memorial Appeal. 
The aim was not only to raise funds, plan and install a new memorial, but in the process to bring the disparate elements of the submarine community together. The appeal was launched by the then Second Sea Lord in front of HMS ANSON in Devonshire Dock Hall at BAES Barrow-in-Furness on 28 February 2020 and a public competition to find ideas to inspire a professional designer announced. 
From over 600 entries, three age category winners and one overall winner were chosen and their designs given to three carefully selected professional sculptors. The sculptors were given wide latitude to be inspired by the winning entries but not to have to reproduce them. The resulting designs were all very different but all impressive, however, Paul Day’s entry immediately engaged the Board’s emotions and caught the spirit of the submarine service. 
Whilst Paul progressed the detailed design and casting of the memorial, fundraising ramped up. Around £500,000 would be needed. The appeal was very lucky to receive two particularly significant donations from the Gosling Foundation and from an anonymous donor. Submarine Industries were also very generous with 21 separate companies contributing. Livery companies, the Freemasons, the Royal Naval Royal Marine Charity, the RN Association and our submarine charities all supported the appeal and many individual contributions were made through crowd funding and a wealth of individual fundraising activities. These included running, rowing, cycling, painting, drawing, printing, coining (selling commemorative coins), writing, merchandising and more. The standout individual effort was Mr Graham Bishop who completed the London Marathon dressed as a model of a submarine.The money was raised in time for the turf to be cut by Diana Mayes, 100yr old widow of Lt Gordon Noll, CO of HMS UNTAMED and a young submariner from HMS VIGILANT on 6 September 2021. 
The memorial itself is 3500kg of bronze sculpted into a divided fin of a submarine with the lone figure of a submariner standing between the two halves looking to the surface. On one outer side of the fin is a frieze of families waiting for the return of their loved ones and on the other fin the Churchill quote: 
“Of all the branches of men in the forces there is none which shows more devotion and faces grimmer perils than the submariners.” 
The memorial is on a long low mound to give the idea that the rest of the boat is just below the water. An interpretation board is sited by its ‘port bow’. On this is a QR code which links to a new Online Book of Remembrance gifted to the Appeal by the Friends of the RN Submarine Museum. 
This is a very significant piece of work in it is own right, it features the most detailed and well researched list of those who gave their lives in service in submarines. It will allow people to add stories and photographs of those whom they have lost and the QR code will be shared with all the other submarine memorials (over 60) around the country. Funds have been set aside to add it to the Embankment Memorial as well. 
The Submarine Service was formed in 1901 when 6 officers and a number of ratings started submarine training. That same year the British Government placed an order for 5 American Holland class submarines to be built under licence by Vickers Sons and Maxim Ltd at Barrow-in-Furness. HMS Holland 1 launched in January 1902. 
Although some senior personnel within the Admiralty saw little point in submarines, Britain pursued an energetic submarine programme and by 1910 had 61 operational submarines. 
Submarines played a major role in both world Wars and a total of 14 VCs were awarded to submariners. 
From the start of the submarine programme, a total of 174 submarines have been lost - the majority during the two World Wars. The last submarine to sink was in 1971 when HMS Artemis sank alongside the jetty at HMS Dolphin during refuelling.

name: Suez Maru Memorial
description:
SUEZ MARU MEMORIAL
Here we have the brick memorial for those who died in 1943 when the Suez Maru, a Japanese transport ship carrying British and Dutch prisoners of war, was torpedoed by an American submarine. Some prisoners escaped the sinking but were then shot in the water by the Japanese. The pillar consists of 414 limestone cubes, one for each of the British prisoners who died. Maru’ means merchant ship. The second cairn lists the names of the 26 Japanese merchant ships carrying prisoners of war and/or civilians on what became known as ‘HELL SHIPS’, that were sunk by Allied action with the loss of more than 19,000 lives. It includes the Suez Maru, giving a figure of 546 casualties which includes those who were other than British (mostly Dutch). The wooden crosses around the edge give the location of military cemeteries. The top name is the country or island where it is situated and the lower name that of the cemetery itself.

name: Suez Veterans Association
description:
SUEZ VETERANS 
The Armed Forces Veterans who served in the Suez Canal Zone during the 1950’s are remembered on the corner of the avenue here. We have this lovely pyramid, palm trees and the Suez Canal itself is represented by the blue channel.
You will see from the board that many of the bases were RAF and although we generally regard 1956 as the year of the ‘Suez Crisis’, the troubles actually began as early as 1951, when an Egyptian policy of non-cooperation with the British began.
This led to acts of sabotage and guerrilla attacks on British personnel and their families.
The information board half-way down gives a timeline of British involvement in Egypt.
Being posted to Egypt was generally regarded by members of our Armed Forces as ‘The worst posting in the world!’
Dedicated in 2004
It is rich in symbolism from the Suez Canal region
This includes palm trees, a thin blue line of glass representing the canal and a pyramid shaped monument
The Suez Emergency was from 16 October 1951 to 19 October 1954 and servicemen were deemed to be on “active service”
This service was not recognised by the award of a General Service Medal until 2003

name: Sultan of Oman's Armed Forces Memorial
description:
SULTAN OF OMAN’S ARMED FORCES MEMORIAL
The truncated pyramid-shaped plinth with its map, inscription and badge, form a memorial in recognition of all who served in or supported the Armed Forces of the Sultanate of Oman. 
Since their formal establishment in the early 1950s,with British assistance, these forces have twice overcome insurgencies which have threatened the integrity or social structure of the state and, more recently, have contributed contingents or facilities to coalitions formed to protect the Persian Gulf states. They still have a close relationship with the British Military.

name: Sumatra Railway Memorial
description:
SUMATRA RAILWAY
Sumatra connected Muaro with Pekanbaru Like the Burma railway, the Sumatra Railway was built in extremely unhealthy, brutal conditions. About 5,000 Allied POW’s and 30,000 local people were forced to take part in the construction and many thousands lost their lives. It took 9 months to construct; was 140 miles long; 700 POWs and 25,000 local slaves died (known as Romusha). This display shows the methods used in its construction. The railway was finished on the day the war ended, August 15th, 1945 which is now known as VJ Day and was only ever used to transport the prisoners out of Sumatra on their way home.

name: The Beat (Police Memorial Avenue)
description:
THE BEAT 
The Beat was originally lined with horse chestnut trees, one for each police force in the UK. Horse Chestnut is symbolic as one was grown from a conker picked up at Drayton Manor where the founder of the Police Force lived, Sir Robert Peel. He named his force the Peelers or Bobbies. The first truncheons were made of the wood as it was a dense wood and would give a knock to remember. 
If we look back to the top of The Beat we can see a traditional Blue Police lamp, they used to be situated outside most Police Stations. This one originates from Hitchin, Hertfordshire, Police Station, it was placed here in memory of Mandy Raynor, the youngest Policewoman to lose her life whilst on duty.

name: The Catenian Association
description:
The Catenian Association Memorial
The Association
The Catenian Association is an organisation of Catholic men whose prime aim is to provide a network of support and friendship amongst its members and their families including widows. Members support the Church both locally and nationally. The Association believes strongly that it should support the development of young people. As part of this commitment, there is a Bursary Fund which provides grants to young people undertaking community projects and helping at Lourdes. Catenians are members of the Catholic Youth Ministry Federation and sponsor the major youth rally ‘Flame’ held every two years at Wembley Arena. In recent years, the Association has developed beyond Great Britain to Australia, Malta, India, Southern Africa, Ireland, Bangladesh and Nazareth. The Memorial The memorial is situated in a very pleasant location alongside the Royal British Legion poppy field. It is immediately opposite the police memorial. It is a very peaceful location surrounded on three sides by trees representing a place for peaceful reflection. The design is very simple topped with the Catenian Association emblem which is very distinctive as you approach. The emblem represents a chain (“catena” is latin for chain) This is meant to symbolise togetherness, friendship and support. The memorial is in memory of members of the Association and their families and friends who suffered, were wounded or gave their lives in conflicts since its formation in 1908. It was designed to be an all embracing memorial and it is hoped that people will visit it as an opportunity to reflect on all loved ones who are no longer with us.

name: The Fisgard Association Memorial
description:
The Fisgard Association Memorial 
The Fisgard Association Memorial and nearby tree are dedicated to the former Royal Navy artificer apprentices, most of whom served all or part of their training at the Royal Navy Artificer Training Establishment, HMS Fisgard or as part of the Fisgard Squadron in HMS Raleigh. 
The original HMS Fisgard was a 46 gun Leda class frigate which was used as a training establishment between 1848 and 1872. A second Fisgard was established in hulks at Portsmouth in 1904 and went through several incarnations. The establishment was moved to Chatham in 1930 and in July 1932 moved ashore. In October 1940 the establishment moved to Torpoint in Cornwall, near Devonport Naval Base. The base was closed on 21st October 1983 when its activities were absorbed into HMS Raleigh

name: The London Scottish Regiment Memorial
description:
LONDON SCOTTISH REGIMENT
Founded in 1859 as a volunteer force sponsored by the Highland Society of London and now part of the London Regiment. One of their nicknames is ‘The Cockney Jocks’. They were the first Territorial infantry to see action in WW I at Messines Ridge 31/10/1914. In its final incarnation it was A (The London Scottish) Company, the London Regiment, until on 1 April 2022, soldiers in the company transferred to foot guards regiments and the company became G (Messines) Company, Scots Guards. Three members of the Regiment have been awarded a VC. The memorial was dedicated in March 2019.

name: The National Memorial To The Evacuation (The British Evacuees Association)
description:
EVACUEES (EVERY WHICH WAY)
During WW2, the decision was taken to move a number of vulnerable people, mostly children, away from the dangers of German bombing raids into safer areas. This was necessary as the country was at total war and later statistics showed that more civilians than military personnel were actually killed during the conflict. Some 3.5 million people were evacuated, and the design of this memorial conveys some of the anxiety and confusion of the child evacuees through deliberate distortion of the figures - some hands are reversed and torsos twisted through 180 degrees. The split open luggage represents how families were torn apart by the evacuation process. The memorial was unveiled in the presence of the Duke of Gloucester by Michael Aspel, who was evacuated during WW2 from London to Somerset, aged 7. The memorial remembers over 3 million evacuees, mostly young children,who were evacuated from cities to the countryside to keep them safe from the bombing. But it wasn't only children evacuated - Over 100,000 teachers, around 500,000 mothers with children under 5 years, 13,000 pregnant women and 70,000 people with disabilities. The evacuation started on 1st September 1939 (code name Operation Pied Piper).

name: The Royal Antediluvian Order of Buffaloes Memorial
description:
THE ROYAL ANTEDILUVIAN ORDER OF BUFFALOES
The order was started in 1822 and is commonly known as "The Buffs". They claim to be the largest fraternal organisation in the UK. It is now a global organisation. 
RAOB aid their members, their families and dependants of former members and charitable organisations. As with all the other fraternal organisations e.g The Free Masons, Oddfellows, they also saw service in both WWs. 
In WW1 they raised money and supplied ambulances to aid the war effort and the ambulances were often driven by volunteer Buffs. In total 22 members of this organisation were awarded Victoria Crosses. 
The key values are justice, truth and philanthropy and their principle aims are friendship, charitable works, social activity, mutual support and care.

name: The Western Front Grove
description:
The Western Front Association Grove
All the hornbeam trees in the Western Front Association Grove were grown from the only tree left standing in Delville Wood after the Battle of the Somme. Each tree has been dedicated by the Birmingham branch of the WFA.
The Western Front Association Grove compliments the nearby Western Front Association Memorial which is dedicated to 956,703 British Empire men and women who died in the First World War. The stone memorial is inscribed with words from Binyon’s poem, ‘For the Fallen’ and Sassoon’s poem, ‘Aftermath’. The Western Front Association (WFA) is an historical interest group established in 1980 by noted military historian John Giles and has a worldwide membership of over 6,500. The WFA supports many remembrance and research projects, including the renovation of battlefield memorials.

name: Tobruk Memorial
description:
TOBRUK 
Half-way down is a memorial to those involved in the siege of Tobruk. 
Tobruk is the only deep-water port in Eastern Libya which British Forces were occupying in 1941. It was attacked by German and Italian forces and was under siege for 241 days - the longest siege in the history of the British Army. Our forces managed to repel the invaders and keep control

name: TOC H Memorial
description:
TOC H 
The lamp on your right is the symbol of the Toc H movement, a Christian organisation that has its roots in a large house called Talbot House at Poperinge (pronounced Pope-a-ringa) in Belgium, about 6 miles from the YPRES battlefield. The lamp itself is a low-burning oil lamp that was used in the Chapel at the top of the house. 
The town of Poperinge, known as Pops, became very popular with British troops. Being so close to the front line, lots of officers' bars sprang up and bars for other ranks. Brothels also appeared. Talbot House was an alternative place for soldiers who wanted a quiet refuge. 
Talbot House was set up in 1915 by a jovial clergyman, the Rev. ‘Tubby’ Clayton providing basic comforts and a chapel for young men going to and from the Western Front. It was a ‘home from home’ where rank had no place. 
The name ‘Talbot House’ was shortened to Toc H by use of the phonetic alphabet of that time. (We now say T tango, not T toc). 
The house was closed when WW1 ended, but a number of men who had made use of it, especially the chapel, got together to form a charitable organisation which they called TocH. 
TocH developed greatly from that time to become an international organisation that tries to improve the lives of those who need help. 
Talbot House still exists today as a museum/hotel. (The house was named after Lieutenant Gilbert Talbot, who was the brother of Padre Neville Talbot and had been killed at Ypres in 1915, aged 23yrs.)

name: Ton Class Minesweepers Memorial
description:
TON CLASS MINESWEEPERS 
116 of these little ships were built and were known as the "Ton" class because they were all named after a town or village finishing in the word 'Ton", e.g. Castleton, Kirkliston. 
Although their superstructure was made from aluminium and other non-ferromagnetic materials, yet again, their hulls were made from wood, in this case mahogany planking; however, the final one, HMS Wilton, built in 1971, was made completely of fibre glass. 
Their role was to detect and destroy surface and seabed mines in shallow coastal waters, rivers, ports and harbours and they were deployed all over the globe. 
The Ton Class Memorial Plaque was dedicated in proud and affectionate memory of the 117 Minehunters of the Ton Class, and the generations of young officers and men who served in all corners of the globe between 1953 and 1993. The plaque also commemorates the men of HMS Fittleton who lost their lives on 20 September 1976. 
HM King Charles, while Prince of Wales, served as CO of HMS Bronington during the 1970s. 
An additional a plaque commemorates an oak tree grown by Bryan Player in Solihull who picked up an acorn on the Meridian Line at Greenwich Royal Park in 1987 at the founding of The Ton Class Association. It was planted at the Arboretum on 10 September 2000.

name: Townswomen's Guild
description:
Townswomens Guild
The Townswomen’s Guild Memorial is dedicated to those who have served in HM Forces or in civilian services and died as casualties of war, civil conflict or peacekeeping . It was unveiled by HRH The Princess Royal, Patron of the Townswomen’s Guild, on 5 October 2017. The memorial was funded by donations from Guild members, who raised over £15,000 through coffee mornings and imaginative initiatives. The Townswomen’s Guild was formed in 1929 but has its roots in the suffrage movement of the late 19th Century. During the Second World War many member of the Guild were conscripted, worked in hosptials, civil defence, factories or on the land. Others used their organisational skills to assist in the maintenance of civil society and staged shows and concerts to boost morale. Townswomen’s Guild is one of the largest women’s organisations in the UK with approximately 600 Guilds and 24,000 members. The Guild has seen significant growth in recent years from those attracted by the events, friendship, crafts and opportunities to campaign on social issues offered collectively and by individual Guilds around the country.

name: Tree of Cherished Memories, The
description:
Tree of Cherished Memories 
The Tree of Cherished Memories is a magnificent four metre sculpture by artist Jill Berelowitz. Nestled amongst a landscaped wooded glade, this magical tree creates an alternative Remembrance space for all. Cast in bronze, the Tree of Cherished Memories is steeped in symbolism. Immortalising one of the Arboretum’s very own hawthorn ‘Crataegus’ trees, the design represents a peaceful connection between humanity and nature. Its interwoven trunk and visible roots emanate strength and determination, and the globe-like crown of the tree symbolises connection and togetherness. On the ground, a growing seedpod represents youth and new life. Glinting bronze leaves and figurative dancers are entwined within the branches and will continue to grow as personal dedications are added. Beautiful leaf and figurative elements of the sculpture can be individually commissioned as a dedication to a loved one, or to mark special occasions for celebration and Remembrance. If you wish to locate a dedication that has been made on the tree, please speak to a member of our team.

name: Trees of Life Glade
description: Trees of Life Glade

name: Trefoil Guild Memorial
description:
Trefoil Guild Memorial
The Trefoil Guild was formed in 1943 and is part of the Guiding Association. The memorial gives a brief history
of the organisation and is accompanied by a copper beech (Fagus sylvatica f. purpurea) which is dedicated to the women and men who serve their communities and help Guiding and Scouting thrive across the United Kingdom.

name: Trenchard's Legacy
description: Trenchard's Legacy

name: TS Exmouth Memorial
description:
Training Ship Exmouth 
This memorial plaque commemorates all the officers and boys who served on the Training Ship Exmouth (off Grays, Essex 1876-1942) and later as the London Nautical Training School (1942-1951). 
Having completed their training, the boys served in all branches of the Armed Forces, the Merchant Navy and the fishing fleets. 
In September 1939, at the outbreak of the Second World War, the boys were evacuated from the ship to Burnham on Crouch in Essex. In July 1940, they were moved on to Lydney in Gloucestershire, which became their main base for the duration of the War. A third move took them to them to temporary quarters at Bray Court, near Maidenhead, before finally locating to their last home at Wolverstone Hall in Suffolk. 
The ship was used by the London Fire Brigade as River Fire Station until 1942. It then moved to Scapa Flow where it was commissioned as HMS Exmouth, a depot ship used for the welfare, recreation and training of the crews for minesweepers and submarines. 
Following the Second World War HMS Exmouth returned to the River Thames and finished her days as HMS Worcester at Greenhithe. 
At the bottom of the memorial plaque is a dedication to those who gave their lives in Service which is accompanied by the quote “We Few, We Happy Few, We Band of Brothers” taken from William Shakespeare's play, Henry V. 
It was installed by the T.S. Exmouth Association in 2003.

name: TS Indefatigable Memorial
description:
Training Ship Indefatigable 
This memorial is in tribute to all boys from Indefatigable Training Ship and School (1864 – 1995) especially remembering those who lost their lives in service of their country. 
The first Indefatigable was an ex Royal Navy wooden frigate which was moored off Rock Ferry, on the Birkenhead side of the Mersey until 1914. The trainees, typically poor and orphaned boys whose fathers were seamen, were trained for a life at sea and actually lived on board the ship. The ship’s gun deck was converted to accommodate 200 boys in hammocks. 
The second Indefatigable (previously HMS Phaeton) entered service as a Training Ship on 15 January 1914 and continued to train boys in seafaring until 1941. During the Second World War the heavy bombing of Liverpool made it unsafe to stay in the River Mersey. The school found temporary shore-based premises near Ruthin in Wales before moving to a mansion at Plas Llanfair at Anglesey in Wales in December 1944. 
The School closed in July 1995, after which the premises was sold to the MOD who agreed to retain the name in the title of the new establishment; hence The Joint Service Mountain Training Centre Indefatigable.

name: TS Mercury, HMS Worcester, Conway, SATS General Botha, Nautical College Pangbourne Memorial
description:
TS Mercury, HMS Worcester, Conway, SATS General Botha, Nautical College Pangbourne Memorial 
This memorial, which was re-dedicated on the 3 September 2016, is to the five following Training Ships and Nautical Colleges: 
The Training Ship HMS Conway 
The Nautical College Pangbourne 
The Training Ship Mercury 
The South African Training Ship General Botha 
The Incorporated Thames Nautical Training College, H.M.S. Worcester 
Made of black polished granite it displays the badges of each Training Ship and Nautical College with their names inscribed beneath. It includes the following inscription at the bottom: 
Dedicated to the memory of the former cadets and staff of these Training Ships and Nautical Colleges who gave their lives in service of their country in times of war.

name: TS Vindicatrix Memorial
description:
Training Ship Vindicatrix 
The Vindicatrix was a British ship built in 1893. She sailed under a red ensign for 17 years until being sold to a German firm in 1910. After the First World War she was repossessed and given to the Shipping Federation. Having been located in London Docks for some time she was relocated to Sharpness Old Dock in Gloucestershire in 1939 where she became a training ship for boys entering the Merchant Navy. 
The Training Ship Vindicatrix memorial is made of grey flecked granite and displays the badge of the Association. It is dedicated to the estimated 70,000 boys who received their basic training for the Merchant Navy between 1939 – 1966 many of whom gave their lives in the Second World War. 
TS Mercury, HMS Worcester, Conway, SATS General Botha, Nautical College Pangbourne Memorial Map 
This memorial, which was re-dedicated on the 3 September 2016, is to the five following Training Ships and Nautical Colleges: 
The Training Ship HMS Conway 
The Nautical College Pangbourne 
The Training Ship Mercury 
The South African Training Ship General Botha 
The Incorporated Thames Nautical Training College, H.M.S. Worcester 
Made of black polished granite it displays the badges of each Training Ship and Nautical College with their names inscribed beneath. It includes the following inscription at the bottom: 
Dedicated to the memory of the former cadets and staff of these Training Ships and Nautical Colleges who gave their lives in service of their country in times of war.

name: Twin Towers Memorial
description:
Twin Towers Memorial 
Pays tribute to those who perished as a result of the terrorist attack on the World Trade Centre, New York on 11 September 2001, including 64 British Citizens. The memorial is sponsored by the communities of Herefordshire and Worcestershire and the Hereford and Worcester Fire Authority in recognition of the courage and dedication of New York’s emergency personnel.

name: Type 21 Frigates Memorial
description:
TYPE 21 FRIGATES 
The Type 21 frigate, was a British general-purpose escort that was designed in the late 1960s, built in the 1970s and served throughout the 1980s into the 1990s 
There were 8 ships in the class - all except HMS Amazon took part in the Falkland’s conflict. Two ships were lost: HMS Ardent was hit by bombs dropped by Argentine aircraft on 21 May and consumed by fire; HMS Antelope was hit by bombs on 23 May, one of which was set off by the bomb disposal team attempting to defuse it on 24 May, causing the ship to catch fire and setting off her magazines, resulting in her breaking her back and sinking.

name: UK Police Memorial
description:
POLICE MEMORIAL
More than 4000 men and women have given their lives in the service of their communities while wearing the uniform. On entering there is descriptive text and a ‘Sillitoe’ tartan, evoking the Police uniform. The space is entered through a tall doorway supporting a brass screen. The doorway represents a ‘threshold’ - the threshold to a different space and ‘the dangerous places where police go’. Leaf-shaped apertures represent service, sacrifice and particularly lives lost: Absence. The brass will weather while the gilt edges remain bright, and as the sun shines the paved surface will be lit by this gilded absence. The leaf-shaped ‘stage’ with two further low screens, creates a more intimate space - like a Lady Chapel within a church. Lawn space for more than 1500 people enables ceremonies and services. Occasional bench seating provides intimate, reflective spaces, tucked onto and backed by the slopes and ring of trees. Raised edges to the sunny circular glade surrounded by a bold and simple ring of trees impart a sense of enclosure and protection, the glade itself edged and embraced by the wilder more natural wooded part of the Arboretum.

name: Ulster Ash Grove
description:
ULSTER ASH GROVE 
The grove of ash trees has been planted as a living tribute to those members of the RUC, the RUC Reserve, the Armed Forces and other organisations who lost their lives during the period of ‘the troubles’ between 1969 - 2001. 
Many of the names appearing on dedication plaques in the Grove will also be found engraved on the walls of our Armed Forces Memorial. 
Further inside the Grove is a small memorial for the 29 Prison Officers murdered in Ulster during that time.

name: Ulster Ash Grove Memorial
description:
Ulster Ash Grove Memorial
The Ulster Grove memorial, made of Mourne granite, is in grateful memory of the men and women of the Royal Ulster Constabulary GC, the Armed Forces and other originations in service of the Crown who laid down their lives in the cause of peace in Northern Ireland 1969-2001. It was dedicated on 23 September 2003, the anniversary of the death of the first soldier in 1969. At the beginning of the UlsterAsh Grove is a stone circle reflecting the geography and geology of Northern Ireland. There is one block of stone from each county: Londonderry, Tyrone, Armagh, Antrim, Fermanagh, Down. They are laid out to form a symbolic map of Northern Ireland and enclose a simple granite pillar with a dedication to those involved and they form a tranquil place where people can rest and remember those who lost their lives. The lives of all soldiers (British and UDR) are commemorated by ash trees, one for each soldier killed in action. The ash was chosen because of the Irish song ‘Down by the Ash Grove’. The memorial trees are dedicated by Regiment and then by date of death. The Ulster Ash Grove was dedicated on the anniversary of the death of the first soldier in 1969. The Ulster Defence Regiment became operational on 1 April 1970 to support the Regular Army and the Royal Ulster Constabulary in protecting the people of Northern Ireland against sabotage and armed attack. Both men and women originally served part-time but as responsibilities increased nearly half became full-time. 193 men and 4 women were killed on operations, in their homes or workplace. Another 63 were also killed by terrorist action. The UDR merged with the Royal Irish Rangers to form the Royal Irish Regiment on 1st July 1992. In October, the Queen awarded those who had served with the Ulster Defence Regiment and Home Service Battalions of the Irish Regiment with the unique collective award of The Conspicuous Gallantry Cross. There is an avenue of trees and a pavement of dedicated granite paviours remembering each of those who died. The Royal Ulster Constabulary worked to protect life and property, prevent and detect crime, and keep communities safe from 1922 to 2001. While endeavouring to keep the fabric of society together against ruthless Irish terrorists 312 officers lost their lives and over 10,000 were seriously injured. Queen Elizabeth II awarded the RUC the George Cross for their gallantry and courage in trying to keep the peace in Northern Ireland. The memorial to the RUC is the RUC George Cross Way which has granite paviours identifying each of the 38 Sub-divisional policing areas in Northern Ireland with an Irish Juniper tree planted behind each one. Halfway along the RUC George Cross way is a black granite memorial stone from Mourne with the RUC and George Cross crests inscribed.

name: Ulster Defence Regiment CGC Memorial
description:
The Ulster Defence Regiment Conspicuous Gallantry Cross (CGC)
In 2007 the CGC was awarded to the Ulster Defence Regiment for its service in Northern Ireland. The CGC is a second level military decoration of the British Armed Forces. Created in 1993 and first awarded in 1995, it was instituted after a review of the British honours system to remove distinctions of rank in the awarding of gallantry decorations. The Victoria Cross is the only higher combat gallantry award presented by the United Kingdom

name: Ulster Defence Regiment CGC Memorial Seat
description:
Ulster Defence Regiment CGC Memorial
The Ulster Defence Regiment (UDR) was an infantry regiment formed in 1970. It was the largest regiment in the British Army - carrying out regular patrols and establishing vehicle checkpoints on the public roads of Northern Ireland. The UDR was operational for 22 years before amalgamating with the Royal Irish Rangers in 1992 to form the Royal Irish Regiment. In 2007, the Conspicuous Gallantry Cross was awarded to the regiment for its service in Northern Ireland and now uses the post nominal letters CGC as part of its name (The Ulster Defence Regiment CGC). The memorial, a polished grey stone bench, bears the inscription: The Regimental Association of The Ulster Defence Regiment CGC. Donated by the Portadown Branch. The badge of the UDR, a gold harp topped with a crown, appears above the inscription. Accompanying the bench are a series of low-level dedicated plinths punctuating the Royal Ulster Defence Regiment Memorial Way.

name: Ulster Special Constabulary Memorial
description:
ULSTER SPECIAL CONSTABULARY
The black marble monolith pays tribute to those who served, but especially those who lost their lives during the period of ‘the troubles’. The Ulster Special Constabulary was formed originally in 1920 and was intended to be a reserve, or ‘back up’ service for the Royal Ulster Constabulary, whose memorial we will see shortly. The Special Constabulary was stood down in 1970.

name: Union Castle Line Memorial
description:
Union Castle Line 
The memorial plaque accompanies a line of trees dedicated to the ships of Union Castle Mail Steamship Company lost in the Second World War and to the sea and shore staff who died as a result of enemy action.

name: United Nations Avenue ; UN
description:
United Nations Avenue; UN
This is an avenue of giant redwoods planted alongside the mainline railway bridge, which will be clearly visible from passing trains as the trees grow. Member countries of the United Nations have sponsored the trees and plaques.

name: Vera Atkins - SOE Memorial
description:
Vera Atkins and the women of "F" section (French)
Special Operations Executive
Born in Romania in 1908, Vera Maria Atkins (née Rosenburg) was one of five children and the only daughter of a wealthy German-Jewish businessman. Adopting the surname ‘Atkins’ (an Anglicised version of her Jewish mother’s maiden name “Etkins”), she came to Britain in the late 1930s to scape the threatening political situation in Europe and the growing extremism and antisemitism
developing in Romania. Vera was recrutied by the Special Operations Executive and given special responsibility to the women agents who were being sent into occupied France to act as couriers, radio operators and to help train the resistance forces. After the war she went back into Europe to find out what had happened to her women agents who did not return and found that 12 of them had been captured and executed in German Concentration Camps. She is remembered as a resourceful, forthright woman whose special diplomacy and negotiation skills provided much needed intelligence during the Second World War. Before her death in 2000 (age 92), Atkins was appointed CBE in the 1997 Birthday Honours. She was previously awarded the Croix de Guerre in 1948 and made a Knight of the Legion of Honour by the French government in 1995. Located in the Allied Special Forces Memorial Grove is a memorial dedicated to Vera Atkins, Intelligence Officer of "F" section (French) - Special Operations Executive. The geometric shape of the seat is a Hexagram with the inner line being a Hexagon. The Hexagram has been a design used in all religions. This is built around a Pine Tree grown from a seed found in a cone at Natzweiler Concentration Camp in the Vosges mountains of Eastern France. The memorial was unveiled by Baroness Crawley, Baroness Verma, Colonel Nicholas Chambaz and Zenna Atkins on the 24 September 2011. 
This memorial was designed and constructed by Mike Colton.Dedicated in 2011.
NOTE: - Six small information plaques are currently being manufactured. (19/2/23)
(The original memorial plaques have been relocated into the Sun Room.)

name: Victims of Overseas Terrorism
description:
Victims of Overseas Terrorism
This national memorial recognises the loss that has been suŽered by British families through acts of terrorism overseas. The memorial sculpture named ‘Still Water’ is designed to represent the calm after the storm, reflecting how the trauma of an event for any person who suŽers loss will eventually lessen but not be forgotten.

name: Victoria Cross Commemorative Paving Stones ; WW1 VC Paviours
description:
The Victoria Cross 
The Victoria Cross is awarded for:- 
... most conspicuous bravery, or some daring or pre-eminent act of valour or self-sacrifice, or extreme devotion to duty in the presence of the enemy. 
The VC is the first level award for all ranks of the British armed forces. 
The Victoria Cross was founded by Royal Warrant dated 29th January 1856. Queen Victoria presented the first 62 awards in Hyde Park on 26th June 1857: 12 Navy, 2 Royal Marines and 48 Army. 
The warrant has been amended several times. E.g.: 
In 1902 King Edward VII approved the principle of awarding the VC posthumously. 
_On 21st October 1911 King George V admitted native officers and other ranks of the Indian Army to eligibility for the VC. 
The warrant of 22nd May 1922 extended the scope of the award to include members of the RAF, and ‘Air Forces of our Dominions, Colonies, Dependencies or Protectorates’; and ‘Matrons, sisters, nurses and staff of the Nursing Services and other services pertaining to Hospitals and Nursing and civilians of either sex serving regularly or Temporarily under the orders, direction or supervision’ of specified Naval Military or Air Forces. 

The medal, made from the bronze cascabels of cannon captured at Sebastopol, has always been manufactured by Messrs Hancocks of London. 
The ribbon, 1½ inches wide, has been crimson since the Royal Warrant of 22nd May 1920 (originally it was crimson for the army and dark blue for the navy) and the inscription on the medal reads ‘FOR VALOUR’. When the ribbon is worn alone a miniature of the V.C. is placed at the centre of the ribbon. 
The bar to the V.C. has been awarded on only three occasions: Captain Arthur Martin-Leake R.A.M.C. (Vlakfontein, South Africa 1902 and Zonnebeke 1914), Captain Noel Godfrey Chavasse R.A.M.C. (Guillemont 1916 and Wieltje1917) and Captain Charles Hazlitt Upham NZ Army (Crete 1941 and Western Desert 1942). 
The Victoria Cross has been awarded on1358 occasions; to 1355 individuals, the three bars mentioned above and one to the Unknown Soldier buried in Arlington National Cemetery, Washington, DC. In addition to British service personnel it has been awarded to 5 civilians and to 14 non British Empire/Commonwealth citizens. 
In recent years Canada, Australia and New Zealand have awarded their own version of the Victoria Cross through their own honours systems. One New Zealand VC and 4 Australian VCs have been awarded. 
Five of the largest public collections of Victoria Cross’ are in the Australian War Memorial which has 80 (including 10 on loan), The Imperial War Museum which has 45 (including 28 on loan), the National Army Museum which has 40 (including 1 one loan), The Canadian War Museum (which has 39) and the Museum of Military Medicine which has 23. The largest private collection is the Ashcroft Collection which has 213 (displayed in the Imperial War Museum).

name: War Widows' Memorial
description:
War Widows Association Memorial 
The War Widows Memorial is located at the front of the War Widows Wood. It includes the emblem of the War Widows Association of Great Britain and a dedication to those who died in service of their country. 
The woodland is a mixture of individually dedicated native trees sponsored by war widows in memory of their husbands who never returned from conflict. 
The War Widows Association of Great Britain was founded in 1971. It campaigns to improve conditions for War Widows, War Widowers, partners and dependants who lost their lives serving in the Armed Forces.

name: War Widows' Rose Garden
description:
War Widows’ Rose Garden 
A tribute to the Nation’s war widows who often endure great hardship, as well as emotional stress, through the loss of their husbands. The garden is designed to take visitors along the journey of bereavement through the colours of the roses – it begins with the reds of anger, into the purples of despair, then passes through the gentler colours of quiet acceptance and finally into the yellows of happy memories.

name: War Widows' Wood
description:
War Widows Wood Map
The War Widows Wood is a mixture of individually dedicated native trees sponsored by war widows in memory of their husbands who never returned from conflict.

name: Watersmeet
description: no information available

name: Western Front Association Memorial
description:
The Western Front Association Memorial
On the side of the memorial shown is the second verse of ‘For the Fallen’ used on many occasions of remembrance. On the reverse are the two final lines from the poem ‘Aftermath’ by Siegfried Sassoon.

name: Women's Auxiliary Air Force (WAAF) Memorial
description:
WOMANS RAF 
It existed in two separate incarnations: the Women's Royal Air Force from 1918 to 1920 and the Women's Royal Air Force from 1949 to 1994. On 1 February 1949, the name of the First World War organisation was revived when the Women's Auxiliary Air Force, which had been founded in 1939, was re-established on a regular footing as the Women's Royal Air Force. The RAF and WRAF merged in 1994

name: Women's Auxiliary Service - The Chinthe Women Memorial
description:
THE CHINTHE WOMEN 
The plaque here remembers a group of Ladies known as the Women's Auxiliary Service (Burma) who operated static and mobile canteens for our troops during WW2 in Burma, supplying tea, cakes and cigarettes. 
These women had been working in the Far East when war broke out but opted to stay there. They set up mobile canteens close to the front line. 
The image on the plaque is of a 'Chinthe', a mythical beast which guards Burmese Temples, from which the Ladies took their nickname.

name: Women's Institute Memorial Seat ; WI Wall
description:
The Women’s Institute Memorial Seat
WI Wall was designed and built by one of Derbyshire’s only registered female dry stonewaller’s, Sally Hodgson. Established in 1915, the Women’s Institute set out to give women a voice and to be a force for good in the community. Today, it is the largest women’s organisation in the United Kingdom and prides itself on being a trusted place for all women of all generations, to share experiences and learn from each other.

name: Women's Land Army and Timber Corps Memorial
description:
WOMEN’S LAND ARMY & WOMEN’S TIMBER CORPS 
▪ This is a tribute to those ladies, some as young as 17, who went to serve on our farms during both World Wars and in the forests during WW2. 
▪ We were importing about 70% of our food and the impact of U-Boats, a poor harvest and so many farm workers away fighting meant a real shortage of food. That is where these women came to the nation’s rescue. 
▪ Shown around the plinth are some of the trades they had to learn (Snedding is cleaning the side branches from a tree trunk and Snigging is moving a felled tree trunk by means of a chain wrapped round it, usually pulled by a horse). 
▪ The dead rat shows how important it was to control pests, known as ‘Hitler’s little helpers’, from eating the stored food. 
▪ The Timber Corps (known as ‘Lumber Jills’, as opposed to ‘Lumberjacks’) was formed in 1942, with the girls taking on the same work as the men and working to keep us supplied with timber. 
▪ The model for the Land Girl was Isobel Wright, whose grandmother Mary had been a Land Girl herself. 
▪ Many former Land Army and Timber Corps women came to the dedication ceremony for this memorial in October 2014, the youngest being 84yrs old and the oldest 101! 
▪ The Timber Corps was disbanded in 1946 and the Land Army in 1950. Turn from the Naval Review and move to the Royal Air Force Wing

name: Women's Royal Air Force ; WRAF
description:
WOMANS RAF 
It existed in two separate incarnations: the Women's Royal Air Force from 1918 to 1920 and the Women's Royal Air Force from 1949 to 1994. On 1 February 1949, the name of the First World War organisation was revived when the Women's Auxiliary Air Force, which had been founded in 1939, was re-established on a regular footing as the Women's Royal Air Force. The RAF and WRAF merged in 1994

name: Women's Royal Army Corps Memorial ; WRAC
description:
WOMEN’s ROYAL ARMY CORPS 
Women served in both World Wars in various units and by the end of the Second World War it was acknowledged that women would be a valuable asset to a peace-time army, so the Women’s Royal Army Corps was formed.
They served all over the world in over 35 trades and over 1200 died in service.
The WRAC was disbanded in 1992
The raised beds form the letter ‘W’, while the trees and bushes either have ladies’ names or their foliage/flowers are the colours of the women’s uniforms.
Also in the garden is are two statues dedicated to all the women who served in the Auxiliary Territorial Service (ATS).
When the ATS was formed in 1938 there were 5 main trades: Cook, Clerk, Orderly, Store woman and Driver but as time passed, more and more trades were taken over, including highly-skilled and technical work and tasks which the organisation of the army depended upon, such as equipment and ammunition. Index
The Queen served in the ATS as 2nd Lieutenant Elizabeth Windsor as did Mary Churchill, the youngest daughter of Winston.
The ATS and WRAC memorials were both designed by Andy de Comyn
Andy de Comyn also designed the Shot at Dawn, Mercian Volunteers, Women’s RAF and National Miners memorials at the NMA
The ATS ACK- ACK memorial was relocated into this garden when the National Miners Memorial was erected at the NMA
During WW1 the code for the letter A in the phonetic alphabet was ‘Ack’, so the AA of Anti-Aircraft became ‘Ack-Ack’.
These girls had a strong link with the Royal Artillery, especially working alongside them in the anti-aircraft batteries. Officially the girls did everything apart from firing the guns (this was a political decision rather than a physical one), but we have had former ‘Ack-Ack’ ladies here who tell us they most certainly DID fire the guns, saying there is no way they would let their homes be bombed just because there wasn’t a man there to pull the lever.

name: Women's Royal Naval Service (WRNS) (Wrens)
description:
WOMEN'S ROYAL NAVAL SERVTCE (WRNS)
The installation of the AOW Centenary Stone took place on Wednesday 23rd September 2020 in the WRNS Garden. The memorial represents one hundred years since the Association was formed and it is very fitting that installation was able to go ahead in what should have been a year of celebration when so many planned events had to be cancelled. The stone was constructed by Robyn Golden-Hann. It represents not only former wrens but also the Women of the Royal Naval Services as they are today. The WRNS were founded in l9l7 to support the men of the Royal Navy, but were disbanded in 1919. In 1939, at the outbreak of WW2, they were re-established and remained in service until 1993 when they were fully integrated into the Royal Navy. Women now carry out exactly the same duties as their male counterparts, both at sea and ashore. The garden is dedicated to all who served in the service and is designed to encourage birds, insects and butterflies. The pathways form the shape of an anchor. The wren, which was carved by the Essex Woodcarvers, forms part of a memorial for the 21 WRNS and a Naval Nursing Sister who lost their lives when their ship, SS Aguila, was torpedoed inl94l. One of the first WRNS to see active service was Wendy Clayin, who in 1990, served on board HMS Brilliant. The Women’s Royal Naval Service (WRNS), known as the Wrens, was formed in 1917 to release Royal Navy men for sea service during the First World War. It was disbanded after the war. On 11th April 1939 Vera Laughton Matthews was appointed Director of the newly reformed Women’s Royal Naval Service WRNS: she had previously been a member during World War 1. It was originally envisaged that there would be about 3000 women in the WRNS, however at its peak the number was more than 65,000. Around 75,000 Wrens carried out highly confidential and responsible roles in Britain and overseas. The WRNS was fully integrated into the Royal Navy in 1993.
Index
This charming garden at the far end of the Royal Naval Review is dedicated to the WRNS and has been designed to encourage birds, insects and butterflies. The paths are in the shape of an anchor. Buddleia shrubs provide a haven for butterflies in summer. The two rose beds are planted with “Wren” roses to celebrate the 90th anniversary of the Association of Wrens 1917 – 2007. Notcutts Nurseries developed this rose for the 2007 Chelsea Flower Show and donated plants to the Wrens Garden at the NMA. In the rose beds and against the trees may be found dedications to individual Wrens.
Located in the garden is the Aguila Memorial, a beautifully carved wren which commemorates the 21 WRNS and one Naval Nursing Sister who were lost when SS Aguila was torpedoed in 1941 (see M-152 Aguilla Memorial).

name: Women's Section Memorial, The Royal British Legion
description:
RBL Women’s Section 
The British Legion Women’s Section was formed in 1921 to safeguard the interests of widows and families of ex-Servicemen. It was also to provide a way for women to be a part of the British Legion and widen its activities. The Women’s Section is autonomous, self-funding, and also comes under the Royal Charter with Her Royal Highness the Princess Royal as the National President.

name: Wooden Minesweepers Memorial
description:
WOODEN MINESWEEPERS Map Index
As with all minesweeping vessels including the RNPS trawlers; these small warships were made from wood because many WW2 mines were magnetic and, therefore, attracted to metal.
The memorial plaque is dedicated to the men who served on the wooden minesweepers built to sweep the mines laid close to shore between 1941 – 1959. The memorial acknowledges the people of Shelburne, Lunenburg and Metaghan for their hospitality to the British Crews who joined 122 MSF built in Nova Scotia.

name: Y Services Organisation
description:
“Y” LISTENING GROUP 
The paths in this garden are laid out in the form of a letter ‘Y’. 
 “Y” comes from the initials for “Wireless Interception”…….”WI” sound like “Y” 
Inspiration for the memorial came from a group of ATS (Auxiliary Territorial Service) ladies who served in the War Office ‘Y’ Group at Beaumanor Hall, near Loughborough and other such stations. 
During WW2 men and women who were found to have the required skills and passed intensive Morse code training were recruited to serve at secret listening stations around the UK to monitor German radio transmissions which had been encoded using Enigma machines. 
Once intercepted the enemy's military messages, still in code, were sent to Bletchley Park - also known as Station X - to be decrypted by its talented, ingenious and often eccentric code-breakers. 
The Germans did not believe that radio messages sent over short distances in occupied Europe could be picked up in England. They could! In short, without the Y Service, Bletchley would not have had the coded Enigma messages to decipher, and the work of these combined teams of many thousands of secret and silent heroes is now widely acknowledged as having shortened WW2 by at least two years. 
Winston Churchill called those involved his "geese that laid the golden eggs but never cackled". 
In the right-hand corner is a bench in memory of the 3 Royal Navy men from the warship HMS Petard - Colin Grazier, Tony Fasson and Tommy Brown - who were instrumental in recovering code books from a sinking German submarine in 1942, which helped considerably in breaking the German Enigma code. 
Unfortunately, Colin Grazier (a native of Tamworth) and Tony Fasson drowned when the submarine sank. Both were awarded the George Cross.

name: Yangtze Incident Memorial
description:
Yangtze Incident Memorial 
The Yangtze Incident memorial commemorates those who lost their lives when the British Royal Navy ship HMS Amethyst was trapped on the Yangtze River for three months during the Chinese Civil War in 1949. 
The circular planting of 46 Chinese euonymus plants commemorates each life lost during the Yangtze Incident in China in 1949. 
A plaque alongside the memorial tells the full story of the Yangtze Incident. Inside the circle is a black polished granite monument and trees planted as a tribute to HMS Amethyst, HMS Black Swan, HMS Consort and HMS London which were the four ships involved in the incident. The human cost in the four ships was 46 dead and 68 injured. 
The tree planted just outside the circle remembers the RAF Sunderland flying boat, named D-DOG ML772, from 88 Squadron. On its fourth attempt it landed successfully on the Yangtze River alongside HMS Amethyst to deliver medical supplies and a replacement doctor. 
Royal Indian Navy and Army Memorial Map 
Between the Yangtze Incident and Far East Air Force memorials, trees from the Indian sub-continent such as Kashmir rowan, cedar and Bhutan pine have been planted as a tribute to those who served in the Royal Indian Navy (1934 – 1947) and Indian Army. The memorial lies within a small area surrounded by a hedge. 
The British Indian Army (1858 – 1947) was a force recruited locally during the British Colonisation of India and commanded by British and Indian officers. Substantial numbers of Indian soldiers served in both World Wars. Note also the memorials to the Dogra, Baluch and Sikh soldiers. 
The Royal Indian Navy had its origins in the East India Company’s Marine, later the Bombay Marine. From 1830 to 1858 the Bombay Marine became the Indian Navy. After the end of Company rule in 1857 the name reverted to Bombay Marine until in 1877 it was renamed Her Majesties Indian Marine. In 1892 it became the Royal Indian Marine. With the introduction of the Indian Navy (Discipline) Act 1934, the Royal Indian Navy was formally inaugurated on 2nd October 1934; its ships carried the prefix HMIS. During WW2 the service greatly expanded, and the Women’s Royal Indian Naval Service was established. Two of its sloops HMIS Sutlej and HMIS Jumna played a role in the invasion of Sicily. In 1947 the Navy was split between India and Pakistan. From 1950 when India became a republic the ships have been prefixed INS.

name: Yeomanry Avenue
description:
Yeomanry Avenue 
This is an avenue of 48 large and small leaved lime trees where each tree is dedicated to a Yeomanry Unit. 
In the 1790s, the threat of invasion of the Kingdom of Great Britain was high after the French Revolution and the rise of Napoleon Bonaparte. In order to improve the country’s defences, volunteer regiments were raised in many counties from yeomen. 
The word ‘yeoman’ refers to small farmers who owned the land they cultivated, but the officers were drawn from the nobility and many of the men were their tenants. Yeomen were not obliged to serve overseas without their individual consent. 
During the first half of the 19th century, Yeomanry Regiments were used extensively in support of the civil authority to suppress riots and civil disturbances (including the Peterloo Massacre), but as police forces took over this role, the Yeomanry concentrated on local defence. During the Boer War, companies of The Imperial Yeomanry were formed from volunteers from the Yeomanry to serve overseas. In 1908, the Yeomanry became part of the Territorial Army.

name: YMCA Memorial
description:
YMCA Memorial
The YMCA is an international Christian movement. The memorial is dedicated to all those who, through the YMCA, served the Armed Forces in times of war and peace, some of whom gave their lives in the service of others.

name: Yorkshire Regiment Memorial
description:
Yorkshire Regiment 
The Yorkshire Regiment was formed from three former regiments: The Prince of Wales’s Own Regiment of Yorkshire, The Green Howards, and the Duke of Wellington’s Regiment. 
The design of the Yorkshire Regiment memorial is based on The Keeper of the Souls, a replica of an interpretation piece which has been installed on the East Front of the York Minster. The Keeper of the Souls has a grand pedigree, being an original idea of HRH The Duke of York who was Colonel in Chief of the Regiment. During a visit to the stone yard in February 2009, he suggested that carvers might include a tribute to the soldiers and this idea was developed by Conservator Mason Carver; Lee Godfrey. 
The design of The Keeper of the Souls draws on the original motifs and meaning of York Minster’s Lady Chapel. It is based upon the 14 Angels who surmount York Minster’s Great East Windows depiction of God the Father in heaven. The East Window Angel voussoirs (wedge shaped stones used in the building of arches) influence the hair, facial features and cloud formation. The wings and position of the hands are based on angels hovering in the bosses of the Lady Chapel. Finally, the altars in the Lady Chapel were used as places to pray for the acceptance of departed souls. 
The angel holds a shield to protect the insignia and souls of the Yorkshire Regiment; the angel is also the protector to the insignia and souls of the antecedent regiment, namely: The Princes of Wales’s Own Regiment of Yorkshire, The Green Howards. The Duke of Wellington’s Regiment (West Riding), The Yorkshire Volunteers and the Yorkshire Volunteers and the York and Lancaster Regiment.

name: 14th-20th Kings Hussars Hawks
description:
14TH / 20TH KINGS HUSSARS (THE HAWKS)
Regiment is involved in tank training, armoured cars and tank destroyers. 
The ex-member’s club of the regiment is nicknamed ‘Noah’s Arc.’ (National Old and Ancient Hawks Annual Reunion Club).
