Sculpture / artist Alan Williams (who specialises in re-purposing scrap metal). 
Memorial is the regimental Hawk (‘also known as the Prussian Eagle’), made using items from the scrap bins of Tidworth Camp army barracks (tools, cogs, gears, nuts & bolts), set within a stone obelisk. The oval hole was cut through black granite by hand and has a 4cm glass rod running through the hole. 
The Prussian Eagle is the insignia of the Royal House of Prussia and was awarded to the 14th Light Dragoons in 1798 by the Crown Princess Frederica of Prussia. 
Princess Royal is the Colonel-in-Chief; the regiment forms part of the Royal Armoured Corp. 
Memorial was dedicated October 2022, almost exactly 100 years to the day since the formation of the regiment.

name: 1st Army 6th Armoured Division
description:
1ST ARMY
▪ 1st Army was first formed in WW1 1914-1918, then disbanded only to be reformed in WW2 1942-1943. They were reformed to fight in Operation Torch the allied invasion of North Africa. After the allied victory in 1943 the 1st Army was disbanded.

name: Anglo-German Garden
description:
ANGLO-GERMAN GROVE 
Circle of stones forming the ANGLO-GERMAN GROVE. The stones are from the Frauenkirche (Church of Our Lady) in Dresden, which was destroyed by bombing during WW2. The metal plates on the stones carry the names of British and German cities that were bombed.

Anne Frank

name: British Limbless Ex-Service Men’s Association (BLESMA)
description:
BLESMA
BLESMA stands for British Limbless Ex-Service Men’s Association 
BLESMA was formed in 1932 
BELSMA works to assist those who have lost limbs as a result of service in any branch of Her Majesty's Armed Forces. 
The garden is planted mostly with fruit trees which are kept purposely at a low height to allow easy access for those in wheelchairs both to smell the blossom in spring and harvest the fruit in autumn. 
An apple or pear, of course, does not need to be peeled for eating (requiring two hands) 
The circular benches do not have any arm rests. A service person may have lost their arms.

name: Corps of Army Music

name: David Childs' tree Founders Tree
description:
DAVID CHILDS TREES 
The Founders Tree can be found in the Neville Barry Grove where you will find David Childs Tree. Neville Barry was one of the first Groundsman to work on the site. 
▪ These two trees are dedicated to the founder of the NMA, David Childs CBE. In the late 80's David met with an old military friend, the late Group Captain Sir Leonard Cheshire VC, and they were concerned that we, as a nation, were beginning to forget to remember those who sacrificed so much for our freedom. David went away feeling some type of National Memorial was needed. 
▪ A few years later while in America on business for the Royal Navy, he found he had a spare day before returning home, and as he was in Washington DC, David spent a few hours at Arlington Military Cemetery and some time at the American National Arboretum. That's when the idea came to him of combining concepts of both those places to create a living memorial to Service and Sacrifice back home in the UK. 
▪ And as we say the rest is history.

name: Le Paradis Massacre Memorial
description: no information available

name: LGBT+ armed forces community
description:
The LGBTQ+ Armed Forces Community Memorial is a lasting and permanent memorial for all members of the LGBTQ+ Armed Forces Community. Following a nationwide competition, “An Opened Letter” is the result. Concept AN OPEN LETTER OF LOVE AND DEVOTION, USED AS EVIDENCE TO SHAME, PUNISH AND EXCLUDE, TRANSFORMED INTO A LETTER OF PRIDE, BEAUTY AND HONOUR. ‘An Open Letter’ is a unique, hand-made pierced bronze free-standing sculpture on a dedicated carved base. The letter is a combination of words taken from evidence collected from personnel who have experienced exclusion, discrimination and in some cases have died as a direct result of exposure of their true selves. The written word and page as a symbol of the struggle and fight for the LGBTQ+contribution to the Nation’s armed forces. The Abraxas Academy is an artist collaborative collective, who are honoured to be chosen for this unique and exceptional project. 
Materials Used - 10mm Aluminium Bronze sheet and York Stone Slab Designers - Abraxas Academy Ltd 
Holkham Forge - blacksmith
You can find out more about the history of the ban, the fight to overturn it, the lived histories of those who experienced it, and the project to memorialise it, by visiting the Fighting With Pride website: https://www.fightingwithpride.org.uk/lgbt-armed-forces-community-memorial/
Memorial Project Team - Roly Woods - Memorial Officer - Fighting With Pride
Kevin Bazeley - Deputy Memorial Officer - Fighting With Pride

name: Millennium Avenue
description:
Millennium Avenue incorporates a number of lime trees sponsored by High Sheriffs, some of whom were in office at the time of the Millennium. All these trees were propagated from the 2,000 year-old lime tree growing at Westonbirt Arboretum in Gloucestershire.
This Millennium sponsorship by High Sheriffs was singularly appropriate given that the office of High Sheriff (or Shire Reeve) is at least 1,000 years old, having its roots in Saxon times, well before the Norman Conquest of 1066. It is the oldest continuous secular office under the Crown.
Originally, a High Sheriff was vested with many of the powers a Lord Lieutenant, High Court Judges and Magistrates have today. The office of High Sheriff remained first in precedence in the counties until King Edward VII, by Order in Council in 1908, gave that primacy to the Lord Lieutenant. The High Sheriff remains the Sovereign’s representative in a county for all matters relating to the Judiciary and to the maintenance of law and order.
The involvement of the

Military Music Society

name: The Mall
description:
THE MALL 
This avenue is referred to as The Mall. Whilst not as wide and straight as The Mall in London, it is lined with London Plane trees (which also line the Mall in London). Between these trees are some flowering cherry trees, the blossom representing the red tunics of the guardsmen lining the route on state occasions..
